Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: Unknown
text: You would never have thought, from observing the performance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in question time on Monday, that there were any problems in this country at all. Mr Rocher-You mean the deficit dalek?

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: Unknown
text: The deficit dalek. You would have thought, from the way he filibustered his way through and carried on, that everything was rosy. Yet we are about to hear from the Reserve Bank, I assume following its meeting this morning, that there will be a further increase in interest rates in this try.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: Unknown
text: Certain to be.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: Unknown
text: There is a very good chance of that. That will be the third interest rate rise we have had in recent times. We have already had an increase of 1% per cent, and I wonder what we can expect to see as a result of today's Reserve Bank meeting. There are a lot of concerns in this country about the economy and one would think, from watching the government's performance, that everything was rosy. I remind the government that increases in interest rates affect average families. They affect the mums and dads. They affect not only rich people, but all people. If we are to have a further increase in interest rates-say one per cent-how much a month does that add to the average mortgage payment?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: Unknown
text: About 35 bucks.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: Unknown
text: The honourable member for Mitchell says it is about $35; perhaps it is even more than that. The point is that this is an expense for average people. The government is looking at ways to reduce its deficit. We are yet to see how it is going to go about doing that. It could take a responsible course, one that we have been advocating: it could look carefully at reducing government expenditure. Ido not pretend that that is easy. We do not believe that that is an easy proposition at all. There are lots of calls on government expenditure; nevertheless, reducing government expenditure is a responsible way forward to attack the budget deficit. This government is clearly a tax and spend government. Therefore,路 the option least attractive to it will be to look critically at government revenue. Having avoided that, despite the calls for a deficit reduction strategy by the Governor of the Reserve Bank on a number of occasions, the government is now about to take the much easier option of increasing taxes. As we pointed out to the Prime Minister in question time on Monday, that is in the context of promises prior to the last election to not increase taxes. No matter how the Prime Minister might want to get around that and argue about the semantics of that, it was very counclear to us-I think it was very clear to everyone in Australia-that, prior to the last election, the Prime Minister was saying that there would be no increases in taxes. The Prime Minister's whole election strategy was based on criticism of our proposal to bring in what ultimately would have been a much fairer, more efficient and more equitable tax system. The government's whole election strategy was an attack on us. The government went to the extreme of bringing legislation into this parliament which was aimed at convincing the Australian people that its strategy was to match our proposal to reduce income tax. So we had the famous l-aw tax cuts. Despite what the Prime Minister said in question time on Monday, the government has reneged on that promise. It has repealed that legislation. The second stage of those income tax reductions is now not to be delivered until some time in 1998, which is a long way down the track. There is no doubt at all in my mind that the tax cuts will disappear completely off the agenda long before that. Rather than have further decreases in income tax, we will see increases in taxes and charges. The opposition is now totally aware, and the Australian people should be aware, that the problem of how to raise more revenue for the purposes of doing what needs to be done-reducing the deficit-is very much on the government's agenda. The government's current substantial deficit is the result of its high spending policies. Almost every day in this place a minister comes in here with a new spending initiative, a new program or a new paper of some sort that foreshadows spending. In the end, that is the only thing this government knows how to do-spend other people's money. Much of this money is wasted. Much of it is to solve problems that the government has created in the first place. Its strategy for reducing unemto ployment is largely based on throwing money at the problem rather than carrying out the fundamental reforms in the economy, which would lead to real job creation. That is not a difficult proposition. We on this side of the House understand clearly that to create real jobs we need to make it possible for businesses to employ more people. That is a simple proposition. But rather than go down the track of proper micro-economic reform and proper reform of the industrial relations system, which this government cannot do because it is bound to the rules set up by the unions-it is governed by the unions-it comes in here with all sorts of other panaceas, such as training programs and subsidies to employers. Everything is done back to front. The government always puts the cart in front of the horse rather than coming up with real and, in the end, simpler solutions to the problems of unemployment. Let us not talk about increasing taxes, which the government is talking about, to solve the problem. Ironically, the solution to the problem is to reduce taxes and charges. In reducing taxes and charges, particularly on small business, employment will be stimulated. There are about one million small businesses in Australia. It does not take too much imagination to realise that if each of those small businesses employed one more person there would be a significant impact on the number of unemployed. When I go out .to my electorate, as I have recently done, and visit small businesses, look at what they are doing and talk to them about their problems, one of the problems they raise consistently is the need to get trained staff. They have certainly been let down on that score, with the very low number of apprentices currently being trained. There is a lack of trained staff and a lack of staff who are prepared to work hard. Small business people in my electorate consistently tell me that they would employ one, two, three, four or路 five more people tomorrow if they could get people who were genuine about seeking work. This government has created a system whereby people can actually choose whether work or not. Despite its attempts in recent times to address the issue of the unemployment benefit being too generous, once again in a bandaid fashion it has simply tinkered at the edges making it possible for people to actually retain their unemployment benefit at the same time as doing some work. Employers in my electorate tell me that people are still saying to them, 'I'm sorry. I really think there are some benefits for me in getting back into the work force, but, unfortunately, I can get as much in benefits from the government by the time. I add them all up, having three or four children, as the wage you are offering me, even if it is the award wage' - and let us assume that those wages in many respects are very generous-'and it really is not worth my while coming to work for you.' Alternatively, I am being told that people are saying, 'I'm getting the unemployment benefit and you have got a desperate need for my particular trade, so I will come and work for you if you just give me a bit of cash or whatever on the side. As long as it does not interfere with my unemployment benefit, I am prepared to work for you.' Mr O'Keefe-It doesn't really happen that way.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: Unknown
text: It does; If you want to come to my electorate, I will take you out and we can visit business after businessMr O'Keefe-You are just perpetuating a popular myth. It doesn't happen that way, and there is any amount of evidence to show that it doesn't.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: Unknown
text: It is not a myth. I am telling you that I have been out in my electorate in recent weeks and this is what is happening. The people on the other side of the House are totally deluded; they just do not exist in the real world. It is a pity that not, because if they went out and saw what was happening in the real world, they would be very concerned. The government's feeble attempts to solve the problems of this country are not going to work. We already see evidence, despite the assurances given yesterday by the Treasurer (Mr Willis), that we will be back on a boom-bust cycle. The government has already lost control of the economy and that will become evident before very long. The government needs to be reminded-and I take the opportunity in the context of this debate about government expenditure-that the solution to this'country's problems is not to talk about increasing taxes, but rather decreasing taxes. In the context of decreasing taxes, rather than talking about spending money, it ought to be looking seriously at saving money and looking at many of the programs. It is almost impossible for a member of parliament who has been here for five yearslet alone for the average person in the street who is subjected to all sorts of propositions by the Department of Social Security or the Commonwealth Employment Service-to understand the complexity of so many of the programs that it has brought in. There is such a diversity of programs-the government is putting money into this and money into thatyet the solutions to the huge problel;TIS of our overseas debt and the level of unemployment that persists in this country are much simpler. They do not relate to spending money; they actually relate to doing exactly the opposite. The solution I advocate as far as deficit reduction is concerned is to look critically at what the government is actually spending. Ironically, in doing that to reduce taxes it will have the effect of encouraging businesses to employ more people and there will be increased revenue to the government by virtue of the dividend that will flow from that. I am very concerned about the prospect of increasing interest rates. I think we are all waiting to see what the result of the meeting this morning will be. We already have very high interest rates in this country. From that base" we are about to step off further onto the treadmill which we have been on before. The they do Australian people remember very well the promises we have had in the past-in 1985 and beyond. We have experienced this situation before. We were told that everything was under control. We were told budget after budget that everything was fine, that we were going along well, then we had the worse recession in 60 years. We are about to get back on that same track, that same treadmill, that will take us in that same direction. Let me remind the House of the impact higher interest rates will have not only on families but also on small business. Many small bUsinesses went broke during the last recession because of not only reduced demand for their products but, initially and subsequently, higher interest rates. Most small businesses rely, to a very large extent, on borrowing money for one purpose or another. They have overdrafts, short-term loans and longer term financing, but they are affected by increasing interest rates. As interest rates escalated rapidly, as they did in the late 1980s and early 1990s, many of them went broke. The effect of that was unemployment. I am very concerned about the prospect of increasing interest rates that we now have on the agenda for this country. Frankly, I do not accept the assurances of the Treasurer that the government has the economy under control. The fact is, and certainly even the government's own advice appears to have been, that it lost control of the economy very early on. In the context of this debate, I want to place on record my dismay at the way this government is managing the economy; in fact, it is mismanaging the economy. It has created a welfare system in this country that has pervaded almost the whole of our society. I wonder at times whether that is intentional. It is almost a new form of socialism that has been thrust upon us, a form of socialism that is not as obvious as earlier forms. Yet 4.4 million people in this country are now totally dependent on this路 government. In the early 1970s around 10 per cent of people were dependent on government for their primary source of income. The figure today is closer to 27 per cent or 28 per cent. That represents an enormous cost to government and it ought to be of great concern to people that 'that is the trend. Average families that previously were not in the government welfare net now find themselves there by virtue of the home child-care allowance. We previously received the dependent spouse rebate through the tax system. It worked very efficiently but the government, for the purpose of another of its agendasthat is, political correctness-decided that out the wrong signals. Hundreds of thousands of people who were never involved with the Department of Social Security before went through the intrusive process of having the Department of Social Security write to. them and ask all sorts of questions that were never relevant to the tax office in getting the dependent spouse rebate. That was available to people by a very simple mechanism. We now find ourselves-I say 'we' because my family is included-in the Department of Social Security computer system. We are now numbers in the Department of Social Security. We never wanted to be involved with the Department of Social Security. We_. were perfectly happy with the arrangements before with the dependent spouse rebate. Now we get $30 a week. I worked out the other day that we end up with $10 a month more than we used to get. I am paying for it because my tax has been increased as a result of my losing the dependent spouse rebate. Each month I get less money. My wife gets it back the same month via the tax office and the Department of Social Security. We can only imagine how many extra public servants have had to be employed in the Department of Social Security to manage that new system. I believe that we are heading down the road towards the next election with the govemmeM in complete disarray, as far as concerns its management of the economy and its whole range of policies. I believe that the Australian people will wake up to the fact they have been conned in many respects, that they have been misled. The irony of this is that they have experienced all of this before. We intend to remind the Australian people, and the government, as we head down the track toward the路 next election, that this Prime Minister was the Treasurer who consistently told us, in all of those years through the 1980s and early 1990s, that we were on track, that everything was under control. We knew then that it was not, we know now that it is not, and we intend to remind the people of Australia about that every day between now and the next election.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: Unknown
text: 1 intend to take this opportunity in the sent debate on the appropriation bills to raise a matter which I think is very important but is being disregarded in Australia. Listening to the last speaker, the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford), I must say that it is heartening to know there are some things that are bipartisan in this parliament-and, clearly, massive ignorance is one of them. We are being told that the future of Australia and of the world lies in some great EI Dorado of free trade. This has always been, basically, the policy of the Liberal Party. With my own party it has not been so, but in recent times we too have embraced this sterile ideology. I think we need to look very hard at what this policy offers us. In my view, the policy is dead wrong and dangerous for Australia. We are told by Minister MCMullan-in fact, by the World Bank-that implementing the full GATT agreement would increase world trade by $213 billion in the next 10 years. That is a lot of money. But we really have to analyse that against what world trade would be if we did not have GATT. If we did that analysis, we would find that the world trade figures would be about the same. Furthermore, $213 billion is 0.7 per cent of world trade. It is no- a. very. significant amount, but its redistribution could have catastrophic consequences. The Secretary-General of the OECD admits that the figures are highly theoretical and also theatrical. I think it does give us cause for real concern. We are told that cheap goods produced by low cost labour overseas will be good for consumers. What governments and oppositions tend to forget is that consumers are workers also. There is absolutely no doubt that, if we are to govern for the benefit of the people of this country, Australia must be a high wage country. There is no future in going down the low wage route. For one thing, there is simply no end to it. If overnight we were to cut a full 33 per cent off the cost of employing labour in Australia, it would simply mean that our competitors would be able to employ something like 30 cheap labour workers, say, Filipinos or Vietnamese, instead of the 40 or 45 workers they do employ now. If we analyse these figures, we can see it is a very dangerous and foolish road for Australia to go down. I think we could also ask ourselves: do we, as a developed country, have any moral responsibility to open our markets to Third World countries? I would argue that we do not. I would also say that, if a country by good luck or good management is able to obtain for its citizens a high standard with good services and a good quality of life, there is absolutely no justification for that country to sacrifice those things on the altar of some altruistic view that we have to help other people. If we go down that road, we will find it is endless also: those countries will not reciprocate; they will simply bypass us and leave us for dead. I drove back from Parkes this morning. I took my son down there last night because he is going to work in Parkes for a company called Austops. Austops is a very interesting company. It produces the highest quality and the cheapest wool tops in the world. We in Australia are unbeatable in this field, if we do it right. We sell our tops in a completely unprotected market. It has always been that way and, as far as I can see, it always will. Free trade does nothing for this industry. It is I already there and we are already highly competitive. We should have 30 of these Austops factories throughout Australia turning the great bulk of our wool into top making value adding in Australia thereby increasing the wealth of this nation and providing much needed jobs in the community. We export our minerals into a world where we have no protection whatsoever. We do very well because we are the best miners in the world. Free trade is not going to assist these industries greatly. Some people from AMIC and some of those whom I call the lead-brained people in the mining industry have said that the access to imports is not going to be of great benefit to them because they can get most of the stuff they use now tariff-free anyway. So there is no great benefit there. They do not face the problem of high labour costs. It is true that Australian labour is expensive in the mining industry but it is also highly productive. The problems this industry faces include access to land. What is going to cripple the mining industry-the industry that is so vital to Australia because of its export earning capacity-is access to land and the increasing sovereign risk that comes with it. There is no guarantee that free trade in the world is going to be a bonanza for us. There is a lot of evidence to. suggest that quite the of living contrary will happen. .(Let us look for a moment at Third World countries. If we w-re to suddenly subject all Third World countries to best practice in agriculture, it would have catastrophic effects. If their agriculture is measured in terms of the number of people required to grow a given quantity of food, it is generally not particularly efficient but it does employ an enormous number of people. If competitive pressures are put in there, those countries will be forced to modernise their agriculture, to go into broadacre agriculture and to lower their' costs of production. The consequence of that will be massive unemployment in those countries: while wages are low in the rural sector in Third World countries, it at least gives people employment and access to food. Then there would be a massive transfer of people from rural areas of the Third World to the already overcrowded cities. The consequence of that would be a push for mass movement of people, mass immigration, which would be impossible to resist. Is this the future that governments and oppositions see for Australia? It is certainly not the future that I want for my children in this nation. Furthermore, we should ask: is it what we want for Third World countries? I am sure that, if they thought about it, it would not be something they would want for themselves. We really have to rethink this issue. Basically, by executive decree, we in the Australian Labor Party have gone down the free trade route. The Liberal Party has no mind; it is simply an amorphous mass. It has this ideological predilection for free trade. It has never bothered to think about the consequences. When people in the opposition prattle on about micro-economic reform, inevitably they mean lower wages. Microeconomic reform is a code word in this nation for lowering wages, it is not the way to go for Australia. I believe there is more to be gained from a study of history than there is from a study of economics. In history, you can see the end product of where the economic actions have taken us in the past. We live in a world in which there has been a revolution in the vocabulary. Words do not mean what they used to mean anymore. When we talk about rational economists nowadays, what we really mean is neoclassical economists. There is nothing particularly rational about that. Let us look at the United States, arguably the most powerful economy in the world-or it was until 1983, when the United States decided to declare class war on its own people. We have seen a reduction in real average wages in the United States. It does not mean everyone is getting less; some people are getting a lot more. But the United States is busily building itself an underclass of its own citizens. That is certainly not the future I want for Australia. I want a much more egalitarian society in this nation. The United States is saying that its salvation lies in free world trade. It wants access to Japanese markets. The reality is that, if Japan were to wipe away all forms of protecI tion tomorrow, it would probably lead to $10 billion a year extra trade for the United States. The reality is that the United Statdoes not need $10 billion a year-it nee-s $300 billion a year-to redress the damage that it has done to its economy. It is absolutely a nonsense concept. The historical evidence demonstrates this, yet we still go mindlessly down this road. We in the Labor Party are driven by the executive, and the people in the Liberal Party follow like the mindless sheep that they are. I believe this free trade business has to be thrashed out in much more detail. We have to have this argument in the Australian parliament before we go too far down this road. I have absolutely no problems with trade, but there is a great need for self-sufficiency in countries. We are told by the rational economists that countries should specialise-a policy which the French reject totally. I believe the management of the French economy has a lot of merit. I do not believe that we s}lOuld be a totally specialist country, because it will leave us extremely dependent. As I have mentioned in the parliament before, in August last year we lost in Australia our last capacity to cast truck wheels. I would have thought truck wheels would have been absolutely vital to transport, on which the whole economy and the defence of this country balance. That company closed down because it could not compete against truck wheels imported from Malaysia. Within a very short period of that Australian company closing down, the price of Malaysian truck wheels went up in Australia to a level higher than had prevailed before the closure of the Australian company. It is clear and rational that this is what will happen if we are silly enough to allow it to happen, yet we go on saying that this is good for us. Obviously, it is not. It is simply a revolution in the meaning of words. 'Yes' means 'no', 'black' means 'white', and 'rational' means 'irrational' . I do not believe it is all gloom. I believe Australia can have an enormous future, but we must tackle it on a simple, common sense basis. The best welfare system in the world is a job. It should be a job that is interesting, offers advanc.ement to a person and offers good remuneration. But, at the end of the day, ajob is very important. We are being told-it is no doubt true and it is in a sense a great tribute to this government-that we have increased the export of elaborately transliving formed manufactured goods by a compound rate of about 10 per cent a year since we have been in government. That is a very commendrelatively able effort indeed. The problem is that the importation of that same category of goods has risen by a slightly higher amount from much bigger base. So the gap is getting bigger, not smaller. That means that there fewer jobs. One of the things that Australia has been good at traditionally is precision engineering and work in the metal trades, yet we see metal workshops closing up all over South Australia and to spme extent in Victoria. economy of South Australia is manufacturing industry based and, without that industry, there is no future for South Australia. It simply a cruel lie and a hoax to keep telling the people of that state that their future lies tourism or free trade. It clearly does not. It is well worth looking at the United States because it became the world's powerhouse. No country could compete with it in export manufactures. That was at a time when United States had a very high import duty. It was internally competitive, but it was largely protected against imports. It was from this potential base that it was able to develop its industries and export to the world. How things have changed and how unnecessary it is for that be the case. The reality in Australia is that are not going to reduce the current account deficit unless we address the issue of import replacement manufacturing. This is where jobs are and this is where the big savings the current account are. Are we doing this? The answer, quite clearly, is no, we are not. There is a simple rule in economics that goes something like this: if we join together two countries of equal size and make them common market union, there will be no effect on wages because they are of equal size equal standard to start off. If, however, we join together two countries of equal size which have very dissimilar standards of living, over 15 years those standards of living will equalise. In the case of the United States and Canada, which are roughly equal, joining with Mexico, which has a lower population, we would see a decrease in the standard of in the United States. I believe the United States will find this decrease intolerable, but it will not be great because of the small population in Mexico. If we look at Australia's situation, however, and we are expected to enter into a free trade a zone with other countries' teeming millions, that formula will apply and the consequences are could be horrendous. People say this will be masked and overcome by increasing world trade and increasing average prosperity. My view is that average prosperity can never rise enough to overcome the consequences of the IS-year rule. I think simple first year mathThe ematics would illustrate that. What does Australia need to do? Obviously, we must exploit those industries we are good is at, where we have no peer in the world. We are the world's best miners. We are the most in efficient miners in the world. We must take the shackles off the mining industry otherwise what will happen is that we will export our technology to Third World countries and other countries, they will then become as the good as we are and have much lower wages and we will force ourselves out of the market. We must also look at maximising the of these industries. The reality is that we cannot value add the mining industry. Our customers in Asia want to value add because to they realise that is where the jobs are. They we are not stupid. It is obvious that jobs are in value adding. What we have to do with the mining industry is to value add the front end. the We have to start manufacturing the mining in equipment in Australia. In Australia we have some of the largest mining operations in the world, we have state-of-the-art miners, the highest standard, world best practice, miners. Why do we not have an industry? Because a there is another vital element: government support. It does not mean government investand ment, it just means government rapport. Austops at Parkes is today up and running 24 hours a day and its order books are overflowing with overseas orders. It is going places because its principal, Jonathan Todhunter, had an assurance from the then minister, Mr Crean, that he wanted to see value adding and he would support value adding. The minister's assurance was the driving force behind the establishment of Austops. Mr Todhunter has told me that absolutely explicitly on several occasions. We do not have that government support with the mining industry. The government should be saying to industry, 'Hey, we want you to get in there. We want a mining industry and it is not happening.' That is why we do not have that industry in Australia. Honourable members should bear one simple fact in mind. A large Haulpak, trucks used in the mines to carry large tonnages of ore, is anything over 200 tonnes. Australia uses 70 per cent of the world's Haulpaks yet we do not make one in Australia. I believe that is a national scandal. Many industries we have in Australia could be, with a bit of incentive and a bit of help, world best performers and great export earners and could form the basis of big industries in this country. The other element of business we need in Australia is those things which are essential to Australia's stability. We need to develop and protect those industries, if it is necessary. I am not saying that the government picks winners, although I believe governments can pick winners, and overseas governments consistently pick winners. You do not have to do it; you only have to pick directions in which industries should go. You pick the general area, and the winners will then pick themselves in that formula. Free trade, as it is being preached to us, is a very dangerous, flawed and failed philosophy. It is something that needs to be discussed far more widely in Australia. I am afraid it is going to need an educated press gallery, which seems to be something long past in this nation.

Speaker: Mr CLEARY
Title: Unknown
text: The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is dead right. We do need the press gallery to take up the issue of this ridiculous free trade position that has been trotted out in this federal parliaand ment. Following the Wills by-election in April 1992-an election which focused on the nexus between tariff reductions and the losof jobs in the manufacturing sector, and which brought to public scrutiny the fantasy of the level playing field-the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was reborn as a protectionist, lampooning the coalition for its so-called zero tariff policy. We all surely remember the Prime Minister pointing the finger at the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), catapulting the derisive 'Captain Zero' into the political lexicon. The fact that the Prime Minister was an unashamed, unreconstructed free traderonly marginally or five per cent different from the member for Wentworth-was lost in the banter. Unfortunately, what continues to be overlooked in the debate is that tariffs are not in themselves the issue but merely a symbol of the problem. In essence, a commitment to tariffs, or non-tariff barriers for that matter, is predicated on the belief that economic sovereignty is essential to any meaningful definition of nationhood-hardly a reactionary or inward-looking view. Members of the coalition used to fly their overseas-made Australian flags on the benches and are always eager to rise to their feet and proclaim their commitment to Australia. On the Labor side, the jingoism focuses on a flag without a Union Jack and a republic with an Australian head of state. All in all, everyone in the House is pretty much committed to Australia. Mention international treaties and you discover just how Australian the coalition is. The irony is that, whilst the coalition condemns the effect of international treaties on Australian law, it refuses-the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and a couple of his mates aside-to adopt the same logic on the question of Australia's economic sovereignty. The dressed up palaver that spills out of the Prime Minister's mouth about an independent Australia is no substitute for a real commitment to an economically and culturally independent Australia. For the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to ape the Murdoch newspeak that superhighways CD-ROM are culturally neutral, innately democratic and liberatory, just about makes me cry. It matters not to the Prime Minister or the Minister for Communications and the Arts who controls, produces and disseminates that which they define as culture. The abrogation of cultural independence exemplified in the government's commitment to Hollywood on the Harbour must surely leave progressive forces in the Labor Party fearful about the future. You only needed to catch a glimpse of the cricket last night to discover how our sports culture has been affected by overseas imagery. The Australian cricket team last night looked, to all intents and purposes, like a baseball team. Shane Warne was a pitcher last night. Packer is well aware that Australian children are seeing more basketball and baseball advertising on the television and are growing up with what Mervyn Smythe describes as 'a diet of American heroes, situations, images and values'. Smythe asks rhetorically, 'Will Australia's sporting and cultural heritage be ultimately wiped out by the unstoppable force of modern American marketing?' If last night is any indication, I would say regrettably the answer is 'yes'. It is no coincidence that the Prime Minister adores French culture. The French, as we all know, are fiercely protective of their culture. Their contempt for the kitsch culture of Hollywood and their preparedness to restrict Hollywood's attempt to dump mass-produced rubbish in their market are some of their more commendable practices. Why, we must ask, does this parliament speak the language of national sovereignty yet accept policies which produce economic and political dependence? Dr Joe Camilleri, in an article 'Music of the Sphere' in the Arena magazine of OctoberNovember 1994, describes the trend this way: Nevertheless the process of global institutionalisation is a striking barometer of the state's ingly restricted freedom of action in the management of the national economy. The growth of international institutions points to a significant, if little advertised, delegation of state authority. Conservatives will read 'international institutions' to mean United Nations covenants and treaties. They do not regard the World Trade Organisation, APEC, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as international institutions to worry about. Members of the coalition might care to explain just why they adore policies which reduce our economic and cultural sovereignty but become panic stricken and froth at the mouth when an international treaty is used to stop homosexuals being victimised in Tasmania. It was interesting to read in the Financial Review of Monday,S December that Australia has deferred aid talks with Papua New Guinea until the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have announced their financial aid conditions. Although the World BankIMF package focuses on some pleasant sounding environmental conditions, vis-a-vis logging, that Australia should defer to what is becoming a discredited int-rnational organisation reflects the loss of sovereignty unbridled globalism creates. John Langmore and John Quiggin in their book Work/or All argue quite rightly that the World Bank must move beyond the contractionary, inequitable, simplistic free marketeering policies of the 19808. It is a bit old hat really. It is almost amusing to see both sides of the House claiming a superior commitment to national sovereignty yet simultaneously promulgating policies which, by their very nature, erode the principles' of nationhood they claim to believe in. Camilleri's scenario that 'a largely deregulated financial system effectively removes major levers of economic policy such as exchange and interest rates from national control and opens the way for unproductive investment and large and unpredictable financial flows' would be music to the ears of the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). When the financial markets prevailed and the 10year bond rate 'went gangbusters', to use the Prime Mini-rer's language, he attacked the increasmessenger boys-those mobile phone-toting, BMW-driving yuppies who gather on the floor of the Australian Stock Exchange and scour terminals looking for a quick buck. What he did not want to acknowledge was that his policies were the reason these charlatans had become so powerful and the nation state so powerless. As we all know, the unpredictable financial flows that Camilleri refers to were the source of the kinds of speculative ventures which devastated Australia in the 1980s. Instead investment being directed to forms of producnorthern tion which were socially useful and enhanced employment, it was-to quote Rhys from his essay 'Capitalist development in the newly industrialised countries'-'dissipated grandiose projects or channelled into real estate or financial speculation'. Ask Christowill pher Skase about that. Rhys Jenkins argues for an interventionist approach to economic life and for the state to have an ability to discipline private capital. The free marketeers construct a labyrinth lies about the means by which economic efficiencies are realised. Jeffrey Henderson seminar. argues in his essay in Leslie Sklair's book Capitalism and development: In stark contrast to the ideologically loaded empirically distorted accounts of East Asian industrialisation that have emerged from the pens and word processors of neo-classical economists . . . it is now clear that though these economies have benefited from vigorously functioning kets, state orchestration of their development projects has been a sine qua non of their success. Henderson goes on to say of the east Asian NICs: They have at various moments acquired foreign technology under license for dissemination favoured companies, encouraged joint-venture arrangements with foreign partners, protected the domestic market from foreign competition, delivto ered subsidised credit through nationalised heavily regulated banking systems (Korea and Taiwan) for approved projects and invested own R&D facilities to help boost the technological capabilities of the private-sector manufacturers. The approach of the Asian tigers to economic matters is a far cry from the silly, ill-conshort ceived approach endorsed in this parliament. The Prime Minister, in his APEC statement to the parliament yesterday, cheerfully minded us that our tariffs are among the lowest in the region and that Australian business'; industry has shown it is more than capable competing in a low tariff environment. It is absolutely absurd to talk of Australia competto ing in a low tariff environment when the very Party. countries against which we compete are proponents of high tariffs. Some APEC and economies, the Prime Minister tells us, have tariffs ranging from 100 to 300 per cent. Is the Prime Minister actually aware of of unemployment that exists in parts of the suburbs of Melbourne, where the textile industry has been ravaged by the Jenkins excesses of free trade? The Prime Minister has come to sound like in a financial shark or con man. He tells us that, under APEC free trade, Australia's real output rise by 3.8 per cent and real national income by 1.2 per cent and that exports will increase by 27 per cent and imports by 20 per cent. This runs totally counter to the thoughtful intellectual assessment of APEC provided of by American academic Chalmers Johnson, who was in Australia recently to deliver a Johnson's approach is far more cautionary. He sees the United States of America and and Japan as the big players. No-one in this House would be surprised to hear that the highly indeficit USA wants a share of the highly in-surplus Japanese market. Nor should marwe be surprised to hear that Japan and China are unlikely to countenance trade policies which jeopardise their position. As Kenneth Davidson argues in the Age on 16 November 1994, 'Even in sport-let alone industry, culture or politics-how often has the winner to changed the rules of the game to give the loser a chance?' Davidson further says, 'Instead of looking for rules, Australia has got look at how it can manage our industrial or development so that it's consistent with in their Australian and Asian needs.' For once the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) is right. Yes, the Prime Minister's speech is short on realism and on detail. Unfortunately, the Leader of the Opposition has no solutions of his own. All he does is reel out the standard right wing recliches: 'lack of macro-economic reform', which should read 'taxes are too high for 'labour market inflexibility', which of should read 'real wages are too high'. The problem is that his party is just as committed simplistic forms of free trade as the Labor The bipartisan commitment of the Labor Liberal parties to radical tariff reduction means that we have no bargaining chips when it comes to the question of market access. As the the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) so blithely reminds us, we have already undertaken tariff reduction. Like the Prime Minister, the member for Werriwa is big on rhetoric, generalisation and wishful thinking. If I had a dollar for every time he used the term 'Australia is perfectly placed', I would be able to buy a house as big as the Prime Minister's. At what point does 'perfectly placed' translate into economic and trade outcomes? For the member for Werriwa to claim that Australia was inward looking, as if the Asian tigers were not, and that our problems were essentially psychological is a complete falsifimake cation of history. Locking out cheap labour, for example, whether it be cheap Asian or white scab labour, should not be scoffed at by representatives of Labor. What was the . capitalist class doing last century when it was trying to import cheap labour? Was it doing this altruistically to help the working class? suggest that the member for Werriwa run this piece of revisionist history past the ACTU, including the Ferguson brothers and Bill Kelty. Is the member for Werriwa suggesting that a free movement of labour of the kind Brian Toohey suggests in the Financial Review on 1 December might be the next step in the logic of market liberalisation? Why not? If, as the member for Werriwa tells us, mobile capital is the great liberator, then why not mobile labour? The member for Werriwa has surely read Monday's Financial Review and is therefore aware that 70 per cent of Indonesian workers are paid wages that barely meet their basic needs. They would be a good source of labour in Australia. A policy of mobile labour would, I am sure, be more than acceptable to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). How the member for Werriwa can describe Australia's tariff regime as being anti-Asian, when the Asian tigers themselves nurtured industry behind tariff and non-tariff barriers, is quite confounding. Even the Prime Minister acknowledges that Asian economies have been masterful at establishing trade barriers. Kenneth Davidson puts it rather nicely when he says, 'Only a few idealogues really believe that the majority of the Dynamic Asian economies have any real commitment to free trade as the path to future economic development.' As I have said on another occasion, the member for Werriwa could easily find a place on the coalition benches. It must surely tell the Australian public something about the state of thinking in the Labor Party. Fancy someone standing up in the House and claiming to be able to, with mathematical precision, calculate Australia's national income 25 years from today. We cannot even get it right over a 12-month period, so how can we possibly statements with certainty over a 25-year period? The Leader of the National Party just tells us that we should not be complacent. What does that mean for the average punter out there trying to find a job? Dr Mahathir gave us a bit of an insight into the dynamic Asian economies approach when he said: I Malaysia would only commit to undertaking further liberalisation on a unilateral basis, at a pace and capacity commensurate with our own level of development. He sounds like a smart sort of bloke. Kenneth Davidson takes up the issue again in the Age on 16 November: The DAEs have a commitment to export-led development but their key industries are opened up to international competition only after they have achieved a size and efficiency that allows them to compete successfully on international markets. Tim Colebatch continues in the same vein: Like Japan and Taiwan, it [South Korea] showed that wodd class industries can grow from scratch behind protectionist walls. The evidence is there. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) like many on his side of the House, blames the tax regime and the labour market for our economic problems. What they do not explain is where government will find the money to fund the kinds of outlays essential to a civilised society. As the member for O'Connor knows, and as the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) are proud to an'nounce, Australia's government outlays are amongst the lowest of OECD countries. Instead of harping about the oncosts experienced by business, we need to put industry policy, as the member for Kalgoorlie points out, seriously on the agenda, and it needs to be creative. The sad reality is that the majority of members in the House have swallowed the free market, deregulation, level playing field lie hook, line and sinker. In November's Arena magazine, Steven Bell provides some figures which give another view of the so called export revival that members of this House crow about. Bell reminds us that, although the automotive industry generated exports of $1.5 billion in 1993, automotive imports have risen from $4 billion in 1988 to $7.5 billion in 1993, and that the trade deficit in the automotive sector is running at over $6 billion per annum and rising. Some useful facts, many taken from Jenny Stewart's book The Lie of the Level Playing Field are contained in Steven Bell's article. These include the fact that the overall share of the domestic market taken by manufactured imports has risen from 17 per cent in the late 1960s to 31 per cent in the 1990s; across 39 manufacturing industry sector categories, imports since the late 1960s have risen substantially in all but three of those categories; correspondingly, only eight categories increased export propensity by more than 10 per cent and only four of these categories were in higher value added areas. It is easy to play with figures; in fact, it is an art form in this House. It is always convenient to talk about a manufacturer here or a manufacturer there in someone's electorate who is doing great things. To focus on a small sample or a small number of success stories does not, as the previous figures show, tell the true story. Bell, like many others who are totally frustrated by our obsession with market liberalisation, argues for a serious industry policy-one which contains a supportive nexus between the state and market players, the kind that we have seen in Asia and France, the kind that proponents of market liberalisation fail to acknowledge when they contrast the economic development of Australia with that of the Asian economies. William Mitchell, in an article in the same ma.gazine, produced a set of propositions concerning the distribution of wealth that has accompanied our pursuit of free market economies over the past decade. Mitchell says: While Paul Keating would have us believe that the HawkeKeating years have made returns to the true believers, it is difficult to find any unambiguous evidence of sustained gains. The facts as presented by Mitchell are, firstly, 'Wages, salaries and supplements as a share of GDP at a factor cost level fell from 62 per cent in 1982-83 to 55 per cent in 1988-89.' In the bad old Liberal 1960s, the wages share averaged 56 per cent of GDP. Secondly, 'The Accord has been extremely effective in reducing real wages and real labour unit costs and increasing profits.' It could have easily been designed by the coalition. Thirdly, 'Between 1983 and 1993, executive salaries far outstripped non-managerial salaries.' But you will not find people in here attacking managerial salaries. They will be attacking the TWU when it tries to get a fair dinkum rise. Fourthly, 'Public outlays due to tax concessions at the top end fell from 30 per cent of GDP in 1983 to 25 per cent in 1990 and in 1993 were around 28 per cent.' The government prides itself on its cuts to outlays. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello)-today he is the deputy leader-has been calling for more cuts to outlays. If he wants the Prime Minister to give a commitment to no taxes, he should tell us what government expenditure he is going to cut. Fifthly, 'Real wages cuts have not prompted investment in productive capital but rather in speculative ventures.' In the 1960s the investment to GDP ratio was over 26 per cent. In the 1990s it is around 21 per cent. Sixthly, 'Australian investors significantly increased their stake in the rest of the world.' We might ask: what is wrong with Australia buying a bit of the world? Nothing if investment was at levels which provided full employment in Australia and if this investment managed to reduce foreign debt. The problem is that it did not. We must ask: are we simply exporting jobs? Seventhly, 'Finally, as everyone knows, but explains differently, foreign indebtedness has increased significantly.' Like most noneconomic fundamentalists, Mitchell blames the lack of private investment and not the skills of the work force or excessive wage growth as our major economic problem. In an article in the Financial Review on 22 November, Peter Roberts said: If we are to avoid continuing current account deficits, what we need is a new wave of policy to identify and nurture specific new industriesensuring a flow of venture and development capital to growing businesses.

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Title: Unknown
text: I have a great deal of respect for the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) and I appreciate his contribution to the economic debate in this House. One of the problems this House faces when we debate the economic side of Australian life is that it is difficult to get an objective assessment. Many jokes have been told about economists on the floor of this House. I just asked the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) if he could provide me with one very quickly, but the honourable member for Wills ended before we could get one out of the box. There is aD. old saying that if you put 10 economists in Ii. room you will get 10 different points of view on the economic problem. What we have heard from the honourable member for Wills illustrates the point I am making. In this House when we come to look at the economy and make an objective assessment of it, our views are often coloured by our political positions and perspectives. No economy in the world has been able to achieve the perfect scenario. Looking at the macro-economic settings, certain things typify the perfect economy. We would all like an economy that generates high rates of growth and has low unemployment rates. We would like an economy with low interest rates, low inflation, high levels of company profitability, high levels of industrial productivity, low debt levels, a current account that is in balance and low industrial disputation. If we put some of the more esoteric overlays on that, we could draw a picture of the perfect economy, or one that is in perfect balance. I suggest to the House and to the honourable member for Wills that no economy on the face of the earth meets all those criteria. But the Australian economy, with what it has achieved over the last decade in restructuring and positioning itself to take advantage of the opportunities that are now becoming apparent in world trade terms, displays many of the favourable characteristics I have just mentioned. The Australian economy is in a high growth phase. It is experiencing low inflation. It has low historical levels of interest rates. Its enterprises have a degree of profitability above the historical levels. We are seeing the emergence of very high productivity levels and we are experiencing low levels of industrial disputation. When you put all these factors together, the Australian economy over the past three decades has seen an improvement in its competitive position of about 30 per cent. That is not a mean achievement. It is certainly one that we on this side of the House are proud of. Every economy has a downside. If we were to take an objective look at the Australian economy, the downside is the extent of the current account deficit and the continuing high levels of unemployment. But when we look at the medium-term overlays of the current economic position, we have some cause for a degree of jubilation about what is going to happen in the economy over the next 18 months to two years. Productivity levels will be maintained. Our micro-economic reform program is continuing. Our access to the international marketplace has broadened with the conclusion of the GATT, and the APEC developments at Bogor in October certainly give us grounds for great optimism. On the ground in our manufacturing sector our export drive is continuing with great results. When the government brought down its last budget, many commentators, and those opposite us here in the parliament, pooh-poohed or criticised the government's targets. But Australia has exceeded the growth targets it set at the last budget. Mr Charles-Too right, and we were proved correct.

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Title: Unknown
text: The bald facts are that the opposition said that we would not achieve the growth targets and we have. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) was one of the people who got up here in the parliament and berated the government about the levels of private investment in this country. The opposition said that the investment targets would never be achieved, but the latest national account figures that are emerging now about private capital investment show that Australia is positioning itself well, with substantial levels of investment in plant and equipment. At the last election, the government made a commitment that we would engineer the economic parameters that would see job growth in the economy over the life of the government of some half a million jobs. I am pleased to say to the parliament today that the opposition was wrong; we were right. The government is on target to achieve the aim it set for itself at the 1993 election. Over the last 12 months the unemployment rate has fallen by two per cent, from 11.1 to 9.1 per cent-a spectacular fall. If the participation rates that existed when the government came to power still existed today, the unemployment rate would be somewhere around five per cent. It is important to make some comparisons between the performance of the Australian economy and that of our industrialised neighbours. Against some of the economic factors I mentioned before, Australia stacks up well. Members opposite are always a source of wonderment to me. They have a fetish about the New Zealand economy. It was the last great tory experiment they point to. The opposition members have got up in this parliament from time to time lauding the achievements of the New Zealand economy. Perhaps they ought to live there if they think it is so good. Mr Knott-They don't talk about the living standards of ordinary workers.

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Title: Unknown
text: No, they do not talk about living standards of, workers in New Zealand. The honourable member for Gilmore has made an important point. The long suffering working people of New Zealand have had to put up with economic policies that have devastated the standard of living of people of low socio-economic standing in that country. The average growth rate of the Australian economy over the life of this party in power has been 3.1 per cent. During the Fraser years, that is, the last time the Liberal National party coalition occupied the Treasury bench, the growth rate was some 2':4 per cent. Our average growth rate to the June quarter for Australia was 4.3 per cent. If we look at the OECD, the other industrialised nations with which we compare ourselves, we see that . their average rate of growth over the same period was 1.7 per cent. The OECD has made projections over the course of 1994. Of the 15 member countries, Australia is projected to grow at the highest level. Since Labor came to power in 1983 the Australian economy has expanded to provide some 1.5 million jobs. The average level of job creation over the period when Labor has been in office has been 150,000 jobs compared to the Fraser government's record of a dismal 37,000 jobs over a comparable period. If we look at a simple measure of economic performance such as inflation, we see that in the 12 months to June Australia's annual inflation rate was 1.7 per cent ,and the OECD average was 2.3 per cent. Since Labor has been in power-over the 1980s and into the 1Q90s-we have had an average inflation rate of five per cent, which contrasts with the coalition inflation rate of some 10.7 per cent. The rate of industrial disputation under Labor is three times less than when the coalition occupied the treasury bench. That paints a fairly favourable picture of the Australian economy. There are things that we, as a government, need to monitor closely over the next 12 to 18 months, such as wage outcomes, the way in which the deficit reduction strategy, put in place in 1993, is achieving the objectives set and the current account position. One of the great successes of the government has been the way we have been able to produce wage outcomes that are consistent with low levels of inflation and high rates of growth in the Australian economy. The government has made it clear that wage rises must be linked to productivity gains at the enterprise level. The gains on the inflation front must be protected at all costs as well as our international competitive position. Our goal of keeping inflation between two to three per cent in coming years is achievable. Even the economic commentators agree with the government that it is a realistic target that can be achieved. We are seeing rising levels of real incomes in this country and that means rising standards of living for Australians. There are positives on the horizon as to our current account position. The world economies are set to grow in a simultaneous fashion, which will lead to greater demand for our manufactures and our commodities. That should see an improvement in commodity prices and an increase in returns. As sure as night turns to day, the drought will break and as farmers resume their historical levels of production that will give an enormous stimulus to domestic activity and our external account and we will see an improvement in the export of services. I read today that the number of international visitors coming to Australia is set to double and our exports of services are projected to grow from $16 billion to $30 billion by the tum of the century-a fairly substantial increase which should ease pressures on the current account. Recent debate has focused on the fiscal position of the government, which has been able to achieve very good fiscal outcomes for this nation. Only one government in the past 30 years has been able to achieve the surplus and the budget deficit that we all desire: Labor in power. I tum now to the opposition's economic policy. I am very interested in the area of industrial relations. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is making a sprint for the leadership of the Liberal Party. We know how interested he is in industrial relations. The Liberal Party wants a totally deregulated labour market. That will lead to strong wages growth and allow those who have a powerful position in the industrial sector to use it to extract wage rises from the economy. If the Liberal Party were ever elected, there would be massive increases in industrial disputation, which would damage our international reputation. We will see a return to the penal sanctions that are typical <;>f tory governments and that will replace the , culture of cooperation which we have assiduously built up in the Australian economy. It is little wonder that the opposition cannot develop a consistent economic policy, because it cannot even determine a leader. We on this side of the House are very astute observers of leadership changes and are all students of politics. I am very intrigued at the underlying principles that govern the selection of Liberal leaders. It is fairly obvious that one of the underlying principles is not talent, so we have to look elsewhere. I have come up with a theory of my own. To become a Liberal leader in the 1980s and 1990s the initial of your first name has to start with either A or J-Andrew, Alex, or John, John-or you must have recyclable characteristics. They are the two characteristics for Liberal leaders today. I went through the potential leaders in the Liberal Party on the conservative side to save the opposition the task of selecting their next leader. There is a field of nine potential candidates: the honourable members for Warringah (Mr Abbott), Wakefield (Mr Andrew), Bruce (Mr Beale), MCPherson (Mr Bradford), Mitchell (Mr Cadman), Ryan (Mr Moore), Pearce (Mrs Moylan), Curtin (Mr Rocher) and Fairfax (Mr Somlyay). If you apply that criterion of A or J, anyone of those nine could be leader. If you move that criterion to the back half of the alphabet to P, then the honourable members for Higgins (Mr Costello) and Flinders (Mr Reith) come into contention. There is a deadly double, if I ever saw one. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), in recent times has come under increasing pressure over the leadership. I read the polls the other day. He has really joined the roaring 20s club, that elite band of Liberal leaders who have managed single handedly to drive their Newspoll approval rating below 30 per cent. The approval rating of the honourable member for Bennelong is 23 per cent, the former member for Kooyong, Andrew Peacock, 22 per cent and the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), 22 per cent. In the last poll, the approval rating of the honourable member for Mayo was 20 per cent. The only thing the honourable member for Bennelong. and the honourable member for Mayo have in common is the fact that they have both polled in the Newspoll at around 20 per cent. The honourable member for Mayo is the limbo king of the Newspoll. When we move the popularity stakes bar down he still manages to get under it. For us old time limbo dancers, it is really a question of: how low can he go? The honourable member for Bennelong is the man in contention at the moment. He is the friend of the tax bludgers in the 1970s and he is making a sprint for the Liberal leadership. He does not want to wield the knife; he wants to be drafted. He wants to go from being the little John of the 1970s to the big John of the 1990s. I am reminded of that old 1960s song Big Bad John: Every day at the mine you can see him arrive He stood 5 fOot 6 and weighed 145 Kind of narrow at the shoulders and narrow at the hips And everybody knew you didn't give no lip-to Big Bad John. Let us hear what the public has to say about the member for Bennelong. I was interested in the recent comments made by Mr Richie from MCDonald's about the Liberal Party and the member for Bennelong. He said: What their major policy lines are is very unclear. In fact I know that there is a thought amongst Liberals that, you know, the less they say about policy the better and at the last minute they will whack John Howard in there and get elected at the next election. I think they're dreaming if they're serious in that thought that they have considered that I have heard expressed. Here is a prominent business person saying that, if you want to go back down the time tunnel and if you want to bring back the honourable member for Bennelong, then you really have no future at all. It is really a statement about the state of the opposition. If they want to put the honourable member for Bennelong in, all I can do is take that line from Dirty Harry Callahan and say that, as far as the government is concerned, go ahead, make our day. The smoking gun on the back bench, the former leader-(Time expired)

text: In relation to these appropriation bills now before the House, I intend to deal with several disturbing current national security issues about which the Australian people and parliament have a right to know. I will cover a range of issues relating to the managementor rather mismanagement-of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, ASIO. In no way am I concerned to criticise the many fine Australians who have worked for ASIO in various capacities and who have, with too little reward and recognition and at some degree of personal risk, served and continue to serve the interests of Australia. However, I am critical of ASIO senior management and the Director-General of ASIO, Mr David Sadleir, who is the wrong man in the wrong organisation at the wrong time. I tum firstly to the attack on the Iranian embassy in Canberra on 6 April 1992. This unprecedented attack on a foreign embassy in Canberra was a first-order intelligence failure by ASIO. According to the official report on the attack on the Iranian embassy, ASIO failed to provide a threat assessment concerning the Iranian embassy, despite the fact that nearly 20 premeditated attacks on Iranian embassies in 11 other capital cities were reported in news services prior to the attack on the Iranian embassy in Canberra. ASIO's responsibility for securing the embassy was discussed in its annual report to the parliament of 1990-91, which referred to its role in warning 'various agencies of protection and enforcement so that potentially threatening incidents can be forestalled'. The same report also claimed that 'politically motivated violence dominated ASIO's operational and analytical work due to growing tension in more than one ethnic community over events in home countries'. In the event, the Australian government reportedly paid between $10 million and $12 million in compensation and increased embassy protection to the Iranian authorities. The ASIO budget should have borne that cost. There are many unanswered questions concerning the attack on the Iranian embassy. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has refused a formal request for an inquiry on the grounds that it is not his responsibility. It is the responsibility of the government, however, to reveal why there was, in the words of the Auditor-General's report No. 44 of 1993-94 into the electronic capture of passenger card data by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, 'an unprecedented computer breakdown' of DIEA's entry control system at a crucial time-six days after the attack on the Iranian embassy-when an entry control officer attempted to obtain a list of passengers to detain for questioning. Moreover, why did a senior audit officer suspect sabotage of DIEA's computer system by a foreign power? The former Director-General of ASIO, Wrigley, was publicly critical of ASIO's failure to warn of the attack on the Iranian embassy. Even the present Director-General, David Sadleir, appointed to the position director-general shortly after the Iranian embassy fiasco, lamely admitted, 'We' - that is ASIO-'have a bit of egg on our face." certainly did. Members will be aware of the recent fire which burnt out the fourth floor of the partment of Foreign Affairs and Trade buildAustralia. ing which housed ASIS central office. should be noted that ASIO is responsible protective and physical security of the Departintelligence ment of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which it lists in its 1993-94 report as one of its external clients. Yet a whispering campaign developed the theme that the fire was deliberminister ately lit as ASIS had a vested interest having its records destroyed. This claim clearly intended to damage the reputation of ASIS. I tum to another vital question: the internal security of ASIO. For ASIO, 1994 has been the year of the spy. The revelations concernBy ing ASIO over the last two years, and in in particular, point to one irresistible concludeign sion: that the director-general should resign. In previous speeches in this House, in Februathat ry and June this year, I pointed out that practical, joke. ASIO's efforts against the KGB and its successor-the Russian foreign intelligence service, the SVRR-had been compromised. Since that time, our security situation has deteriorated even further. ASIO has had to reconstruct its computer and telephone systems as they were believed to have been compromised by Soviet agents. Since that time, ASIO has reportedly replaced the system at an estimated cost of $7 million, although the precise cost is unknown. I now wish to examine ASIO's counterintelligence record. It will not take long. ASIO's counterintelligence record-that is, the protection of ASIO against penetration by hostile or foreign intelligence services-can be summed up in one word: failure. Despite the directorgeneral's description of himself in the press in August 1993 as the nation's 'top spy catcher', ASIO has not uncovered a single Alan KGB or SVRR agent by its own efforts. Every piece of information concerning the penetration of ASIO by the KGB or its successor, the SVRR, has been supplied by of foreign intelligence services. In February 1994, the government reluctantly and under pressure publicly revealed that It the US Central Intelligence Agency had informed ASIO in late 1992 of the role of several Soviet intelligence officers in AustralDeia. They were subsequently expelled from The government disclosure was It made in February 1994 only after I had for informed the House that several Russian officers had been expelled from Australia. Until that time, Senator Evans had major been conducting his own unique form of communication with the Russian foreign and the head of the Russian foreign in intelligence service, the SVRR, by secret was letters-secret, that is, from scrutiny. In mid-1992, Senator Evans proposed to the Russian foreign minister, Andrei Kozyrev, that both Australia and Russia would agree not to post undeclared intelligence officers. magic, apparently, espionage would cease. 1994 Not surprisingly, Mr Kozyrev did not even to reply to Senator Evans's letter. He probably viewed Senator Evans's proposal spying should cease as a subtle, even In late June 1993, Senator Evans again wrote to Moscow. This letter was to Yevgenni Primakov, the head of the Russian foreign intelligence service. Evans informed Primakov that the expulsions of the Russian intelligence officers would take place in secret to this minimise any damage to diplomatic relations between Australia and Russia. Primakov a of wily and former long-time KGB agent, cally replied to Senator Evans that the expelled officers were 'rogue elements' whose activities were not authorised by the Russian ASIO: government. Senator Evans's credulous 路 participation in such correspondence c'an, at best, be described as comic. I now wish to refer to the Australian Federal Police investigation into KGB-SVRR penetration of ASIO conducted in 1992 and 1993, called Operation Liver. Regrettably, a press campaign has begun to describe Operation Liver as a costly failure. However, this view is certainly not shared by Mr Gerard Walsh, the Deputy Director-General of ASIO. In a speech at a social but secret gathering of ASIO staff late last week, Mr Walsh claimed that Operation Liver was, in fact, highly successful. I will, of course, not disclose the entire contents of Mr Walsh's speech 'or where it was made. However, I can inform the House that Mr Walsh was so concerned at the morale of ASIO, at the extent of penetration of ASIO, that he requested staff to express the same spirit as that exhibited at the function to the task of assisting ASIO in detecting Soviet agents and not to allow personal loyalties to cloud their judgment. Mr Walsh did not state-although he is no doubt aware-that ASIO's records were so inadequate that, in the course of Operation Liver, ASIO could not identify over 20 Soviet agents and assets, detected by the Federal Police, operating outside the Russian embassy, who had contacts with ASIO officers. Once again, these agents and assets had been detected by the Australian Federal Police and not by ASIO. The Federal Police took over the telephone interception of suspected ASIO officers, as ASIO lacked the equipment and resources. Over 40 telephone intercepts were conducted-an unprecedented number, which indicates the seriousness of the investigation. Additionally, four ASIO staff left ASIO without apparent loss of entitlements. Why? Because it could not be proved whether they were wittingly or unwittingly involved in ASIO's most serious scandal to date. This is an extraordinary state of affairs. A key statutory responsibility of ASIO is to ascertain the security status of its own staff. The person responsible for ASIO is the Director-General, Mr David Sadlier. Mr Sadlier should resign. In calling for the resignation of Mr Sadlier as Director-General of ASIO, I am not reflecting on his loyalty to Australia but on his competence. Mr Sadlier is a competent diplomat; Mr Sadlier is an incompetent Director-General of ASIO. He does not have the temperament or training to be head of ASIO. He was appointed Director General of ASIO to improve its relations with intelligence services in our region. Mr Sadlier does not know any Asian language; he is not an intelligence officer. Under Mr Sadlier, ASIO has veered from disaster to disaster. The government is well aware that ASIO morale is at an all-time low. For ASIQ the game is up. The government should therefore give serious consideration to amalgamating most of the functions of ASIO with the Australian Federal Police-after, of course, the路 most vigorous vetting. It is my understanding that many ASIO staff would welcome amalgamation with the Federal Police. They realise that ASIO is no longer a viable organisation. They realise that ASIO is not held in high regard by the government or overseas intelligence organisations. They also realise that ASIO is beyond micro-level management reform, reorganisation or even the appointment of yet another new Director-General. Increasingly, even the government is conceding that, given the Iranian embassy fiasco and the cost of protracted investigations and inquiries into ASIO, ASIO is no longer cost effective. The government's continuing inquiries into ASIO are evidence of this belief. From 1987-88 to 1993-94, ASIO vetted over 109,000 Australians; only one adverse and nine qualified assessments were issued. These figures would be laughable, if the situation concerning the integrity and efficiency of ASIO were not so serious. They underline the point that even ASIO's vetting function has become obsolete. The matters I have raised today are too important to be whitewashed by the government. There are currently three security inquiries taking place: the inquiry of Mr Justice Samuels into ASIS; ASIO's own internal inquiry into Russian penetration; and the inquiry of Mr Michael Cook into national security and the penetration of ASIO. There is no valid reason why the major findings of these inquiries cannot be disclosed to this House and the Australian people; I call on the government to do so. Mr HAVILAND. (Macarthur) (11.07 a.m.)-I welcome this opportunity to speak on the appropriation bills for 1994-95. Today I would particularly like to address my remarks to the government's funding of migrant resource centres within the immigration and ethnic affairs portfolio. This Labor government spent $5.8 million in the 1993-94 budget period to support more than 25 migrant resource centres throughout Australia. In fact, the Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre has been a happy partiCipant in this program, receiving more than $330,000 in the last two federal budgets. This is one of the things that makes us different from our conservative opponents: we recognise the fundamental importance of multicultural tolerance and cooperation in this m-nt, country-and we are prepared to do something about it. This government is prepared to put its money into the support of organisations whose work is absolutely invaluable in encouraging real access and equity in our society. This is not the cosmetic pretence at multicultural acceptance that the opposition offers. Our government has made a commitment to empowerment and equality, and it is serious about that commitment. It is prepared to commit both money and other resources to ensure that all people in our society have the opportunity to fully participate in all aspects of Australian society and to recognise their potential. This is one of the reasons why I am always very proud to attend citizenship ceremonies in my electorate. Both previously when I was a councillor on the Campbelltown Council and since I have been a federal member, I have attended as many of these citizenship ceremonies as possible because I am always very proud to see new citizens taking the oath of allegiance and pledging their loyalty to Australia and its people, whilst at the same time being able to have a right to their own cultural heritage and beliefs while respecting those of others. Multiculturalism is a very important aspect of Australian society and one that this government supports.
