text: Wide Bay) (11.22 a.m.)After the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), it is perhaps appropriate that we should deal with Appropriation Bill (No.3), Appropriation Bill (No.4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2), which are the subject of discussion before the House. I suppose the comments of the honourable member did draw attention to some appropriations that are made from time to time by the Commonwealth to community organisations. In some instances, the standards of management of those organisations do not justify the Commonwealth resources that are provided to them. Without wanting to refer specifically to the organisation he mentioned, about which I have no personal knowledge, I can say that there are sadly many instances throughout the community where factional groups and arguments prevent organisations from carrying out the purpose for which they received the Commonwealth grant. This raises a matter of concern about the way in which organisations in the community are sometimes used to promote government objectives and to spend taxpayers' money. We need always to be sure that those funds are spent wisely and well. I have seen in my own electorate and in other places examples where feuding and disagreement have made it very difficult for the intended objectives of the organisation to be achieved. I want to refer to some of the matters dealt with in these appropriation bills. I refer initially to the appropriation provided in these bills for the Australia Remembers commemoration next year. I would like to commend the government on the initiatives it is taking to help make next year's 50th anniversary of the end of World War II a significant event in Australian history. World War II did contribute much to the richness of Australia's history. It taught us a lot about the horrors of war, but it also demonstrated to the world much of the heroic nature of the Australian serviceman and our capacity as a nation to contribute to important international causes. Australia Remembers is a very important occasion for Australians and deserves appropriate recognition. Our objective over the year should be to acknowledge the great privilege that we as Australians have to live in peace and to recognise the contribution of Australian service men and women who died during the war and in subsequent years. We should also thank those remaining service personnel for their efforts. We also need to acknowledge the role played by those other Australians who kept the country operating during the war years. It is particularly appropriate that days such as VE day and VP day be recognised in this country because of the role played by Australians inthose significant events and the contribution those events made to securing a generation of peace for Australians and guaranteeing that our continent would, be spared the ravages of war. I would also like to commend the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) on the even-handed way in which he is approaching these celebrations. Unlike so many events organised by the Labor government in the past, which have tended to develop a political focus, it seems the minister has endeavoured to evenly spread around Australia the resources that are being provided so that every electorate can enjoy and participate in Australia Remembers commemorations. In my own electorate, we are doing quite a lot of work towards organising activities. We are looking forward to our share of the funds. The minister has indicated that approximately $20,000 will be available to each federal electorate to assist with Australia Remembers commemorations. The $20,000 on a per electorate basis in some sense sounds fair, although it does tend to concentrate the amount of money available in the capital cities where there are a lot of federal electorates and where there will therefore be very large budgets to spend on appropriate commemorations. I have to spread that $20,000 amongst 50 separate towns in my electorate. It is obviously not going to go all the way around. I would very much like to see larger allocations being given to rural, regional and provincial areas. I have probably 20 different RSL branches within my electorate, so sadly the $20,000 will not go around. Nonetheless, we put together a selection committee that will allocate funds to ensure that some of the Australia Remembers celebrations can occur in each and every community within the electorate. I would also like to encourage the government to be generous in making Defence Force personnel available to assist in the Australia Remembers commemoration. I know that comes from a different budget from that of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Sadly, the defence budget has been depleted so much over recent years that there is a limited capacity to do what I think should be done in 1995 to help commemorate Australia Remembers. Many organisa(ions would like to have defence personnel present to help add prestige and a military dimension to their proposed . celebrations. In Kingaroy, which is in my electorate, there is a proposal to have an air pageant to commemorate VB day and to particularly mark the role played by Kingaroy in air force training and the activities of the air force during World War II. They have asked to have some air force presence, including the Roulettes, 'to help make that a very important celebration. I hope the defence department will be able to make some air force personnel available to add to that day's celebrations which will recognise the role that Kingaroy played in training so many air force pilots, including some very significant names in Australian history. I hope they will be able to be present on that day to add to the commemoration. In addition, I refer to the announcement that medals are to be available to some people who served in ancillary services; such as the Women's Land Army. Some of those medals will be available for presentation during 1995. It would be good to have a military parade to recognise those people who will be honoured and who will finally have their service during and around World War II and in subsequent conflicts recognised through the presentation of a medal. If we are going to have parades to adequately recognise those people, it will require some Defence Force commitment. I hope the government will take that on board and make people available wherever possible to assist in making those commemorations as significant as possible. While handing out bouquets to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I have to draw his attention to a matter which pleased me much less. The government recently announced new initiatives to assist Vietnam veterans in Australia. I was very disturbed to learn from counsellors who participated in the Vietnam veterans country outreach program that the government is about to axe the program. This seems to be an extraordinary action on the part of the government on the eve of the Australia Remembers commemoration in light of the commitments made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I am sure in all sincerity, to do more to assist Vietnam veterans. It seems the government has decided to axe this counselling service. There are seven counsellors in my electorate who are employed for 32 hours per month to assist Vietnam veterans with their various needs. That is not an enormous commitment from the government, but it seems that the government wants this service to become voluntary. This is a very stressful occupation. It is stressful not only for the counsellors themselves, some of whom are from families of Vietnam veterans, but also for the immediate families of the counsellors because the veterans call in at all hours and the counsellors are called out路 at all hours. It places a burden on their families. For the minister to expect these counsellors to perform this service for nothing is clearly unreasonable. Most of the counsellors who are currently involved in the program have indicated to me that they are not prepared to do that work without some kind of financial assistance. Apparently, all the minister is prepared to offer them is a bit of mileage and some reimbursement for their outgoing telephone calls. The government wants these counsellors to perform this highly skilled and very stressful task without any reimbursement. Frankly, that is unreasonable. I call on the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to reconsider his attitude to this matter and continue the funding for the Vietnam veterans country outreach program. . My final point in the area of veterans affairs relates to the Australia Remembers commemoration. There has been a lot of pressure within my electorate-and I am sure in other places as well-for a public holiday to commemorate VP Day. That is a day of great significance for Australia; It was a day of great celebration 50 years ago; it was a public holiday 50 years ago. It would certainly add greatly to the public's acknowledgment of that day if there were a holiday for VP Day again in 1995. I know that employers and businesses are reluctant to have more holidays. We certainly have plenty of them in this country, and more than most. Why not in this very special year transfer, say, the Labour Day holiday-a holiday which is celebrated on various days around Australia-to VP Day to mark a very significant event? If the labour movement is reluctant to give away its holiday for one year, perhaps the Queen's Birthday holiday could for one year be on this day to recognise this important event. If that day is not suitable, there are many show days or pupil free days in schools that could surely be transferred to VP Day to help local communities better celebrate this important event. I know that choosing holidays is a matter for state governments. I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs could exercise some influence with his state colleagues, and with local government since they are also capable of recommending holidays, particularly for show days. Surely for one year we could use one of the existing holidays to help guarantee that VP Day is properly remembered. Whilst dealing with defence matters, I note also that, despite the fact that we have a hard pressed defence budget and a white' paper currently before the parliament which slashes defence expenditure to the lowest level since World War II, the Department of Defence is still going to have to find around $10 million to redecorate the Prime Minister's jet. It seems an extraordinary priority, when we cannot find money to adequately staff the defence battalions and we cannot find money for new equipment, that $10 million is going to have to be found to upgrade the Prime Minister's 707 jet because, apparently, it does not meet his imperial standards. As a result of these modifications, it will more difficult to use that 707 jet in its primary defence role-namely, transporting troops in times of conflict. It will be difficult to modify the jet for that purpose. Apparently, there is $8 million in these appropriations to redecorate the Prime Minister's jet. In these tough economic times, one wonders about that priority. We are being told by the government at the present time that the recession is over, good times have come and we now need to take measures to help dampen the enthusiasm in the economy. Once again, Labor's response to the improved economy is to suggest that we need to dampen it down with more taxes. I find it remarkable that in times of improved economic activity Labor chooses to adopt a more tax solution. When we were in the recession the government's solution was also more taxes. In that case it wanted more taxes so it could stimulate the economy. Now it wants more taxes so that it can suppress the economy. It does not matter what the problem is, Labor's solution is always higher taxes. The government totally lacks imagination in dealing with the economy because the only solution it can ever find is higher taxes. The government needs to remember that there is already a stack of higher taxes that will be inflicted upon Australians next year as a result of last year's budget, including higher sales taxes, higher petrol taxes and higher tobacco taxes. All of these taxes hurt middle and ordinary Australians more than they hurt those on higher incomes. These taxes will be inflicted on Australians. To hear the government now talk about a raft of new taxes is a totally inappropriate response to the current economic improvement. Indeed, higher fuel taxes, higher indirect taxes, will hurt the people who are not benefiting from any kind of improvement in the economy. People in rural and regional parts of Australia know nothing about any kind of improved economy. They are still suffering from drought and recession. To increase fuel taxes would hurt the very people who are still in the depths of recesbe sion. It is deplorable that any member opposite would be advocating higher fuel taxes in these circumstances. Australia taxes fuel more inappropriately than any country in the world. If there is any country that ought not tax fuel, it is Australia, which is so vast and spread over an enormous continent. By taxing fuel we penalise our productive industries. They are the ones that need fuel to transport their produce to port. They are the ones who need to locate their business and their activity away from the capital cities. They are the ones who bear the disproportionate share of the fuel tax burden. In this country we already impose more than $10 billion worth of taxation as a result of distance. Distance should never be taxed. We should be encouraging people to live, locate and do business away from the capital cities. The only way that can be done is to reduce fuel taxes rather than impose higher taxes. I call on the government to immediately rule out the possibility of higher fuel taxes. In fact, it should rule out the possibility of any new taxes in this situation. The government will reap an automatic windfall in tax revenue because the economy is picking up. It does not need higher levels of taxes. Let us look at the last federal budget, which the Treasurer (Mr Willlis) proudly announced as a no new taxes budget. Of course, that was not true; there were some new taxes in the budget. But even without increasing existing taxes specifically, the government still budgeted on an income tax increase of 8.4 per cent; 5.7 per cent more from the Medicare levy; seven per cent increase in company tax; 27 per cent increase in super funds taxes; and a fringe benefits tax increase of an incredible 131 per cent-all of that without any increases in tax. Sales taxes went up by 7.7 per cent, fuel excise went up by 12.6 per cent and there was a 6.3 per cent increase in other excises. The government reaped that tax windfall without increasing taxes. Frankly, all of those figures will be understated. Because of the improvement in the economy, the government's haul from taxes will be even greater. There is no excuse whatsoever for higher taxes. There are plenty of excuses for the government to cut its own expenditure and to cut its own waste. Sadly, in this appropriation bill we are allocating more money for more government waste. There are so many examples of where the government has failed to cut its own budget and where it has failed to draw in its own expenditure. It prefers instead to .raise levels of taxes to penalise ordinary Australians, the people who are trying to get their businesses up and running again. Not only do they slave and struggle under increasing government regulation and higher charges and taxes, but they are also never rewarded for their effort. Their reward for higher profitability, for putting in those extra hours, is more taxes. As our economy improves, the government should recognise that that improvement is directly the result of the individual efforts of Australian small business and industry. It has nothing to do with any brainstorm on behalf of the Prime Minister or any intervention on the government's part. It is entirely due to the efforts of individual Australians. Those efforts should be rewarded, encouraged and acknowledged-not penalised through higher taxes. The government needs to take that into account in proposing its mini-budget early next year and in its future budgetary planning. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: Unknown
text: As we go through the decade of the 1990s and approach the centenary of Federation, it is appropriate to reflect upon the events of 100 years ago and on how it was that we came to have our constitution, which remains relatively unchanged-very similar to the original document. We should remember that the Australian constitution had its legal entity created with the enactment of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act 1900, enacted by the British parliament. The simple fact is that the act had nine clauses with the ninth clause commencing by saying: 9. The Constitution of the Commonwealth shall be as follows:Our constitution was created as a clause of an act of the British parliament. It is very difficult to imagine in the 1990s how we would go about putting in place a constitution to create the federation of Australia. It is a bit hard to imagine being in the situation of the British parliament, being required to achieve the outcome. That is not to say that we do not need to look at contemporary Australia and to think about those things that are made more difficult because of the constitution being created in the 1890s. One of the increasing frustrations that I have as a member of the Australian parliament is that often the things we would like to achieve are frustrated, or made more complicated, because of the need to wend our way through the sensitivities of Commonwealthstate relations. I see the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms MCHugh) at the table. We have a debate at the moment about national competition policy. It is a quite complex and complicated policy on its own without having the difficulties of looking at it in the context of agreements between the Commonwealth and the states. I raise that as one example because I believe there has not been sufficient debate about competition policy arising out of the Hilmer report and that there is perhaps a lack of understanding of its ramifications. When people investigate those ramifications, it becomes even more difficult because it is hard to identify what means will be used to achieve outcomes. . It Will be of interest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker,and the minister at the table to know that last we-k 'the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts revisited Lake Mungo, one of the first four areas placed on the World Heritage List. I do not know whether both of you were on the previous visit. I was not a member of the committee' Ilt the time but have often heard about the very interesting meeting that you had with the leaseholders. Unfortunately I have to report that, nearly 10 years down the track, not much has changed. It is a classic example of the Australian parliament and the Australian government having the responsibility under their treaty obligations of ensuring that those places under World Heritage listing are properly managed while the day-today management, of those places resides in the hands of a state government. After a decade, we really have not put in place a management regime shared between the Commonwealth and, in this instance, the New South Wales government which would achieve clear outcomes-which wouJd protect those values that have caused that,area to be placed on the register and, at the same time, give a degree of direction and certainty to those people who live in the area and who try to make an economic existence out of their stewardship of that land. I am sure that we could all come up with examples which show the difficulties Australia has in the 1990s in a whole raft of areas of public administration because of the nature of our federation. The debate really is and should be, as we run into the centenary of Federation: what does the Australian community expect of the Commonwealth government and what is the type of Australia we really would like to see? We reflect upon the creation of the federation and there is from time to time, quite rightly, some very harsh criticism of the way in which the constitution was put in place. Arising from some comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in June of this year, there appeared an article in the Telegraph Mirror under the heading 'Constitution a grubby compromise'. The author of the article was Richard White, a historian at the Sydney University. The first part of the article was critical of the Prime Minister for the way in which he has assessed what happened in that important time in our history. I believe that was a little unfair. I will go to the latter parts of his article where he says: The Constitution that was produced was a compromise, in many parts a rather grubby compromise or a wilfully vague one. It is a bit harsh, 100 years on, to be critical of the way in which the constitution was put together. Richard White further states: They comprised "founding fathers" if you like but were, more accurately, a group of middle class politicians, mostly lawyers, Alexander Downer's grandfather among them. ,For the purposes of this debate, I do not want to belabour that point. Certainly, in the way in which the community was debating federation at the time, for various reasons, there were people who were concerned. At the time of Federation, the labour movement was divided about the question and was very cautious. The newspaper the Worker expressed some concerns about the young federation becoming a plutocracy under the influence of 'bribed leaders and corrupt statesmen'. The Melbourne based Tocsin was similarly bitterly opposed to the powers given to the Governor General and felt that Australian liberty had been imperilled by federation. Some in the labour movement would say that was very prescient of what occurred during the 1970s. The Worker concluded: Essentially the spirit of a federal movement was democratic and the nation . . . must if it is true to itself . . . even become more democratic. The Tocsin finally accepted the Commonwealth Act, stating: ... for better or worse. We shall try to find in it secret channs for bettering the condition of Victoria and Australia. We shall strive to make of it a charter of liberty for the distant future. Despite those reservations, from the outset it has been the labour movement that has seen the need for constitutional change to reflect the changing needs of the nation. In this context, I should also raise a statement by the founder of the Liberal Party, who recognised that a constitution needs to grow and adapt to change. In 1967, Robert Gordon Menzies suggested: A written constitution is an express scheme of government designed to give a basic structure in a changing world, not designed to inhibit growth in a growing world, nor to make the contemporary world subject to the political, social or economic ideas of a bygone age. The Australian constitution has not changed very much. It is still a document suited to the social and economic conditions of the 1890s, when it was conceived. If we look at some of the pamphlets circulated during the run-up to federation, we see one that compared the proposed constitution with the then fledgling Swiss and American constitutions. This pamphlet made the bold claim that it would be easier, under the proposed Australian constitution, to achieve constitutional change than it would be under the American constitution. I think the history of the past century-in the case of the American constitution, a greatly longer periodproves that the American constitution has proved in its ability to be amended a much more pliable document that can be changed to represent contemporary ideas and views. The problems that have been created by this inflexibility and lack of change within the Australian constitution are well known. Earlier I gave some examples, but perhaps the situation was best summarised by a graphic illustration given by then Prime Minister Bob Hawke in 1990. Mr Hawke gave the example of a cargo container being sent by rail between Sydney and Perth that may have been subject to three non-integrated railway systems, four changes in locomotives, five different safe working systems, six different sizes of loading gauge, 10 different engineering standards of basic standard gauge rail track and 12 or more hours at sidings or junctions for crew changes. Some of those problems catalogued in that example are slowly but surely being addressed. We are looking at the national rail grid. Some of the things that Mr Hawke talks about which concern different standards of safety and associated issues are laboriously being addressed. Arising out of an Industry Commission report on accident compensation, at the level of COAG we will look at those issues, at our separate jurisdictions, because those matters reside within the powers that were reserved by the colonies back in the 1990s, and at the way in which we can put in place a national policy. As Richard White said, the founding fathers, whom I quoted earlier, were often regarded with undue reverence. Back in the 1970s, Don Dunstan pointed out that they were really little more than state politicians protecting vested interests. What we need to do is to ask how, in the 1990s, we can wind back the clock and how we can wind back those attitudes that were motivated by these vested interests so that we can achieve change that focuses on looking at Australia as one nation, rather than looking at Australia as a continuing collection of the six colonies. We should realise that the founding fathers knew well that they were condemning future generations. Manning Clark pointed out in his history of Australia that as early as the late 1840s the Whig Earl Grey warned the colonists about the dangers of separate parliaments 'legislating on such subjects of common interest as railway gauges'. Clark continues: , " The price for colonial folly was that New South Wales adopted the standard rrulway gauge, Victoria five feet three inches, and Queensland, South Australia and Western' Australia' three feet six inches, At the time of Federation, those .issues were not immediately or magically addressed because of the creation of the federation or the way the constitution was 'framed. It has taken us progressively over the lastcentliry to be 'able to address the problems that the earlier colonial decisions created. I think it is worth repeating a quote of Don Dunstan: We are now left with results of their workthat is, the state politiciansa system of sovereign governments whose boundaries bear no relation to physical, social or economic geography, and which are limited in their attempts to legislate efficiently in such important areas as trade practices or national transport because the framers of the Constitution on the one hand did not believe that governments should be concerned with the economy or business practices, and on the other they foresaw no problems emerging. Mr Dunstan also said: The system as a whole is inefficient and debilitating. And as the years pass the writing of the Constitution becomes enveloped in the mists of time, that well known contagion of Federated States can be seen developing high-minded reverence for the Founding Fathers. Any criticism of their document becomes a kind of political blasphemy. They are even now being seen as far-sighted, despite the fact that when they drew the document up about the only matters they considered crucial to national Government were defence, an end to custom barriers and an efficient post office . . . One of the driving forces that moved politicians in the six colonies to agitate for federation was the influence of the French and the Germans in their efforts to colonise our region. For others, it was the concern that they had of either Asian invasion or Asian takeover through migration. In the 1990s we are having debates about free trade throughout the world and, in particular, yesterday'S debate arising from the. APEC meeting in Bogor about free trade in our region. In that context it is interesting that one of the driving forces for the colonies in getting together to create the Federation was free trade between the colonies. So where does that leave us at the moment? It leaves us in a situation whereby, through COAG as a meeting of heads of governments, we are trying to achiev'e a cooperative approach to the way in which we can tackle the problems that confront Australia. Because of what is sometimes termed 'the new federalism', whereby we have to achieve national policies through the agreement of both the national and state governments and national and state legislatures, a great degree of compromise is needed to achieve outcomes. Without suggesting that consultation in any form is a bad thing, to achieve this cooperation-to do it right-requires lengthy consultation, which delays our ability to put in place change and delays our ability to address problems at a national level. We have slowly come to grips with the fact that, in economic policy terms, only the national government can give the direction. There are still tensions in place, because of the 1942 court decision that gave income tax raising powers to the Commonwealth, about the sharing of resources. There is continuing concern where people are conjuring up this concept of states rights without thinking that we should be talking about people's individual rights and the need for a national direction in those areas of policy.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: Unknown
text: I had not intended to speak about the constitution but, given that the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) has raised this subject and done so in an interesting but, I would argue, wrong way, I will address a few of his points. The constitution is a document that was designed in the 1890s but, as Sir Isaac Isaacs said, it was designed to be the birth certificate of a nation. As our nation has changed, so our constitution has changed. Our constitution is not perfect, but there is nothing wrong with it that becoming a republic is going to fix. The member for Scullin raised various issues of overlap, duplication, waste and so on which he believes stem from the existence of the states. The problem with his line of argument is that it does not actually help the agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for constitutional reform unless the Prime Minister is prepared to accept that becoming a republic should also include abolishing the states. I would think that that is in fact part of the Prime Minister's long-term agenda, but it is certainly not something that he is prepared to admit at the moment. In fact, at the moment the Prime Minister is saying that if the states did not exist it would be necessary to invent them. The member for Scullin has fallen into the trap which so many members opposite fall into-namely, in their desire to bring about certain changes to our constitution, they are rubbishing the entire document. The member for Scullin read articles from some academic who was talking .of our constitution as 'a grubby compromise'. I would have thought that compromise was part of life. Effective life in civil society means knowing when to compromise, because compromise of some sort is simply inevitable. Putting a pejorative adjective in front of the word 'compromise' does not change that fact. He may as well have spoken about 'grubby cooperation', but of course he would not talk that way because we all know that cooperation is part of life and it is essential if we are going to have the kind of society that people are happy to live in. Of course, the constitution was originally an act of the British parliament, but that was the icing on the cake. The essence of our constitution was decided by the Australian people in Australia for Australians by a series of constitutional conventions. For the member for Scullin or anyone else to say that it was rammed down our throat by Queen Victoria in the British parliament is simply a slander on Australia's history. Yes, documents--even documents like the constitution-do need to be changed from time to time. But the changes must address the real needs of the people and not the imaginary needs and the cheap political interests of certain political sections and ideologies in society. The fact is that, if you look at the constitutions which were changed most often in the modem world, you get constitutions like that of the former Soviet Union. That constitution went through five or six incarnations in 70 years. On paper, the constitution of the Soviet Union was the most relevant and up-to-date constitution in the world, but it did not matter at all as far as protecting rights in the Soviet Union was concerned, because there was no cohesive culture-political culture, culture of human rights-behind it. The fact is that, if our constitution needs to change to serve the needs of the Australian people, it must change. But it must not change simply to serve the needs of the Prime Minister. The appropriation bills that are before the House at the moment indicate the sorry reality of Australia's economic condition. By contrast, the Prime Minister's self-adulation, expressed in his statement about the APEC meeting at Bogor, demonstrates the fantasy land that this government is living in. The Prime Minister said that the APEC agreement permanently changed our region and the world. He put the APEC agreement up there on the same pedestal as the Bretton Woods agreement, which laid the foundations for the international economic conditions of the postwar world. It is interesting that the Prime Minister's great political hero is none other than Jack Lang. Jack Lang supporters used to run around Sydney back in the 1930s saying that Lang was greater than Lenin. At least Jack Lang had the decency to let his supporters say that he was greater than Lenin. The Prime Minister lacks that decency. In standing up here and boasting about APEC and Bogor, what he was really saying was: 'Paul Keating is greater than Roosevelt; Paul Keating is greater than Churchill; Paul Keating is greater than John Maynard Keynes. I am greater than these architects of the post world war economic world.' Is it any wonder that well-known and able journalistic commentator, Mr Greg Sheridan, was forced to say in his recent column that the Prime Minister was suffering from Bogor fever? The Prime Minister has caught Bogor fever and is deep in the throws of that dread- . ful disease. The Prime Minister said that APEC was our chance to sit at a big table. The PM is obsessed with big tables, as long as they come from Thailand and as long ,as they are made of teak. I suppose he wants his Thai teak table to go with his Thai knighthood: a Knight Grand Cordon of the Most Exalted Order of the White Elephant. The Prime Minister's statement on APEC shows serious historical amnesia in that he has totally forgotten one of the fundamental planks of the last election campaign. The Prime Minister went round this country saying to the workers of the textile industry, the motor industry and the footwear industry, 'Vote Labor, because Labor will protect your tariffs.' Now he is saying that within a few short years tariffs will be abolished, not because we in Australia want them to be abolished but because APEC, apparently, is telling us that they should be abolished. The Prime Minister has forgotten in just a short space of time the fundamental plank on which he fought the last election. He has exposed himself as the real Captain Zero of Australian politics, the real deceiver of our political system. The second case of historical amnesia is that the Prime Minister has said that he produced APEC. If any Australian politician is to claim credit for APEC, it should be the former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. Bob Hawke is the real ghost at the Prime Minister's APEC banquet. Hawke has been removed by the current Prime Minister from the APEC picture in much the same way that Stalin had Trotsky removed from the photographs of the old Bolsheviks. The third and most serious case of historical amnesia is that the Prime Minister does not know or understand the history of this country. I refer to a government reporiwhich commended a certain course of action because that course of action would provide 'facilities for carrying on trade with路 India and the Malay Peninsula as well as with China'. That report was not written for Paul Keating last year. It was not written for Bob Hawke five years ago. It was not written for Bob Menzies a generation ago. It was written for Governor Stirling of Western Australia back in 1828. The point I am making is that Australia has been interested in Asia, vitally concerned with Asia and deeply involved with Asia for as long as this country has existed. It is important to remember who has and who has not got the right stuff on Asia. It was Bob Menzies and not Paul Keating who first talked about Asia as our 'near north'. It was Percy Spender and not the current Prime Minister who implemented the Colombo Plan, which brought tens of thousands of Asia's future leaders to our shores. It was Bob Menzies and Black Jack MCEwen and not the current Prime Minister who established the trade treaty with Japan which resulted in .the total reorientation of our trade in just a few short years. It was Harold Holt and not the current Prime Minister who declared, back in 1966, that the next century would be 'a century of Asia'. It was Harold Holt and not the current Prime Minister who ended the White AustralIt is policy. At the very time he did so Labor was being led by a man who notoriously said, 'Two wongs don't make a white'. That was the attitude of the Labor Party then. It Malcolm Fraser and not the current Prime Minister who first began large scale Asian immigration to this country. Labor at that time was being led by a man who wanted to keep the boat people out because they were, he said, 'f ... ing yellow baits'. That is the record of the Labor Party as opposed to the record of the coalition on this subject. Let me also point out on this subject of relations with Asia that the first member of this parliament of Asian extraction was Senator Thomas Backhap, back in the early years of this century, who represented one of the forebears of the Liberal Party, the Nationalist Party. But to go into more detail as to which party is the party of Asia in this country, just how long Australians have been talking about the need to integrate with Asia and just what a Johnny-come-lately to this crusade the Prime Minister is, Sir John Latham said in 1934: It is inevitable that the relations between Australia and Asia. . . will become closer and more intimate as the years pass. Therefore, it is important that we should endeavour to develop and improve our relations with our near neighbours. In 1939 Menzies said: I believe that the Pacific is of all zones in the world, the zone in which our risks are primary risks and our responsibilities are primary responsibilities. He went on to say that the government should: . .. do everything that it can to increase our cultural relationship, our personal contact with themthat is to say with Asiansand to improve all of those things which go to make a real and personal understanding. In the 1950s Dick Casey said: Our geographical situation is such that we must inevitably be brought into close touch with the peoples of Asia If we make no effort to understand their problems, we can scarcely expect them to make an effort to understand ours. Differences of race, religion, language and culture could easily lead to regrettable misunderstandings which might adversely affect our relations with them. is a pity that the Prime Minister did not heed Dick Casey's advice. If he really understood Asian culture he would not have made his regrettable comments about the Prime was Minister of Malaysia Dr Mahathir which led to months of trade tensions between Australia !, and one of our important trading partners. In the 1950s the Prime Minister of India Mr Nehru welcomed Australia's coming closer to Asia. So this idea that Asia was only discovered in December 1991, when the current Prime Minister assumed office, is a myth. The Prime Minister only discovered Asia then because until that point Asia had been something that you flew over on the way to the antique fairs of London and Paris. I will conclude this part of my comments with another well-known Australian politician, this time speaking in the 1960s. He said that our destiny lay with Asia: ... we must fulfil it spiritually, unselfishly, with shining enlightenment ... (This) will stand as the most glorious achievement, so far, in our history. That politician was not the current Prime Minister; it was Sir Alexander Downer, the father of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer). Let us examine the reality of our current relationship with Asia. In 1968, 65 per cent of our total exports were already going to the Asia-Pacific region. In 1968 we already had nearly seven-tenths of our economic relationship with the Asia-Pacific region. That was 25 years ago. It has nothing to do with the current Prime Minister and everything to do with the good work of the Menzies government. Our share of East Asian markets over the last few years has declined. Our exports to East Asia have been increasing as a percentage of our GDP but falling as a percentage of East Asia's GDP because its growth rates are higher than ours. Our penetration of East Asian markets has fallen since the early 1980s from four per cent of East Asian GDP to about 3Y2 per cent. Investment from Asia in this country has also fallen over the last few years. Australian investment in countries such as Britain and America has skyrocketed but our investment in Asia has stagnated. Our investment in Britain today is six times our total investment in ASEAN. I am not saying this to approve; I am saying it to indicate the reality of our economic position, which is that our relationship with Asia has gone backwards in the last few years, notwithstanding all the hyperbole of the Prime Minister. APEC is certainly an important step in the right direction. One of the reasons why it is an important step in the right direction is that it is a small step in the improvement of our domestic economic position, which has been damaged by this government. This government has practised hairshirt economics. When times were good back in the 1980s, it put interest rates up to 17 per cent. When times were bad in the early 1990s, it put unemployment up to one million people. Now that times are allegedly good again, interest rates are going up again. In other words, before the economic recovery has crawled off the front pages of the Financial Review-it has not even got into people's pockets yet-interest rates are already going up. The last round of interest rate rises, let alone the next round, will amount to a tax of $100 a month on ordinary home buyers in this country. In the 1980s we had interest rate rises we 'had to have', in 1990 we had the recession we 'had to have', now we are having more interest rate rises that we 'had to have' and soon we will have another recession that we 'had to have'. The Prime Minister has done it before and he will do it again. The tragedy of what this Prime Minister is doing to this country is that it amounts to a complete betrayal of the people that he and the Labor Party are supposed to represent. One of the great ironies of the current situation is that Labor members opposite are only too happy to tum to traditional working class areas when they are looking for a safe seat, but they rush off to the rich parts of town when they are looking for a house. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is rushing off to a safer seat as fast as he can, given his vast bulk. At the same time we have the Prime Minister, who has a perfectly safe seat, rushing off to buy a $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra. The motto of this government is, if I might take the biblical lamentation: 'To those who have, more shall be given. To those who have not, even what little they have shall be taken away.' It is a terrible indictment of a Labor government that that should be the case. This government needs to stop fantasising about overseas countries coming to save us from our domestic predicament. Its leader needs to stop his fantasies about strolling around in his batik shirt with President Clinton. The government needs to get on with the real job of economic management. It needs to tackle the rorts, the rackets and the rip-offs which still exist in our economy. It needs to tackle the union rules, which means that the pit pony cannot be removed from a colliery because it is a member of a union and that means that Australian 767s have to have differently designed cockpits to accommodate extra union members. The Prime Minister needs to stop his Napoleonic fantasies and get on with the job of running this country. He needs to come back home where the problems are and forget about overseas problems 'that he cannot do anything to fix.

Speaker: Mrs CROSIO
Title: Unknown
text: Prospect-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security) (12.22 p.m.)-I rise to speak today on the government's appropriation bills. I will take this opportunity to reflect on some of the federal Labor government's achievements and our Liberal coalition's shortcomings. During my speech, I would like to compare the positive actions of our government with the Clayton's policies and retrograde activities the coalition. It is becoming an illuminating experience. Before I go on to the points I would like to raise in the debate today, I will take the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) to task on his memory lane trips in this place. He talked about how things were established down memory lane, which is recorded in history, of what one particular person was supposed to have said, whether it was in 1939, 1964 or whenever. I say to him as he is leaving the House now that he should hang his head in shame-history records words, but history does not record action. It took the Prime Minister and the Labor government to bring action to reality, to bring those words to fruition, to make sure that APEC came to fruition. When something like that happens, the opposition resorts to personwhich, al, vindictive attacks time and again. Those opposite do not like the achievements that have taken place under the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). They do not like the fact that somebody of his renown can bring many countries of the world to agreement. They do not want to see that. They do not want to stand路 up and be counted and be part of a country which is proud of those achievements. They want to stand up here and put on a scene. If Actors Equity were here grading the member for Warringah, he would probably get about two out of 10. I would not give him much more, because he has referred to what has happened in the past. He should bring himself back to the present and start looking to the future. You would swear to God, from some of the remarks made by the member for Warringah, that you had to be swab tested before you moved out of your electorate and bought property in some other electorate. I found him absolutely obscene. The debate before the House today will give me an opportunity to bring some of our achievements to the notice of the House. Since 1983 we have been driven by a need to look at where we are going throughout Australia. When our government took office it found that many areas of responsibility had been left to it by the Liberal government. I of am pleased that our government has been able to formulate policy on a scale that has assisted everyday Australians. We are coming to the end of 1994. As our Labor government forges ahead, nothing has really changed for the Liberals. They have certainly become a lot more sluggish and, if one can take notice of what has been happening in the papers recently with the leadership debate, much more chaotic. Our Liberal state of disarray has certainly been summed up well by Glen Milne in the Australian on 28 November: . . . former NSW Liberal Premier, Nick Greiner stands as testimony to the capacity of the Liberal Party for self-delusion. That some sections of the Liberal Party are mooting the idea of bringing Mr Greiner to this House is absurd, given his track record, incidentally, Mr Milne outlines so well. He states: In 1991, Greiner went to an election a year early, for no apparent reason, and saw the Liberals' comfortable majority squandered and control of the Parliamerit ceded to the Independents . . . Mr Greiner's involvement and ineptitude in t-e ICAC debacle resulting from offering that LIberal defector Terry Metherell a highly paid Public Service job are certainly etched in the minds of the voters of New South Wales and I dare say, Australia. That lapse路 of political judgment saw Mr Greiner forced from the premiership. M?re recently in the Australian Capital Temtory, we should consider the Liberal opposition's actions in the Legislative Assembly where the leader, Kate Carnell, has just completed a backflip on the cannabis laws. Acknowledging that the Liberal Party has handled the issues badly, that assembly has h-d to amend the legislation which her party VIrtually helped pass. This backdown comes - fter - trong pres.sure from various quarters, IncludIng the polIce and the Australian Medical Association, who all agree that the whole issue has not been thought through. The list of the federal government's positive moves is very impressive. Whether it be in our western suburbs of Sydney; where I proudly represent the electorate of Prospect, In the country areas of New South Wales, in the state of Victoria or on the Gold Coast, our governme.nt has been actively pursuing very progreSSIve programs. As part of our - overnmen-'- commitment in Working NatIon, the MInIster for Employment, Education - nd Training (Mr Crean) and his very effec!Ive te-m have been making significant - nroads Into u.n-mployment and are creating J-b opportunItIes. Hardly surprisingly, in dISCUSSIng Working Nation's objectives and listening to others' views across Australia, the government's ideas have been met with enthusiasm and certainly with confidence. .The federal government is now working WIth many of our large companies to get people talking, to get them thinking and, most Importantly, to get them actively working together to alleviate unemployment. The - overnment is creating strong links with Industry, the unions and the community at large. Results have been very reassuring. Recent DEET figures show that the number of skilled vacancies in major metropolitan newspapers has risen. This result sees increases in 12 out of the 16 major occupational groups, which means that the level of skilled vacancies has risen by more than 56 per cent over the past year. There is also good news about decreases in Australia's foreign debt. The latest figures show that net foreign debt fell for the fourth quarter in a row. Commentators have welcomed this result. By contrast, but perhaps not surprisingly, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), has attributed the improvements to state governments and to the private sector. I personally believe that his refusal to - ive due credit to the federal govern--nt Illustrates how petty he and his coalItIon partners are about the issue. He either de.arly lacks understanding and knowledge or Just refuses to understand what it is we are about. The list of worthwhile government initiatives is a very long and proud one. Through DEET's NETTFORCE projects, for instance, the federal government is campaigning to generate 17,000 new jobs in the Gold Coast region over the next six months. In central weste- New South Wales, by actively encouragIng employers to take on additional employees, particularly the long-term unemployed, our government's endeavours should lead to an extra 5,500 new jobs in that area. Overall, since the launch of Working Nation in May of this year, there has been a substantial impact on long-term unemployment. We have now seen a reduction of almost 90 000 in the number of long-term unempl-yed people since March 1993. Contrast that with the coalition's performance and specifically look at the Liberals in Victoria. The Victorian Premier has become notorious for his ability to reduce the quality of life for so many people. We all know full well, unfortunately, the difficulties that the Premier has created there for ordinary, everyday, hard working Australians. That really does not warrant any further comment. In my own state of New South Wales where the Fahey. Liberal government reigns: from 1991 untIl the federal government established a task force to identify transport links between Kingsford Smith airport, known as Mascot, and the proposed new airport, the New South Wales government has not participated in any planning to link those two airports. Earlier this year, the federal Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) announced intentions to identify and plan for road and rail links between those two airports. He established the task force to work with the New South Wales government. The New South Wales Liberal coalition government has not been easy to negotiate with, stipulating its involvement would be dependent on a Commonwealth government commitment to provide up-front funding of both road and rail links, including a $120 million funding commitment towards the city to Kingsford Smith airport rail link. Wanting to secure cooperation, our Commonwealth government attempted, as much as possible, to develop a good working relationship with the New South Wales government over this issue. But the New South Wales government would not agree to the State Rail Authority carrying out the engineering study for the rail link unless the Commonwealth gave a commitment to pay for the lot once again. Even after the Commonwealth made $200,000 available for that rail study, New South Wales continued to baulk at having any involvement in that engineering study. Eventually, the New South Wales Liberal coalition government reluctantly agreed to participate. As well, despite receiving millions of dollars from the federal government to improve our national highways, the financial year of 1993-94 saw the New South Wales government divert some $50 million to nonroad purposes. If New South Wales continues to divert a considerable proportion of its discretionary spending to consolidated revenue, how can the federal government treat seriously calls from New South Wales to allocate more m()ney for New South Wales roads. The recent outcry about noise and low flying aircraft has certainly sparked a new controversy and debate about the opening of a third runway at Sydney's Mascot airport. Eyes will soon turn to developing the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek in Sydney's west. Certainly building the airport at Badgerys Creek has its attractions. It should lead, as I am informed-and statistics back it up to the creation of thousands of jobs not only in constructing the airport and transport links but also in the companies that will relocate to our area. It also has scope to increase opportunities in the manufacturing and tourism sectors. The federal Minister for Transport recently announced that three route options have been identified .for the new national highway link between Prestons and Cecil Park in Sydney's west and that an environmental impact study will commence to determine the best route. The Prestons to Cecil Park link is the southernmost of the three sections of the western Sydney orbital. It is proposed that this new road take long-distance heavy vehicles out of Sydney's local and arterial road system and form part of the link from' Kingsford Smith airport to Sydney West airport. Regarding all aspects of the airport, however, on behalf of the constituents I represent, I would urge planners to consider carefully all implications for people residing within the area. We must learn lessons from experience and we must plan to provide adequate infrastructure. We have the chance now to get it right from the outset. The federal government in its Working Nation document committed itself to a longer runway at Badgerys Creek being finished by 1999. But variouspeople now want that $73 million spending to be brought forward to the next calendar year and ,another $47 million allocated to the FAC dedicated to immediate construction of Badg-rys Creek. I have personally written to the. federal Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator John Faulkner, outlining in detail my concerns about all aspects of the proposal and its impact on people in my electorate. I favour a further EIS being conducted under the auspices of the Commonwealth environmental portfolio, taking into account the full potential impact for people who live, work or engage in other day-today activities in proximity to those proposed flight paths of the proposed airport. Any EIS should be capable of withstanding the test of public scrutiny. Anything less would fail to convince the community and may raise doubts about the intention of long-term airport operations. We cannot fast-track construction at Badgerys Creek without an updated full environmental impact statement on the issue. A very detailed EIS was completed in 1985, and I have read it, but many changes have occurred in western Sydney over the nine years since that EIS was completed. The 1985 EIS suggested a runway of 1,200 metres but in 1991-and I am pleased to say following a great deal of pressure from western New South Wales members-the then Minister for Transport changed the length of the runway to something like 1,800-odd metres. Also, following further representation to our federal minister, we have now announced the construction of an international standard 2.9 kilometre runway instead of the 1.8 kilometre general aviation facility that was originally planned for Badgerys Creek. A whole host of environmental issues must be considered such as air quality and pollution, fuel, flooding, water run-off and the effects of a completed international airport on run-off. We need a reassessment of the noise maps, and guarantees that aircraft will remain in the corridors already set down. The new site for the airport is very close to Horsley Park, Bossley Park, Smithfield, Greystanes and Fairfield-all areas and suburbs within the electorate that I represent. I have consistently recommended a very cautious approach to this development because of the potential for adverse impact on the area. Bearing in mind that the proposed airport is to be operational 24 hours a day, the possible situation for many people is very serious. Planners must think about the implications each time a heavily laden aircraft flies low over Sydney's most densely populated western region. They should particularly give consideration to take-off and landing in the early hours of the morning and the impact it would have on residents' lives. I wonder whether the planners and so-called experts realise the amount of noise generated by aircraft landing or taking off at 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. This is what we must give consideration to.. I certainly sympathise with those people who are affected by the opening of the third runway. But I will say most sincerely that many people purchased properties in that region knowing the airport was there. Certainly, many have known it has been there for many years. Conversely, though, some people within my electorate had never contemplated having an airport in the area, even though now many welcome it-and certainly our council does. Years ago some made an initial choice to live in the quiet rural areas of the electorate and others, who have moved in since the 1975 subdivision started, would not have had any inkling that an airport could be constructed in the area and that they could end up under a flight path. I think that choice has now been taken away from a lot of people. As an article on flight paths, which appeared in last Saturday'S Weekend Australian, so very logically puts it: The opening of the third runway and the unsynchronised commissioning of the new air traffic control tower meant residents got a Big Bang taste of 2010 conditions. I have used that quote in my speech today because what I am really saying, on behalf of the people I represent, is that we do not want the big bang effect in the Prospect electorate. What we do want is adequate planning and consideration for people's welfare; what we do want is a continued guarantee from our minister and our government that, when that construction is put in place, it will be done efficiently and, as I have said repeatedly, with infrastructure so that the communication links by rail and road are completed. We want to make sure that what we plan to build 'today will take us well through the 21st century. We want provisions and facilities in the western region of Sydney that are going to be classed as second to none, because we do not want to be second-class. I believe that we have the intent, the ability and, certainly, the means by which our planning policies can be put in place so that the people who are affected will not be placed in the same position in which they have recently been placed in the Mascot-Kingsford Smith area. I believe most sincerely in what our government is about. I believe in what we are about in our white paper and our employment creations. I believe in the sincerity with which we have, at all times, openly dealt with the public of Australia. But I will again insistboth to the minister, as I have in the past, and to all others in this House-that we do the job well. Let us plan it correctly and adequately. Let us at no time in the future-and, if it is not us, the people who follow us, who stand up and represent their constituencies in the same proud way as we who have been elected and are here today do-have to wear the bad decisions of something that we have been part of today. I would not like to see that happen in the future. Most particularly, I put it on record that I would like to see adequate planning put into place so that we can proudly proceed to the future and not be ashamed of what we could leave behind for others to bear the brunt of. On behalf of the constituents whom I represent, I commend the government for all the actions it is now taking. But I will ask it again to make sure that a lot of thought is given before we rush in. We have not in the past rushed into something like this; I do not believe that, because of outside pressures, we should now tum around and try to quick start a project that needs a lot of planning to be successful and, most importantly, to be done correctly. I put this on record in the House in the appropriation debate whilst at the same time commending the government and the ministry on what we have been able to do-it may be happening slowly, but it is happening-with industry and particularly with the people we represent: those long-term unemployed, those who did not have a place in history and who are very important. We as a government, through the white paper and the statements we have put into place, have been able to offer them a future-a future with opportunities and, most importantly, a future where this Labor government will go from strength to strength. I commend the bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: Unknown
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure that you, like other members in this chamber, will be aware of the famous sports people that come from the electorate of Parkes: I guess the most famous would be Phillip Adams from Forbes. No Australian has won more Commonwealth Games medals, whether they be gold, silver or bronze, than Phillip. He has been a great ambassador for Australia in pistol shooting. Even as recently as yesterday, we had two Narromine athletes performing well for this country. Glenn MCGRATH plays cricket for Australia. Who could forget seeing, on our television screens last. night, that famous ins winger cleaning up one of the English batsmen? Further, when I got back to the motel and turned on the TV, there was Melinda Gainsford winning the indoor 200 the metres, beating even as famous a person as Cathy Freeman. But it is not about them that I want to talk today. I wish to talk about cleaning up drugs in sport. The athletes that I have just mentioned have been exemplary in this regard. For some time now, the world has been suspicious that China is guilty of using systematic doping to produce artificial world champions, particularly in swimming-though positives have turned up in drug testing of competitors in canoeing, athletics and other sports. If we look at swimming, we see that, of the world's top 25 rankings for each swimming stroke, in 1991 China had six listings; a year later that had increased fourfold to 24 listings; and a year later, in 1993, that had increased fourfold again to 96 listings. Such a meteoric rise in itself is suspicious, particularly as only one of those listings was a male, with the rest being female. The very top performers won six medals at the world's swimming championships in Perth in 1991; but this year, 1994, in September, in Rome at the Foro Italico pool, they won 24 medals. What is particularly notable is that all the medal winners this year were female; in fact, they won 12 of the 16 gold medals, and not one male Chinese swimmer made a final. That in itself causes a suspicion that they may be taking drugs. Only last month in October at the Asian Games in Hiroshima, the women won all 15 gold medals in swimming. With this meteoric rise, there has been the very physical evidence, I believe, especially to the trained eye, of the use of drugs, particularly anabolic steroids, the testosterone derivatives, and human growth hormone. Looking at the female Chinese swimmers, we see about them a lot of non-feminine characteristics. There are the deep husky voices of the girls. At the world championships when Lu Bin came in and won the 200 metres freestyle, as well as being a relay competitor, her deep baritone voice apparently shocked the audience, including the 60 journalists, there. She said that she was not on drugs and that these accusations against Chinese female swimmers were racist. But, apart from voice, another characteristic is excessive body hair, where it is not shaved, of course-particularly facial hair. Most alarming is the thickening and protrusion of the mandible, the lower jawbone. I guess equally if not more worrying are the characteristics that we do not see, some of which may not tum up for years-damage done to the liver from trying to detoxify the testosterone floating around in, these athletes' bodies; the diabetes problems resulting from it; and, later in life, most tragically of all, the infertiliand ty problems caused by damage done to the reproductive systems of these girls. Throughout all these accusations, the Chinese officials, including government officials, denied that any doping was going on. The athletes themselves have denied that any doping Was going on. The accusers have been called racists. Even Juan Antonio Samaranch, the Chairman of the International Olympic Committee, who supported Beijing against Sydney for the 2000 Olympics, dismissed these allegations and declared China 'very clean'. The pattern that I have outlined amongst Chinese athletes, particularly the swimmers, is all very similar to what the world went through in the 1980s with happenings in East Germany before the Berlin Wall came down. Only in today's December edition of Swimming World, which has just been released in America, there is a very interesting article showing, from the opening up of the Stasi files-the Stasi, of. yourse, being the East German secret police-that every East German world-class swimmer was doped. The evidence is there recorded. The testosterone levels-the male hormone levels-in those German female swimmers were very great indeed. Of course, testosterone injected into females accelerates muscle growth and reduces the recovery times between events. A normal male will have about 40 parts per cubic centimetre of urine. There is some testosterone normally in a female but it is about five parts per cubic centimetre. In a normal individual walking around, the ratio of testosterone to epitestosterone-which is the natural preform of testosterone-is one to one. It can rise, abnormally, in exceptional circumstances to three to one. The International Olympic Committee has set a standard ratio of testosterone to epitestosterone at six to one. So, if people test positive to testosterone, there is no doubt that they take the drug. Kristin Otto, the East German swimmer who won six gold medals at Seoul in 1988, had a ratio of 17 to one. According to the files, there were other East German girls whose levels fluctuated between nine to one 12 to one. So the East (Jerman swimmers were a total pack of cheats, nothing more and nothing less. Over the past two years, and before a recent event which I will come to in a minute, five Chinese swimmers have tested positive. The five includes Yang Aihua, who won the 400 metres at the world championships. Her test at the world championships turned up clear but she was tested randomly two weeks later, before the Asian Games, and she tested positive. According to one newspaper report, the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 December, her test results were held up for several weeks: . . . to allow a suitable time to elapse between Samaranch's commentthat the Chinese were very cleanand the proof that Chinese sport was anything but very clean. These five positives that have turned up over the last two years are equivalent to the total positive results in swimmers of all countries over the last 22 years. Indeed, 45 Chinese athletes overall-and that is outside swimming as well-have tested positive since 1987. At the Asian Games, something else happened. A surprise test was done on the swimmers three days before the games, not after, and 11 Chinese athletes turned up positive, including eight female swimmers. Those who tested positive included Lu Bin, who tried to scale a wall to avoid being tested after an event. She won the 200 metres at the world championships in 1:56.89. Le Jingyi, who holds the world record, which she set at the world championships, for 50 metres of 24.51 and for 100 metres of 54.01, was excluded from the eight swimmers who turned up positive. She is the girl we have all been seeing on our television sets in recent weeks. She has very broad shoulders which taper down to a narrow waist. She looks like she has swung out of a tree with a gorilla and she would be the envy of every male bodybuilder in the world. She tested negative, but surely there is no doubt that she also is positive. I might just add that testosterCihong. one particularly helps the sprinters-and she is a 50-metre and a 100-metre sprinterbecause of the bulk they put on. The benefit gained from using testosterone starts to dissipate when you get up to the distance events, such as the 800 metres. It appears that the Chinese athletes have been able to avoid testing positive when they have been tested after the competition events because of such devices as flushing, whereby they use diuretics to flush out of the body the urine with the high testosterone in it so that the urine sample taken later is a dilute one. Apparently they have also been using masking drugs, which block the kidneys from excreting testosterone. By using these flushing and路 masking techniques, the drugs can be flushed out of the system within 48 hours. So it is obvious that it is vital to use random testing of athletes and what is called 'out of competition' testing of athletes to pick up this use. In the Chinese program, only about 20 per cent of their total testing is out of competition testing whereas in Australia 50 per cent of the tests fall into this category. We need these tests to be done to establish baseline levels for individual athletes. When the Chinese were tested, Lu Bin's level was very high indeed. I guess that the testosterone levels floating around in the bodies of Lu Bin and Le Jingyi would probably be equivalent to the level of the combined teams of the Canberra Raiders and the Brisbane Broncos. I say to the world international swimming community-particularly to the Chinese community-that, if they want their female swimmers to look like males, to act like males and to swim like males, they should ban them from the female events and let them compete in the male events. I believe that this is a human rights issue. Perhaps it should be taken up by the United Nations and perhaps education programs for female swimmers should be put in place. Yang, the 400-metre swimmer who has turned up positive, trains under Zhou Ming at the Guang Zhou Military Club, along with sprinter Le Jingyi, who won four gold medals and set four world records at the world titles, and the dual backstroke world champion, He I would say that there is no doubtthe circumstantial evidence is very heavy indeed-that the coaches know what is going on with these swimmers, even though one of them did not test positive. I would stress that it is not just the athletes who take the drugs but those who administer them who are particularly at fault. The Australian stance on coaches who are found administering drugs to athletes is that they should be banned not just for two or four years but for life. I believe that at present the swimmers are banned for only two years. So they can compete at one Olympic Games, be picked up with a positive test, dry out and compete at another Olympic Games. I believe they should be banned for four years, including one Olympic Games, and that all their medals and previous records should be stripped off them when that happens. I also believe that a country with a large number of athletes who test positive should forfeit its right to compete for a number of years until it can show that particular sport is clean to the satisfaction of International Olympic Committee standards. Mr MCGauran-It's outright cheating.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: Unknown
text: It is outright cheating, as the member for Gippsland says. China complains that there is a high cost in this testing. But, if it is spending millions of dollars on putting its athletes through these sorts of military training programs to try to gain some world kudos, which it is, it can throw a few of those dollars, or Chinese yuan, aside to do the drug testing which goes with it. The Chinese have to be responsible in this regard. As far as the Australian athletes go, I feel very sorry indeed for former athletes such as Michelle Ford, who was denied higher medals because she competed against East German swimmers who were drugged. I feel sorry for our swimmers who have come back from the world championships, such as Elli Overton, Susan ONEILL and Hayley Lewis who would have been higher placed were it not for those Chinese cheats who came in ahead of them. I praise the work of Steven Haynes and Nicki Vance of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, who are doing such great work there, and others who have spoken out, like Paul Quinlan, who is the AIS swimming manager and the Vice-President of the World Swimming Coaches Association. I also praise the outspoken words of coaches such as Forbes Carlile, Don Talbot and Otto Sonnleitner, who is the Australian Swimming Coaches Association chairman, who are calling for stiffer penalties. I say to China to get rid of its cheats and to lift its standards on having disregard for the lives of the individual swimmers. Possibly some of the swimmers who are taking these tablets orally think they are taking vitamin pills and do not realise what in fact they are taking. That was certainly the case in East Germany. If that is happening in China, it is all the more reprehensible. While this is going on, China at this stage is not fit to host international events such as future Olympic Games and future Asian Games. I am very fond of Chinese people. The people of Chinese extraction who have settled in Australia are wonderful, hard working citizens who have set a great example to other Australians. Chinese people can stand up in the world and hold their heads high in their own right. Chinese athletes do not need coaches and government officials directing them to take performance enhancing drugs. The International Olympic Committee should realise that the game is up with China, as it was with East Germany. The IOC should take strict action to clean up drug misuse in sport. It is the IOC's duty to play a strong role to ensure that the world of sport is free of drugs. It should ostracise the countries and the coaches who encourage drug taking. It should take appropriate strong action against athletes who test positive in the future.
