text: Forde-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development) (1.01 p.m.)-It gives me great pleasure to speak today on the appropriation bills. As most of the honourable members in this House will recognise, appropriation bills are about money and the funding of government programs. A major issue connected with appropriation and stateCommonwealth funding arrangements is that dealt with by Hilmer in looking at national competition policy and through that at the concept of a national electricity grid. While people, in principle, support the concept of a national electricity grid, it is a different issue. when the power poles required for that grid are to go through their home and affect their livelihood or, mOre importantlyas the good citizens of Boonah would arguethey are to go through a recognised scenic rim. Over 200 people attended a public meeting in Boonah last week to voice their opposition to the proposed route for the QC east link. They have formed themselves into a group called the Boonah Citizens Opposed to East Link. It befits the government to listen to those community concerns and to evaluate them so that, if the option is chosen to put powerlines through there, the decision is made with all the facts to hand and taking into consideration all the issues that the community has raised. Many of the issues raised at that public meeting had not been brought to the attention of the QC. The area in which the QC intends to place these powerlines covers the Mount French National Park, the Mount Greville National Park, the Main Range National Park, the Mount Barney National Park and the Lamingvery ton National Park. These areas are recognised as having value to the community. These located areas should be preserved and their character should be preserved. The area itself is recognised as being of the scenic rim. It embraces a number shires and it has changed from a dairying community to a tourism community. That is particularly important. It has nine outdoor education establishments for school children and it is the largest area that provides such facilities in south-east Queensland. Over 10,000 students per year visit this area to participate in outdoor education pursuits. Those establishments have chosen this area because of its beauty and because of its access to both the mountains and the waterwho although, sadly, there is not too much water at the moment. This area has been chosen because it provides a unique opportunity our young people not only to develop themcourse, selves and to learn the kind of self-esteem self-confidence which come from outdoor education but also to learn to value the livelihoods, environment which they have access to. That is one issue. The other issue has been the pursuit of tourism as the area has attempted to diversify from fairly intensive dairy farming. over 10,000 adults a year visit this area on wilderness holidays. Mount Barney lodge camping ground cites how it offers the opporpowerlines tunity to share our wilderness heritage. Yarrafarmer malong advertises indoor recreation with privacy, no overcrowding, and horse riding facilities. The national horse trails go through this area. O'Reilly's mountain resort is there. Tamborine Mountain and Willowbank Raceus way are there. There is a whole range of things. This whole area has a historical perspective as well as its tourist attractions. It is believed by those people who are working in that that they will not be able to continue their tourism operations if the skyline is ruined unsightly, hideous powerlines. One of the important attractions of the area is the fact that it is the leading parachuting centre in Queensland. At Boonah there is quality tandem and free-fall training. Gliding is also significant. We have the Kooralbyn Parachute Centre and the ultralight operation in Boonah. All of those operations are placed at risk if the QC east link connection goes through this area. How on earth can part people parachute if they are in danger of of falling onto powerlines? How can people glide if they are in danger of falling onto powerlines? How can people fly ultralights if they are in danger of falling onto powerlines? I also point out that Mount French is classified as 26. For those people in this chamber who do not know what 26 means, it can be equated to degrees of difficulty, and 26 means that this is an international peak. It is where our Olympians go to train for their mountain climbing. It is where those people hope to climb the Himalayas also go to test themselves. Why would they want to climb to the top of Mount French lookout and for see ugly powerlines in front of them? Of they do not want that and nobody who and is reasonable would want it. There are very real concerns about people's people's quality of life and, more importantly, people's incomes in a community which has shown it can diversify. It is, however, still a very large farming community, producing carrots, Queensland pumpkins, Indeed, avocados, fruits and flowers. A matter of real concern is an admission by the QC that it uses chemicals under its to keep the grass at bay. Does a who has to put up with these terrible powerlines through the middle of his farm have any guarantee that the chemicals used by the QC to keep the grass at bay will not find its way onto his carrots or pumpkins? All of have been made very conscious of what is happening with the use of chemicals, particularly in the international meat market. Not only do farmers lose control over their property, but they have no control over what the area Queensland Electricity Commission may be doing with chemicals. That is one very real by concern for quite a large number of the farming community. We can say categorically that the people whose livelihoods are at risk, whose whole of life depends on the recreational and national environmental parks in this area, are 1\ vigorously opposed to the QC east link going through that area. They would argue that this area is designated national park; it is designated heritage. It is part of our history and, as such, should be preserved and should be pristine. Tourism is now very much a part of the livelihood of that community. The power link would be totally and utterly destructive of ecotourism. People parachuting, gliding or fiying ultralights would no longer have clear airspace. The Olympic climbers and our mountain climbers who go to Mount French to test themselves would no longer enjoy the conditions they do now. I bring to this House, with all the weight I can muster, the views of those residents who were at the Boonah council chambers last week. They expressed their very precise and very clear objections to the placement of the QC east link through their area. They object not because they are necessarily opposed to the QC east link-although people did raise issues as to whether this was necessary, and whether in fact the kind of electricity that would be generated in the link-up would be important-but because, if they are to survive as a community, they need that area to remain pristine. They need that area to remain as part of our heritage in order to develop their livelihoods through tourism, through outdoor education and, indeed, through the kind of farming to which they have now adapted. There are a couple of other concerns which have come about, with some of the changes and some of the moves that we have seen, through governments seeking to become more competitive and perhaps more financially secure. Within this area we have also had a second action by the Department of Primary Industries, which took over the water resources management of Moogerah Dam at Lake Moogerah. Unfortunately, the dam is currently only operating at 9 per cent capacity, and we all hope and pray for a break in the drought. As if that situation were not bad enough, we now find that the children's play equipment in the area has been taken away and that the area is being only scruffily maintained. The citizens there are very concerned. They believe that in this, the International Year of the Family, it is wrong that this very popular family area-where people can take their own lunch, have their children play and be very much part of a family situation-can have its playground equipment removed in the middle of the night because of certain financial constraints on government departments, and it is wrong that the kinds of maintenance and facilities needed are no longer available to families. This is particularly important, given that we have school holidays in the next week or two. Given the constraints of the financial impact of the drought upon them, very many local people will not be able to go very far from home, and this is a very popular place for family gatherings to be held. What could be more delightful than children being able to play on playground equipment, with parents bringing their own food and using the barbecues there, and doing so in an area which is relatively pleasant and not just scruffily maintained? I urge this House to give some consideration to the community's concerns when we are discussing the appropriation bills and the finances which we see translated from the federal government to the states. We are, after all, appropriating Australian taxpayers' dollars. It is their money. Our people pay taxes to ensure that government services run; and all of us need to be very conscious that there is no question that the concerns and needs of the community need to be addressed. We are, after all, a government about people, and I urge this parliament and this government to do what they can to ensure that the needs which were expressed last week by the people of Boonah are heeded and taken into account when government decisions are made. While we may think about a national grid and look to savings with the sharing of electricity and so on-all of which, of itself, may be valuable-when we are standing here we perhaps fail to recognise that the communities out there, at the very heart of what we are doing, may not want this. These people certainly do not want the QC east link in their national parks, because it will destroy their livelihood. The very reason for their living in that community will be gone, because those pristine environments...:.. - those national parks which are part of our heritage-will in fact no longer be as they are now; and neither will our farmers be able to continue to give us guaranteed clean food. In the debate on this appropriation bill, I give voice to the needs of that community and bring those needs before the House.

text: I want to use the consideration of the appropriation bills to review the state of the economy and where Australia might go. This is the appropriate occasion in the House for that kind of activity. The current situation of the economy is a delightful one, as has been said a number of times in the last day or two from this side of the House. The rate of economic growth is measured at 6.4 per cent and even if those figures have to be revised downward, as is possible because it seems extraordinarily rapid, it is quite clear that the economy is now growing very strongly, that the level of economic activity is high and that therefore there will a strong rate of economic growth and a strong rate of employment growth, which is what we all want. The principal problem of the Australian economy at present is the level of unemployment. It has fallen significantly from its peak but it is still over 9 per cent, and we want that to come down rapidly and to remain much lower. One of the principal requirements for that is for the level of economic activity to remain strong. The rate of inflation is also extraordinarily low. At less than two per cent, less than half the OECD average, that is less than half also the rate amongst our trading partners, and there is no significant sign of that rate of inflation increasing. It is quite clear too that business investment is growing strongly and that there is also strong growth in many exports. Of course, the drought is retarding growth of primary exports, which is a tragedy for the rural sector. The government has a package in place to try to offset that to a limited extent but the drought is containing the growth of the whole economy and, until the drought breaks, we will not see the uniform spread of economic activity that we want to see. Given those situations and the fact that we still have a significant current account deficit, it is important to try to maximise growth of employment, to minimise the impact of that on the current account deficit and to minimise the impact of it on inflation. The question is how we do that, and it is not an easy policy balance to achieve. We all want to avoid increases in interest rates and taxation but, on the other hand, it is crucial to ensure that this recovery, this strong period of economic growth, is sustainable. That cannot happen if we go into a too rapid boom in a way that leads inevitably to a recession later on. So the question is what balance of policies the government and the Reserve Bank should use to ensure sustainability. Many people, particularly from the financial markets, have been arguing that interest rates should be increased yet again. I think they neglect the fact that, since the September quarter increase in the national accounts, there have already been two increases in interest rates, increases totalling one and %per cent, the most recent of which was towards the end of October. It is quite clear that those increases would not have made any impact at all on the activity in the September quarter, and it is therefore appropriate to wait awhile before any further decision is made on interest rates. Some of the commentary from the financial markets suggests that the government and the Reserve Bank should act as if what is happening at this very moment, the beginning of December, is what was measured for the September quarter. That is an oversimplification. It is highly likely that the growth rate will remain strong now, but it may be somewhat less than it was measured to be in the September quarter, because of the impact of those two interest rate increases. It is quite clear, for example, that housing activity is already tailing off a bit. I know, from anecdotal evidence, of business people who have deferred investments that they were planning, because of the two increases in interest rates that have already occurred, and because they fear that there may be more in the pipeline and they fear the cost that those increases would cause them if they were to invest further now. I think responsible policy would suggest that there should not be any further increases in interest rates for some time, until it is possible to accurately and comprehensively evaluate the impact of the two increases in interest rates that have already occurred, and the consequences of that impact for every part of the economy. It is important to do that, of course, in ways that take account not only of statistics but also of the evidence that comes from the business sector, the housing sector and the consumer sector, in so far as that can be assessed. Of course, since the Christmas period is always a period of very rapid activity-a turbulent period, if you like, in measured terms-it would be wise to leave further decisions until late January or February. It is good to see that the Reserve Bank has today decided not to announce any further increase. I hope that it will take no further action for at least a couple of months. One would hope that it would then find that further increases were not necessary. We want to avoid interest increases in so far as we possibly can, because they increase the cost of investment and they increase the cost to home buyers and buyers of white goods and cars, and we want the level of economic activity to remain as strong as is possible. One of the lessons of the last decade was that interest increases can be very damaging. That is the lesson, not only from Australia but also from other countries. Therefore, we want to be quite cautious about any increases that occur. The fact that increases are happening in the United States does not mean that they are appropriate policy here, not least because real interest rates in Australia are already-still-well above those in the United States, despite the fact that there have been half a dozen increases there. Because our inflation rate is so low, the real level of interest here is still high, by historical standards and by international standards. 路We ought to remember that. As well, we need to remember that when interest rates rise the exchange rate rises. That has happened in the months that have foIl' lowed the increases in interest rates here. Increases in the exchange rate make adjustment of the current account deficit more difficult. For those reasons, as well as for the reason that we want employment growth to be maximised, we should be very cautious about any further increases in interest rates. Of course, we have to find ways of containing demand. It seems entirely appropriate for the government to be seriously thinking about very modest, progressive increases in taxation. It is something new in the Australian environment, since the last decade and a half, for there to be serious consideration of what should be done about taxation. During the last decade we had a whole series of reductions in taxation, which were no doubt widely welcomed. But it is responsible, as the Treasurer said yesterday, to use taAation, as well as monetary policy and policy about outlays, as countercyclical policy. At a time when outlays have been severely constrained, when there are strong demands for improvements in education or health or welfare, or for spending on the arts, the environment or infrastructure, and those demands are entirely justified, it seems right to consider the possibility of using taxation as well as outlays as a countercyclical tool. The question then for the government is how to do that. All of us would have our appropriate suggestions to make, but I would wimt to emphasise that the changes should be carefully targeted and should be progressive. In other words, they should be imposed on areas where people can more readily afford them; in other words, they should be imposed on high income earners rather than low income earners or middle income earners or perhaps on certain areas in the business sector where they will not discourage investment. Such areas are available. Let me mention just a couple. A very obvious area would be to have dividend imputation. Australia is, I am told, perhaps the only country, but at the very least one of the few countries, with 100 per cent dividend imputation. Most countries in the OECD have half dividend imputation. That is a benefit, of course, only to those who own shares. By definition, that is principally those who are on upper incomes or the more wealthy. To have dividend imputation would still give them some of the benefit of that policy but it would save about $900 million in revenue forgone. That would be an equitable measure. It would bring us into line with a lot of the rest of the Western world, and it would not discourage the purchase of shares. I think that that is a very serious possibility that ought to be considered. Another course which many people mention would be to do away with negative gearing. That too is a tax policy that is of benefit to those who are by definition relatively well off, who can benefit from the effect of their assets on their net income. I think a lot of people judge that abolition of negative gearing would be a progressive policy. Another possibility would be changes to some of the tax treatment of superannuation, particularly for very high income earners. Other possibilities are available but those ones would be quite well targeted. They would be progressive policies which would not discourage investment, which would bring us into line with much of the rest of the Western world, which would not be discriminatory and which would be paid for by those who can most readily afford them. It is important to consider those possibilities, as well as the possibility of perhaps a higher marginal rate for people on over $70,000. There is nothing sacrosanct about the upper limit at present of $50,000. That too would make the income tax system rather more progressive. I have explored these ideas with quite a lot of care in a book that I wrote with a friend the Australian National University, John Quiggin, and we have done quite a bit of research on them. Therefore I make these suggestions on the basis of quite a bit of careful thought, and I hope that they will be considered by the government. I conclude by repeating that what is happening at present is in large measure the result of sound policy over the last few years. forthwith. The economy is now growing strongly. The problems are the delightful ones of a strong recovery. The issues for the government are how to ensure that that recovery can be sustained so that employment can go on growing in the ways that we all want. .Employment growth will occur mainly in the service sector, and a lot of it in the human service sector. To build up the revenue base allows some of that growth of employment to be in the area of publicly provided human services like education and health, areas where there are desperate needs for improvement. The example that seems to me to be most powerful is that at the beginning of this year 140,000 people who applied to go to technical and further education colleges were not able to find places. Therefore, it is a very high priority to build up the number of places available so that those people can get the skills that they need for the working life that they want and so that Australia can have the benefit of a more skilled work force. For some of the additional revenue to be used for improvements in the number of TAPE places would be welcomed very widely in the community. Since TAPEs are the most widely underfunded areas of education, I think that is one of the highest priorities for use of any additional revenue that is available. No doubt, some of the additional revenue would rightly be used for reducing the deficit. It should also be used in ways that will maximise growth of employment, and the TAPE sector is a particularly good example. I conclude by reiterating the centrality of the employment goal and the need to ensure sustainable economic development in ways that will also include increased equity, which at would in tum contribute to making the economy more humane and sustainable. Question resolved in the affirmative. NA ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994 Cognate bills: NA AND COMPANIES lULL 1994 AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994 Consideration resumed from 29 June. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: Unknown
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill, together with the two others that are part of the same package, is to replace the Audit Act 1901. That act is one of the few Commonwealth laws that have operated continuously since they were passed by this parliament in its first session after federation. Its intended replacement, therefore, represents something of a landmark in the history of Commonwealth financial administration. The Audit Act is not being replaced simply because it is old. In fact, it has proved remarkably robust over its 93-year life in providing for the procedural framework for Commonwealth financial administration and for the audit of the Commonwealth's activities. But too many of its basic concepts and structures reflect their 19th century origins to an extent that ignores and in some cases even impedes modern management practice and contemporary expectations for public sector accountability. These limitations were recognised by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the course of its comprehensive inquiry into the operations of the Audit Office. In its report 296, tabled in April 1989, the JCPA recommended that the Audit Act be replaced with more modern legislation, with separate acts to deal with auditing and financial administration. In giving effect to that recommendation, the government believes that clarity would be served best through the adoption of three new acts. It is proposed that there be an Auditor General Act to provide for the powers and functions of the Auditor-General. In relation to financial administration, however, Commonwealth bodies differ according to the basic legal financial status that each one has-namely, whether the body has the legal capacity, in its own right, to acquire ownership of money and other assets coming into its possession, or whether it acts only as a financial and custodial agent for the Commonwealth, without acquiring separate legal ownership of such money and assets. Consequently, it is proposed that there be a Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act to specify certain matters that are to apply to the operations of financially autonomous bodies-that is, Commonwealth bodies that have legal ownership of money in their own right; and a Financial Management and Accountability Act, to apply to the financial operations of agencies-that is, Commonwealth bodies that financially are agents of the Commonwealth in that the bodies acquire no legal ownership of the money that they raise and spend. That money, in the constitutional sense, directly comprises the 'Treasury of the Commonwealth'. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may recall that, upon introduction of the package of these three bills on 29 June 1994, the House agreed that the legislative package be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its consideration and advisory report. JCPA report 331 tabled on 22 September 1994 is the result of that process. I believe that the committee is to be commended for its quality analysis and recommendations, the great majority of which the government accepts. In that regard, I foreshadow that the government will be moving a number of amendments to the bills to pick up the recommendations of the JCPA accepted by the government, together with several other minor changes the desirability for which became evident as a consequence of reviewing the bills to address the JCPA's examination. I now wish to provide an outline of the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act. The proposed act is concerned with the regulatory-accounting-accountability framework for dealing with and managing the money and property of the Commonwealth. It will specify responsibilities and powers necessary for the efficient, effective and ethical use of the resources lawfully available to the Commonwealth to carry out its programs; and it will provide appropriate mechanisms to ensure that the stewardship and management performance of those who are responsible for those resources can be made visible and thereby allow them to be held accountable. The proposed law will add substance to the spirit of the public sector financial reforms that have been a feature of this government's administration over the last decade. At the same time, the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act is intended to preserve the traditional strengths of the Audit Act's key principles of financial control and, where possible, to clarify and simplify them. The explanatory memorandum accompanying this bill deals comprehensively with its features. There are, however, a few elements that I would like to mention specifically. The definitions of 'Agency', 'Chief Executive', 'official', 'public money' and 'public property', between them, describe the proposed boundaries of the act's application. Within those boundaries, the principles set down in the act will be fleshed out, where necessary, by subsidiary legislation-regulations and finance minister's orders-to provide procedural substance for the day-today application of those principles. Such a legislative framework is patterned on the structure established by the Audit Act for regulations and finance directions, except that, unlike finance directions, which are administrative in character, provision is made for finance minister's orders to be tabled as disallowable instruments. The legislative framework will be completed by instructions which chief executives will be authorised to issue to officials of their agencies. The act will preserve the unique role of the Minister for Finance, which is central to the orderly functioning of the Commonwealth's financial administration. The finance minister is, for all practical purposes, the custodian of the constitutional 'Treasury of the Commonwealth' so that the range of statutory powers and responsibilities for the proper custody of the Commonwealth's money is vested in that office. The finance minister will retain the sole power to agree appropriate banking arrangements for public money and to make orders concerning the handling of receipts and withdrawals of public money and its investment. The existing power under the Audit Act to arrange overdrafts and advances from banks has been clarified to specifically limit such arrangements as short-term cash management tools-overdrafts on operational bank accounts for up to 30 days; borrowings from banks as advances paid to the Commonwealth for up to 90 days; and other types of credit arrangements, to be prescribed by the regulations, such as those represented by credit card and cabcharge transactions, for up to 60 days. It should be noted that these arrangements confer no power for the Commonwealth to spend otherwise than as authorised by parliament through appropriations. One of the most 'visible changes to be brought about by the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act is in relation to the accounting classifications of money in the Commonwealth's possession. The trust fund established by section 60 of the Audit Act is to be abolished and replaced by two purpose based funds-the. reserved money fund and the commercial activities fund. Apart from components of the reserved money fund that may be established pursuant to other enactments, the components of these two funds will be established or varied by finance minister's determinations. The effect of such determinations will be to specify the kinds of money that may be drawn from the consolidated revenue fund or loan fund and credited to the particular component and the purposes on which that money may then be spent. Since the spending of money from such a fund is in all respects an appropriation, the proposed act will require that these determinations by the finance minister be tabled as disallowable instruments that do not take effect until the period for disallowance has passed. This procedure is more visible and provides a greater measure of parliamentary control than has traditionally been the case in the establishment of trust accounts under the Audit Act. Payments of public money, including debiting a fund against an appropriation, will be controlled by a system of 'drawing rights', to be issued by the finance minister. This system is predicated on the fact that the laws made by parliament relating to appropriations, variously compelling or permitting the executive government to spend, always specify the fund being appropriated and the purpose of the spending. Such laws may also specify an amount and a time frame. It would be a breach of section 83 of the constitution for spending to occur in any instance outside of those parameters, so the act will stipulate the finance minister has no capacity to issue valid drawing rights that are inconsistent with the terms of the relevant appropriation law and will make it an indictable offence for an official or minister to knowingly spend, or seek to spend, otherwise than in accordance with a valid drawing right. The act would create a standing appropriation out of which rewards could be paid in certain circumstances for information furnished that led to the apprehension of persons defrauding the Commonwealth. The government is serious about deterring and detecting fraud against the Commonwealth, and the potential for this measure to assist in that battle cannot be overlooked. Nevertheless, the government acknowledges the recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and路 Public Administration in its report on the inquiry into fraud on the Commonwealth, Focusing on fraud, tabled in November 1993, that there be no such formal scheme of rewards. The response to that report, including that recommendation, is being considered by the government and will be announced shortly. Should it transpire that the government accepts the committee's recommendation, the government will move for this clause's removal from the bill. The act would put into the principallegislation the powers that are presently carried only in finance regulations in relation to providing a source of authority for the Presiding Officers to approve expenditure under appropriations for parliamentary departments. The present Audit Act is generally silent on matters of management performance. The new act seeks to remedy this through particular responsibilities being expressly placed on chief executives of agencies for which they may then be held accountable. They are to be required to manage the affairs of their agencies efficiently, effectively and ethically to the extent allowed by law. They will also be required to implement fraud control plans and establish audit committees. The accountability mechanisms to mesh with these responsibilities will include powers of the finance minister to obtain financial statements and that other reports more frequently than annually from agencies. Importantly, it is proposed that chief executives be permitted to subdelegate to officials any of the act's finance minister's powers or functions, unless the minister has imposed a restriction prohibiting or limiting such subdelegation. These arrangements for subdelegating are intended to achieve a major strengthening in the financial framework. Chief executives are better placed than the finance minister to manage, to monitor and to control the activities of those officials who perform the delegated tasks. It will thus be practicable to hold chief executives accountable to the finance minister in these respects, whereas it is currently quite impracticable to do so under the existing Audit Act's delegation structures where thousands of individual officials are directly delegated by the finance minister. The government believes that this proposed law represents a significant landmark in sharpening and strengthening the framework of Commonwealth financial administration. I commend the bill to the House. NA COMPANIES BILL 1994 The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 is one of three bills forming the package of legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. The bill seeks to replace and enhance part XI of the Audit Act 1901, which currently provides standard financial provisions for Commonwealth authorities and certain other bodies. It is also intended course that the proposed Commonwea1th Authorities and Companies Act will replace individual financial provisions contained in the enabling legislation of authorities not subject to part XI. As I foreshadowed in the second reading speech for the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the government will be moving a number of amendments to this package of legislation to pick up issues that have been considered following the report on the three bills by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on 22 September 1994. The underlying purpose of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act is to replace, with a single set of requireone ments, the myriad of variations on a similar theme scattered throughout the enabling legislation of Commonwealth authorities and the constitutions of Commonwealth companies. The approach proposed by this bill would enable the accountability requirements of Commonwealth controlled bodies to be viewed as a whole and should significantly streamline the focus of the government's and the parliament's interest in this area. Broadly, the bill proposes a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for djrectors of 'Commonwealth authorities' and sets out standards of conduct for executive officers. Many of these requirements are modelled on comparable areas of the Corporations Law as well as best practice currently applying to individual authorities. The bill also proposes a single set of requirements for ensuring that 'wholly-owned Commonwealth companies' keep ministers and the parliament informed of their activities. In particular, this bill seeks to extend the mandate of the Auditor-General to be the sole external auditor of all Commonwealth authorities and companies, and their subsidiaries, without exception. At the same time it would modernise the requirements for the Auditor General's reports on authorities making them consistent with those required by the Corporations Law. In some areas, the bill traverses ground that is covered, to varying degrees, in the enabling legislation of authorities and the constitutional in due documents of companies. These areas of overlap will be removed by consequential amendments to the enabling legislation and are contained in the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1994, which I propose to introduce shortly. Similarly, it is intended to replace areas of overlap in the memoranda and articles of association of Commonwealth companies with cross-references to the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act. . For the purposes of the bill, a 'Commonwealth authority' is, in essence, one established by an act as a body corporate for a public purpose and which holds money on its own account. A 'Commonwealth company' is in which the Commonwealth has a direct controlling interest-that is, there is no interposed entity between the company and the Commonwealth. All Commonwealth companies will be subject to the requirement for the Auditor General to report on their financial statements, and the financial statements of their subsidiaries, and for their annual reports to be tabled in the parliament. However, only 'whollyowned Commonwealth companies' are to be subject to the other provisions in the bill relating to companies. This reflects the difficulty-in the case of Commonwealth controlled companies which have private shareholders-of imposing a general regime which requires the provision of plans and reports only to ministers: namely, a risk of oppression actions under the Corporations Law by minority shareholders who might perceive discrimination against their interests. I will now briefly outline the main provisions of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act. The annual report is seen as the centrepiece of directors' accountability to the parliament. The bill proposes that directors of Commonwealth authorities must prepare an annual report containing a report of operations, financial statements and "a report by the Auditor-General on the financial statements. The report of operations and the financial statements must be prepared in accordance with finance minister's orders and the directors and the Auditor-General must certify whether, in their opinion, the financial statements give a 'true and fair view' of the matters required-to be reported. I should mention that the proposed obligations on directors, as individuals, will replace more general obligations on authorities under existing arrangements. This approach is similar in principle to that applied to companies by the Corporations Law and is intended to clarify the accountability arrangements. I should also mention that the finance minister's orders will be disallowable instruments, thereby ensuring an ongoing role for the parliament in determining the reporting obligations of directors of Commonwealth authorities. The directors of both Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies will be required to give the responsible minister a copy of their annual report, or annual general meeting documents, which the Minister must in tum table in each House of the parliament. There are a number of other reporting obligations proposed by this bill. The finance minister may require Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned companies to prepare half-yearly or quarterly financial statements. The statements must be given to the responsible minister within two months after the end of the period to which they relate and must be tabled in each House as soon as practicable. It is envisaged that this requirement to prepare interim financial statements will mainly be applied to bodies with a high degree of independence, such as government business enterprises-GBEs. Of course, as the government, from time to time, develops new approaches to providing the services now provided by GBEs, there may be a need to look again at how the proposed act will apply to those bodies. Directors will be required to keep the responsible minister informed of the operations of Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned companies, including their subsidiaries, and to give the responsible minister and the finance minister such reports, documents and information as they may require. Where the finance minister requires such reports, documents and information it is intended that, in the normal course, he or she will first consult with the responsible minister and provide a copy of such reports or documents to that minister. Such consultative arrangements have not been included in the bill, because of long standing policy, reaffirmed by successive governments, that as a general rule the internal operations of government should not be reflected in legislation. Directors must also notify the responsible minister of certain proposed activities such as significant acquisitions or disposals of shares or businesses, changes in business activities or involvement in partnerships, trusts or joint ventures. However, the responsible minister may give written guidelines, as to the coverage of the matters to be notified and may in writing exempt the directors from notifying particulars of proposals to form or participate in the formation of a company. Directors of a government business enterprise, whether constituted as an authority or a company, must prepare a corporate plan at least once a year and give it to the responsible minister. This is a key planning document that will provide the responsible minister with financial and other performance information. The bill also contains a number of miscellaneous provisions relating to the governance of Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned Commonwealth companies. It its parent. proposes that the responsible minister may, after consulting with directors, notify them general policies of the government that capable of being applied to the authority company concerned. The directors must ensure that such policies are carried out and, as far as practicable, ensure that they are also carried out in relation to any subsidiaries. Such policies cannot be in conflict with any statutory obligations of a particular authority or company. This provision is intended to cover government policies that are applicable to the Commonwealth public sector in genertheir al-for example, policies relating to trade contact with foreign countries or equal emimproper ployment opportunity. Nevertheless, in recognition of their special roles, and so as to avoid any misconceptions in so far as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service are concerned, I' intend to propose consequential amendments to their enabling acts through the foreshadowed Audit (Transiauthority tional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill that will make it abundantly clear that this provision cannot affect the editorial policy independence of those bodies. The bill also provides that directors must establish and maintain an audit committee. The government views this as a step in the improving internal control and communication within Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned companies as well as the accountabiliby ty of their management. It will also ensure that directors have appropriate assistance the discharge of their accounting and financial reporting obligations. Consistent with the government's response to a recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administraparticulars tion in its 1989 report on government comregulation. panies and their reporting requirements, the bill provides that a Commonwealth authority must ensure that none of its subsidiaries anything that the authority itself does not have power to do. This does not, of course, preclude the parliament from passing legislaaccountability tion to empower a subsidiary to perform a particular activity that exceeds the powers of The bill imposes standards of conduct on of executive officers of Commonwealth authoriare ties broadly equivalent to the standards or already imposed on executive officers of companies 'by the Corporations Law. Executive officers include directors and any other persons who are concerned in, or take part in, the management of the authority. Specifically, the bill provides that 'executive officers' must at all times act honestly and exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of their powers and the discharge of duties. Also, an executive officer, or former executive officer, must not make use of inside information, or of his or her position as an executive officer, in order to gain an advantage for any person, either directly or indirectly, or cause detriment to the authority. Both criminal and civil sanctions are provided for contravention of these provisions. In addition, a director of a Commonwealth who has an interest in a matter that is being considered, or about to be considered, by the board must, as soon as posor sible after he or she becomes aware of the situation, disclose the nature of the interest concerned at a meeting of the board. The director must not participate in deliberations on the matter concerned unless the board or responsible minister determines otherwise. Finally, in accordance with the government's response to another recommendation the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its report on in government companies and their reporting requirements, the bill provides that the responsible minister shall table in each House particulars of any new or varied direct Commonwealth interest in a company. The required are to be prescribed by The proposals put forward in this bill will have no direct impact on government revdoes enues or outlays. However, I am confident that, through the implementation of a more streamlined and consistent operational and framework for Commonwealth authorities and companies, improved performance and value for money will be achieved both for the Commonwealth and for Australians generally. I commend the bill to the House. AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994 This bill is one of the package of three bills to replace the Audit Act 1901. The other two bills are the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994 and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994. The purposes of the Auditor-General Bill are to continue the statutory office of the Auditor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia; to specify the powers and functions of the Auditor-General; to establish the Australian National Audit Office; and to provide, in tum, for the independent audit of the Australian National Audit Office. The bill draws heavily on the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, JCPA, in report 296-The Auditor General: ally of the people and parliament. The effect of the bill's proposed provisions will be to support the continued functional and professional independence of the Auditor General from the executive government. The corollary is that the Auditor-General's special relationship with the parliament is protected. As I foreshadowed in the second reading speech for the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the government will be moving a number of amendments to this package of legislation to pick up issues that have been considered following the report on the three bills by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on 22 September 1994. I now wish to provide an outline of the proposed Auditor-General Act. The bill specifies there is to be an Auditor General for the Commonwealth of Australia and details the appointment and conditions of the office. The Auditor-General will continue to be appointed by the Governor General on the recommendation of the appropriate minister-which, under the administrative arrangements orders, will be the Prime Minister. Under arrangements proposed in this bill, prior to advising the Governor General, the Prime Minister must consult with the finance minister, the chairman of the JCPA and a nominee of the Leader of the Opposition. As recommended by the JCPA in report 331, the government will seek an amendment to the provision in the present bill to include a requirement for the Prime Minister to also consult with the chairperson of the audit committee of parliament, as appropriate. The bill also includes provisions for the removal of the Auditor-General by the Governor General following a petition by both houses of the parliament in the same session. The Auditor-General has a broad mandate to be enshrined in legislation, replacing the existing arrangements whereby the Auditor General's mandate is only partly derived from legislation and partly from government policy. The Auditor-General will have a mandate to undertake the audit of the financial statements of all Commonwealth bodies. In addition, the Auditor-General may undertake performance audits of Commonwealth bodies at his or her discretion, the only exception being in respect of government business enterprises-GBEswhere the accountability framework estab. lished by the government requires GBEs to focus on performance and to improve the return to the Commonwealth as shareholder. Despite the focus on performance by GBEs, the government nevertheless proposes that parliament or a minister may request the Auditor-General to carry out a performance audit of a GBE or GBE subsidiary. However, the government has reflected on the need to continue the principle, as already accepted under the Audit Act, of forbearance in consideration of the investment interests of private shareholders in partially privatised Commonwealth companies. Performance audits are an extra feature on the accountability landscape peculiar to public sector bodies. It does not follow, however, that the often high parliamentary profile given the reports of such audits would always be beneficial to the interests of the companies' private investor/shareholders. The government will, therefore, be proposing an amendment whereby a performance audit of a GBE company would be invited only if the company was wholly owned by the Commonwealth. The bill seeks to permit the Auditor-General to enter into an arrangement with any person or body to conduct financial statements audits or performance audits, or to provide services that are of a kind that are normally performed by auditors. These arrangements would be at the discretion of the Auditor-General and be undertaken where he or she considers there is a benefit to the Commonwealth. The bill proposes that the Auditor-General and authorised officials have full and free access to information, documents and premises. These powers are considerable in their scope but are necessary if the Auditor-General is to fulfil his or her obligations to the parliament. The information gathering powers are complemented with strong secrecy and penalty provisions for any person performing an Auditor-General function. The bill seeks to establish the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority with the sole function of assisting the Auditor-General. The staff of the Australian National Audit Office are to be appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922, as a reflection of its status as a core public service. Nevertheless, should the staff's existing skills and expertise need to. be mented from time to time, the bill also seeks to preserve the Auditor-General's flexibility to engage any person-for example, to contract with auditors from the private sector-to assist in the performance of an Auditor General function. The government sees the establishment of the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority as an important symbolic step to demonstrate its commitment to the independence of the Auditor-General and his or her office. Further, the bill would establish the office of independent auditor, who is the parliament's auditor of the Australian National Audit Office. It provides for the appointment and conditions of the office which, as far as are appropriate, mirror those of the Auditor General in relation to his or her audit functions for the balance of the Commonwealth. The independent auditor is to be a part-time statutory officer appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the appropriate minister, who will have first consulted with the chairman of the JCPA. The independent auditor is to hold qualifications and have the experience determined necessary by the minister after consultation with the chairman of the JCPA. The government will seek an amendment to this provision to include a requirement for the minister to also consult with the chairperson of the audit committee of parliament, as appropriate. As previously indicated, the government has drawn heavily on the recommendations of the JCPA in framing this legislation. While the committee's recommendations have not been taken up in their entirety, the provisions of this bill and the complementary provisions in the other two bills in the package ensure that the Auditor-General can fulfil, independently, the role demanded by this parliament, and with all the professional and functional freedom required for the task. The Auditor-General plays a vital role in giving credibility to Australia's system of parliamentary governance, and this legislation will preserve and strengthen that role. I commend the bill to the House.  aug- package of bills presents a long overdue improvement and overhaul of the Audit Act 1901. The bills provide for greater scrutiny of government operations and businesses and for greater independence of the Auditor-General. The Australian people have a right to know that their money and interests are being adequately looked after by the Commonwealth. It is especially important when dealing with a government such as this one, which rules by grubby deals and bias. I take this opportunity to condemn the government for its handling of these bills as they come before this House. It is ironic that the coalition, which represents many millions of people throughout the nation, could not get hold of a copy of the government's amendments after the government established its direction in regard to the bills. The government is wrapping itself in greater accountability, while at the same time deliberately seeking to reduce the effectiveness of parliament and its scrutiny of bills. This is representative of this government's complete disdain for the parliament and its effect on its representatives. This government fears accountability. Evidence of the fear of accountability of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is found in the fact that he and his ministers decided to face parliament only twice in a sitting week to answer questions. This grubby little incident serves as a stark reminder of why these bills are so sorely needed. This government cannot even deal with these bills concerning open and honest government in an open and honest way. The Financial Management and Accountability Bill provides stringent new requirements for the handling of Commonwealth funds. Its scope covers the underlying principles that to govern the activities of persons in organisaneed tions that financially are agents of the Commonwealth. The fundamental principles of financial control contained in the Audit Act 1901 have been incorporated in these bills. This bill is intended to improve the quality and clarity of understanding of the Commonwealth financial management framework and to sharpen accountability for financial management performance. This, again, is entirely appropriate. There should be strict controls over how taxpayers' finances are managed. It is a great pity, however, that the greater accountability requirements within the bill are not carried over into government policy. This is a government of mates for mates. The ordinary Australian rates a mention only once every three years when the Prime Minister promises the world and then reneges on those promises. This government is typified by waste, shady deals and taxpayer funded buy-offs. There are numerous examples of these. One only has to recall the sports rorts affair, the maritime union buy-off, the Prime Minister's table, the Prime Minister's paintings, and the credit card controversy within the Lodge itself. Sadly, tight financial requirements will not always be prevalent in this government's case. What will stop all this is a government with integrity which is in touch with the things that matter to ordinary Australians, not a government, such as the present one, which uses taxpayers' money to buy more and more true believers. It is for this reason that the coaliout tion must always be on its guard against government attempts to restrict and limit parliamentary scrutiny. True to form, .this government has sought to do just that. I refer to the disallowance provisions for commercial funds. The standard provision for disallowance is 15 days. What does the government want to do? It wants to strip away parliament's oversight by taking the disallowance time down to just five days. What is the hurry? Is the government so badly organised that allowing parliament to have proper scrutiny w.ould disrupt financial plans? Does the government view parliament with contempt and as something to be avoided? are Surely, a Commonwealth entity which has for commercial provisions can take account of parliament's sittings in its plans? Call me old fashioned, but I like to think that parliament and its elected representatives should still figure in the minds of Commonwealth entities. Remember parliament? You are sitting in it! Parliament is the place that looks after the interests of ordinary Australians, those people who do not figure in the ALP's grandiose plans. At least one group still represents the cares of ordinary Australians, and that is the coalition. In order to uphold the interests of ordinary Australians in this House, the coalition will be moving an amendment to standardise the disallowance provisions. The parliament must be given sufficient time to scrutinise instruments which will affect the lives of the people we represent. I certainly hope that the government will have enough integrity to change its mind and vote with us, but that would be running against form. I tum now to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. This bill will enhance part 11 of the Audit Act 1901, which currently provides standard financial provisions for public authorities and certain other bodies. It will also replace individual financial provisions contained in the enabling legislation of authorities not subject to part 11. The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill will provide a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for directors of Commonwealth authorities and set standards of conduct for executive officers. Many of these requirements are based on i, comparable Corporations Law as well as the best practice applying to individual authorities. The Auditor-General's mandate will be extended to all Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies without exception, and this is how it should be. The public has a right to expect that public businesses are following sound financial reporting. For too long there has been this hole in Commonwealth law. Commonwealth companies have been expected to act in a commercial sense or attain best practice but the auditing provisions have not been able to back this up. Of course, the best way to obtain best practice in government businesses is to expose them to competition from the private sector. Why should the taxpayer be sinking money into an enterprise which can most effectively be operated in the private sector? Where a Commonwealth business can operate in the commercial marketplace to the benefit of the economy, it should be allowed to do so. The marketplace will impose far greater discipline with lower cost and at lower prices than any amount of government tinkering and social engineering. This has at last dawned on the government and so they have stolen the coalition's principles in this area well, albeit only to the extent allowed by its ACTU masters. As usual, the ALP's rhetoric far outstrips its actions. Modem financial management and accounting principles are an important support to the principles of greater commercial practice. It is a truism, however, that merely updating financial requirements will not force companies to act commercially. Where possible, government businesses must be allowed to take their chances in the marketplace if consumers and the nation are to get maximum benefit from the policy. Typically, however, the Labor Party has also bastardised this principle for petty politipowers cal reasons. I refer, of course, to the government's spineless response to the Maritime Union thuggery and intimidation. Rather than rule in the interest of the nation, the government acted to protect and pay off its mates. Of course, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) the minister for backflips, was only too happy to dip into the taxpayers' purse so that his union mates could have more comfort in the workplace. So .much for exposing businesses and their work practice to competition in the market. But it does not stop there. The so-called privatisation program of the government is a farce. Privatisation is clearly the best way of exposing appropriate government business enterprises to full commercial reality. But this government could not sell heaters in the Arctic. On the Qantas float, it would be fair to say that the Minister for Finance, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), is having trouble getting the nose wheel down for the .sale. In the sorry saga of ANL, while the government is throwing taxpayers' money around and desperately trying to come up with a sale, ANL's finances are dead in the water. So it really is not good enough to simply put out new legislation on accounting requirements. This must be backed up by active policies to expose Commonwealth companies to commercial pressure and best practice. But given that the Keating government has completely dropped the ball on micro-economic reform, there is little chance of the hard as decisions being made. It is the Auditor General's bill where the government has again dropped the ball. To be effective, the Auditor General must be truly independent and answerable to the parliament, not the executive. The executive must not be able to apply pressure-either implicit or explicit-to gain a more agreeable finding. This bill improves the powers of the Auditor-General to gather information and ensure that taxpayers' interests are being looked after. It establishes the office of Auditor-General for the Commonwealth and sets the Auditor-General's functions. The Auditor-General will have new, stronger of entry and information gathering. The coalition fully endorses these new principles, but would prefer to put in place even stronger safeguards of the Auditor-General's independence. We believe in this because, unlike the government, the coalition has nothing to fear from an independent Auditor General. The coalition believes that the people's representatives should have oversight of the Auditor-General. While it is correct to increase the financial and functional independence of the Auditor General by providing independent powers of spending within the appropriation, we must do more to ensure that the Auditor-General is an instrument of the parliament. The coalition is strongly of the view that oversight of the Auditor-General should be done by an Audit Committee of the Parliament by modifying the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. This committee will be a permanent feature of the parliament; it will not exist as a whim of the government. Government business enterprises are an important sector of the economy. They are frequently an important input to the economy. For this reason, they must be functioning efficiently and effectively. To assist in this, the coalition feels that they should be open to the scrutiny of the Auditor-General and, through that office, the parliament. The coalition will be moving an amendment to allow the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of public enterprises wherever desired if there is significant or complete government ownership. The Auditor-General should not be constrained by ministerial veto or lower house votes. If the Auditor-General has concerns about the performance of a GBE, then the Auditor-General should rightly be able to investigate that matter. I cannot think why the government would oppose this. Perhaps greater scrutiny will help prevent more ANLs and taxpayer-funded buyouts.

text: In view of that interjection, let me make this point: up until recent years, since 1901 when the Commonwealth was established, those people who have tended to monopolise national government in Australia, in the Commonwealth, have been members of the coalition. The Audit Act, which we are now in the process of replacing, was the fourth item of legislation enacted by the new Commonwealth government back in 1901. That legislation, which has undoubtedly had numerous amendments, has existed until now. It was this government which put into place not only this legislation but all of the processes which have led up to it. We are too often amused by some of the absurd positions which are adopted by the opposition. I mentioned in passing that the legislation was first enacted in 1901. As I said, there have been many amendments. To a very large extent, those amendments have sought to respond to changing circumstances. But this is the first comprehensive, overall review leading to the complete restructuring of the government's audit legislation. It is a complete, new, comprehensive, more appropriate and contemporary approach to the whole question of financial accountability within the public sector. The basic reason for this legislation is the present act, that act which has persisted with amendments since 1901, has become increasingly less able to accommodate the needs and the realities of the modem public sector. This inadequacy was recognised in the 1989 report of the Public Accounts Committee on the Auditor-General. That report recommended that the act be repealed and replaced with legislation which was more in tune with present day realities, which was more effective in addressing their needs and which allowed greater flexibility in the financial management of public sector operations. The government accepted that recommendation. This legislation is the result. The Public Accounts Committee, as I indicated, became involved as a result of the Minister for Finance referring the legislation to it on 29 June this year. On that same day, as a result of a motion in the Senate, the Public Accounts Committee had referred to it the question of the establishment of an audit committee. As a result of both of those references to the Public Accounts Committee we now have this very comprehensive report-report 331-of the Public Accounts Committee. The committee tabled its report on 22 September. The government has considered that report. This legislation represents a modification of the initial legislation as a result of many of those recommendations made by the Public Accounts Committee. This package comprises three bills: the Financial Management and Accountability Bill, referred to generally now as the FMA Bill; the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, referred to more generally as the CAC Bill; and the Auditor-General Bill. The general construction of this legislation was referred to in some detail by the Minister for Finance in his second reading speech. But let me refer very briefly by way of background to the essence of this legislation. The FMA Bill, for example, establishes appropriate arrangements for financial management and accountability within Commonwealth agencies. For the purpose of the legislation, Commonwealth agencies are those departments and statutory authorities whose enabling legislathat tion does not give them legal ownership of money or property separate from the Commonwealth. Those Commonwealth authorities and companies which do legally own money or property on their own account are those which have been picked up in the CAC Bill. That legislation has been necessary in particular to draw together, to coordinate and to integrate all of the existing provisions which are scattered through diverse and disparate sources. The legislation is designed to make consistent and explicit the accountability requirements for each type of Commonwealth entity. The Auditor-General Bill-and this is the legislation to which most attention is being given by the government and by way of amendments proposed by the opposition-is a very comprehensive piece of legislation. It not only establishes the offices of the Auditor General and the Independent Auditor but also describes their powers and, as the minister indicated in his second reading speech, it establishes the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority to provide resources and support services to the Auditor General in the carrying out of the responsibilities which he has. It is interesting to note the comments the member for Forrest made about accountability and whether or not the government's conduct in relation to these bills has been adequate. During the inquiry which the Public Accounts Committee undertook it had occasion to deal with a letter written in response to an approach by the PAC to the Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Dr Keating. Dr Keating concluded his letter by saying: ... it is difficult to think of any Bills which been subject to longer and more extensive consultation before being presented to the Parliament. There is no way that the claims of the kind that the member for Forrest has made can, in any real sense, be substantiated. I will now refer to the background to the reference of those three bills to the Public Accounts Committee. The Procedure Committee in its report entitled About time referred to old standing order 221 which permitted bills of the parliament to be referred to a select committee following their second reading. No bills had ever been referred under that provision, although the standing orders had been suspended on occasions to refer a bill to a joint select committee immediately following the minister's second reading speech. The Procedure Committee considered that a procedural mechanism to permit a bill to be referred to a standing committee needed to be provided formally in the standing orders and it made an appropriate recommendation. That recommendation has been picked up in new standing order 217 A. That particular provision provides a more effective mechanism by which legislation can be referred to committees. Since that special provision was made a number of bills have been referred to committees. For example, on 4 May a bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, on 11 May a bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, on 7 June a bill was referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, on 29 June this package of three bills was referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and on 25 August the Minister for Employment, Education and ,Training (Mr Crean) referred the Employment I Services Bill 1994 to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As a result, what we have done is introduce, where necessary and appropriate, a new process into the legislative continuum-the initiation of legislation, the preparation of legislation, the work of Parliamentary Counsel, the political party processes, cabinet have consideration and so on. Another stage has been introduced as a result of these changes. I referred to this earlier when I said I welcomed and applauded the change. I think it has been a very desirable change. The effectiveness of that process is reflected not only in the very effective way in which the Public Accounts Committee gave consideration to these three bills but also in the quality of report which it brought down and now, the final stage in tpis process, the fact that the government has responded fa-ourably to so many of the proposals. That was an undertaking given by the Minister for Finance when he moved the motion to refer the legislation to the Public Accounts Committee. Referring to the three bills, he said: These bills, like few others, will ultimately have an impact on the entire field of government activity, simply because almost every action of the government has a financial implication. The JCPA was the body which initiated action to replace the Audit Act and the government believes that it should be the body to formally examine, in the first instance and on behalf of the parliament, the proposed outcome of this action. He concluded with a statement which really underlines the sincerity with which the government adopted this process. The minister said: As I have indicated, virtually by implication in the things that I have been saying, the government is not so proud of its authorship in this regard that it is going to take umbrage at getting additional advice from any sources and we look forward to the consultative processes yet in hand. Of course, the way in which the government has responded to that report indicates that that was not an idle statement by the Minister for Finance. It is one which the Minister for Finance quite clearly has honoured by the way he has responded to that report. I mentioned that the opposition was taking up some of the particular items of the Public Accounts Committee report in connection with what it had identified as some of the more important elements of the legislation. Certainly as far as the Auditor-General legislation was concerned, I would agree that they are some of the more significant. The particular recommendations from the Public Accounts Committee report that are picked up in these issues are recommendations 19 and 20, both of which are concerned with the capacity of the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of GBEs. The opposition proposes with its amendment to allow the Auditor-General to at any time conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth authority or company. If that amendment were successful, the Auditor General would then have unilateral power to decide whether or not those performance audits would be undertaken. The provision the government has is that the performance audits be undertaken by the Auditor-General in two circumstances: first, if there is a request made by the responsible minister; or, second, if there is a resolution both houses of parliament. I do not believe that is unduly restrictive. I do not think there would be any difficulty, in the case of a good relationship existing between the Minister for Finance and the Auditor-General, as there should be, with the Auditor-General, if he or she were to become aware of any inadequacies which would appear to justify a performance audit, having some discussion with the responsible minister in connection with any other government authority, agency or entity and seeking that request. Let us be clear about this. If in a situation of that kind it became apparent to the Auditor-General that some sort of performance audit was necessary or desirable and a request was made to the minister for the request to go back to the Auditor-General, the minister would need good grounds to knock that back. The whole question of public accountability and public transparency in relation to issues of that kind indicates that any minister who sought to refuse a request of that kind would be very foolish indeed if the grounds for the request were clearly sufficient. Recommendation 28 of the Public Accounts Committee report is concerned with the conditions under which staff of the audit office should be employed. The suggestion has been made-this has also been picked up by one of the proposed amendments of the opposition-that it should be withdrawn from the Public Service Act provisions and that the Auditor-General should have the power to negotiate the terms and conditions under which he or she employs staff. That certainly would provide the Auditor General with greater management flexibility. It would perhaps also provide the Auditor General with the opportunity to attract and keep the necessary staff. I have not yet seen within the Auditor-General's office where this does not exist. I have never seen any significant deficiency in the operation of that office. It has an enormous and a very effective output. Recommendation 33 concerns the appointment of the Auditor-General. The recommendation was that approval should be sought of from the Leader of the Opposition or his or her representative, the Public Accounts Committee and the Audit Committee. The appointment of auditors-general has always been transparent. I have not noticed people making any claims in Australia that the appointments have been deficient. These are matters which can be revisited from time to time, but again I do not believe it is a matter of very great substance. Recommendations 37 to 39 concern the question of a separate audit committee. The government has chosen to establish a separate audit committee rather than have those responsibilities absorbed by the Public Accounts Committee. (Time expired)
