text: And he is ratting on the committee whose recommendations he should uphold and endorse. Let us look at the detail of the way in which this works. An independent auditor is the only protection the parliament and the people of Australia have against the government departments doing the wrong thing. We are ultimately responsible for their actions. Our servant, the Auditor-General-an independent person-has the function of examining the accounts of all of these departments, and he should have that function. How can we discharge our responsibility here in this parliament if the Auditor-General is not free of ministerial control? He reports to the parliament, goes to those great departments and examines not only whether their adding and subtracting are right but also whether the efficiency of their programs is right. We need to have that. In part, you are denying that process by going against a report that you yourself signed. An路 independent auditor is a great protection for the citizens this nation against the abuse of government departments. . On many occasions members of the Public Accounts Committee have sat aghast as somebody appearing before the committee has explained a misinterpretation of the administration of public funds, and on occasion members of the Public Accounts Committee have disclosed the inisallocation of funds to the point of fraud. The Public Accounts Committee and the Auditor-General are protections for the Australian people. We have stopped fraud, we have prevented the abuse of funds, and saved the taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in this process. I would have thought that you would see that today and say, 'Yes, we really want to have a refinement of that independence of the auditor.' I would have thought that you would have endorsed the recommendations of your own report. The other great truth of this process is that not only is the independence of the auditor critical but also we must have a process where ministers and departments are answerable to somebody. It is no good ministers just going into the cabinet room and being responsible to the Prime Minister. We as parliamentarians have a responsibility to our electors to see that ministers and their departments administer funds properly. The policy items and the political processes are a matter for debate-that is fair enough-but when it comes to the expenditure of public moneys and the way in which they are used ministers need to be squeaky clean and be answerable to the parliament. On those two grounds, I think this is an important report and an important response. The government has failed to fully demonstrate its understanding of the need for an independent audit office and of the role of the Public Accounts Committee. If the Public Accounts Committee and the auditor are used properly, they are great tools for governments to be able to disclose misallocation of funds and inappropriate administration. It is a strengthening tool for government to be able to use the Auditor-General and the Public Accounts Cominittee. No minister should be of ashamed of sending something off to the Auditor-General, because that enables the electorate to gain confidence that the right thing is being done. So I cannot understand why the minister is chary about pursuing the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee. I only have to give the House one recent example of the necessity of this process. In the last 24 hours we have had in the House two ministers trying to defend the administration of the Child Support Agency and the terrible mess and abuse that its examination by ont< of the parliamentary committees disclosed. Those ministers would be far better off saying: 'Why not have the inquiry adopted by the parliament?' That is the way it should work. This is the tradition of the great Public Accounts Committee stretching back decades to Henry Bland, who founded it. It goes right back to that time. You are leaving a tradition that you should not walk away from. The role of the Public Accounts Committee has been to work without dissent and you have presented a report without dissent. It is a great shame that you now choose to support the government's decisions in the way it has provided legislation. Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: Unknown
text: My question is addressed, again, to the Minister for Transport. Why did the government open the third runway ahead of the completion of the new control tower and radar systems, when to do so would result in a reduction of capacity and create unnecessary additional noise over large sections of Sydney? Will the minister admit that this has led to one airline alone-that is, Ansettreceiving 30,000 complaints about delays in a single day, with 91 per cent of its flights through Sydney being delayed? Will he admit that his decision has reduced the capacity of Mascot from 64 movements per hour to 50 movements per hour, while at the same time increasing aircraft noise to intolerable levels for those under the flight paths? Will the minister finally be honest with affected residents and the travelling public and accept his responsibility for this total fiasco?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: Unknown
text: The impact of noise at Kingsford Smith airport is very sadly, I must say, consistent with the environmental impact study that was carried out, to which the Prime Minister referred in this House earlier this week, which indicated that, whilst 182,000 people were formerly affected by moderate or severe noise nuisance, under the new arrangements the number of 95,000 is much lower. That said, the fact is that one must feel very intensely for the 95,000 or so people who are at the moment experiencing the impact of the construction of the parallel runway. It is for that reason that cabinet will be considering, in the next day or so, a range of measures to tackle the question of alleviating this nuisance. It may be appropriate if I indicate to the House the sequence of events in respect of the timing of the opening of the parallel runway. On 1 February, which was right at the very start of my time as Minister for Transport, I wrote to the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority seeking advice on the best means to further improve safety at Sydney airport. I did so, against the backdrop of real concerns that had been expressed about the simops arrangements at Kingsford Smith-that is, the simultaneous take-offs and landings arrangements-which, of course, from a safety point of view, are not as optimum as parallel runways. That letter was prompted by concerns that had been put to me about the relative safety of simultaneous runway operations being used at that time in comparison with other possible methods of operating the airport. The Civil Aviation Authority wrote back to me on 15 February proposing a phased introduction of operations on the new parallel runway system to take advantage of the expected early completion of the new runway by the Federal Airports Corporation. In that advice to me on 15 February, the Civil Aviation Authority advised that operations could commence as early as September 1994, which is when it anticipated the new runway would be completed, by controlling traffic from the existing control tower, although there would be an initial slight fall in peak hour capacity. With the use of parallel runways, Sydney airport no longer requires the extensive use of simultaneous runway operations. Therefore, an already safe airport becomes that much safer. That was the backdrop to the timing of the opening. On the interim basis of the runway, the operations have very little impact as far as noise nuisance is concerned for the most affected people-the residents living in the corridor to the north of the airport-who are bearing the burden of the increased traffic. They bear that burden because, in the last month since operations commenced, some 30 plus per cent of take-offs have been to the north as a result of prevailing winds. When the wind blows at more than five knots apparent north, for safety considerations, planes need to take-off into that wind. Some planes can handle it better than others, but the fact is that the airport has to revert northern take-offs to suit some classes of planes, and that of necessity means that all planes have to take-off to the north in those circumstances. That has resulted in a very real impact. That is no different from the impact that will exist when the new tower opens in February or March next year. In respect of the new parallel runway, there are no take-offs to the north under the environmental impact statement. We are now seeing take-offs to the north, which is a noise nuisance factor of about double that of landings, principally brought on by the wind considerations at Kingsford Smith. That will not change at all. That somehow people are being exposed to greater noise nuisance than they should as a result of the airport being opened before the control tower is a total furphy. The fact is that a lot of planes have deviated from the flight paths in the last month. Lots of concerns have been very gravely expressed about the number of take-offs to the north, which is the very issue that cabinet will be addressing in the next day or so. Mr Tim Fischer-Will the full length of the east-west runway be available?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: Unknown
text: The Leader of the National Party asks whether the full length of .. the east-west runway will be available. Let me make it very clear to him and to the House that the east-west runway is available for those situations when there is too much cross-wind to operate the parallel runways. That is the case now, and will continue to be the case in the future. Let us be quite clear about that. On the first five days of operations of the new airport arrangements after the parallel runway was opened, because of exceptional westerly winds which prevailed in Sydney and, indeed, right across New South Wales at that time, the east-west runway was used exclusively. For those first five days, the burden of noise was overwhelmingly carried by people in the east-west corridor. That will be the case whenever that runway is required for operational reasons. Having said that, it needs to be understood to that in those circumstances only one runway is being operated, and operating one runway drops the capacity of the airport down to 30 to 40 take-offs and landings per hour. The big problem facing Kingsford Smith airport at the moment is the tremendous expansion in demand for its services during the peak periods. It has been stated by the Civil Aviation Authority that, between February and November this year, the demand for take-offs and landings at Kingsford Smith airport during the peak hours on the peak days has gone up by 50 per cent. With that unbridled demand in the peak hours on the peak days, the whole of the additional capacity at Kingsford Smith will readily be swamped. Indeed, there will be very extensive queuing and circling when the east-west runway is the only runway available as a result of safety considerations brought on by wind factors. For all of these reasons, the parallel runway at Kingsford Smith, as a result of the opening of which we have already seen volumes return almost to those of previous operations-that is, it is back up to over 61 take-offs and landings per hour-is operating satisfactorily and safely, but we need to, and we intend to, very seriously tackle this issue of noise nuisance, which is the subject of such grave concern for all people living under the flight corridor. Speaker: Mr HORNE
Title: Unknown
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. What progress is being made in implementing the training wage?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: Unknown
text: I thank the honourable member for Paterson for his question. Indeed, very good progress has been made. Today I have been informed that next week South Australia will move to fast-track award by award the training wage in that state. The House would be aware that, under the federal system, the national training wage was ratified by the federal commission as far back as 4 September. But what has been required is a mirroring of it in the states. With the South Australian operation in place, we will have effectively mirrored it in the states of South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. Tasmania has also legislated to give effect to it. This leaves Western Australia alone in not taking steps to secure the wage. The training wage that we have introduced is not the cut-price, punitive, training-inname-only wage that was proposed by the opposition at the last election. This is a genuinely award based rate. It is linked to a national training framework. It is industry responsive and supported by industry. I also remind the House that, whatever uncertainty people might think surrounds wages in the current environment, there is no uncertainty under the training wage because these rates have been set for 12 months. Anyone taken on under a traineeship arrangement incorporating the training wage is exempt from the unfair dismissal provisions of the IR act. As important as this progress has been, it is not the training wage alone that will help us secure the new training places. We have announced other measures, including funding for new traineeships, secured agreement from the states for a vocational training system and significant new funding to the vocational education and training sector. Today I spoke with the ACTU's regular council meeting and received from that meeting

Title: Unknown
text: I thank the honourable member for her question. It is the case, as members will know, that each year there is a range of discussions between Papua New Guinean and Australian ministers, generally involving half a dozen ministers from each side, alternately in Papua New Guinea and in Australia. That annual PNG-Australia Ministerial Forum took place in Melbourne last Thursday and Friday. Among the wide range of matters discussed was the future of our aid program. That is a very important strand of our relationship with PNG and, given the crucial economic problems-I think it is fair to describe them in that way-PNG is facing, it was a very timely discussion. We on the Australian side take the view that, in view of the fiscal and foreign exchange problems PNG is facing, which have led to the floating of the currency in PNG, amongst other things, there is simply no alternative to the PNG government negotiating and, importantly, then implementing a reform package with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. We think that should take place as soon as possible. Indeed, during those meetings we had assurances that the discussions with the World Bank would continue in January. In that context, an international support package is being talked about, but the figure-I see there were some references in the reports, which the honourable member referred to, to a figure-is still something that needs to be assessed. We made the point very firmly that any Australian support for an economic reform package to Papua New Guinea is dependent on Papua New Guinea negotiating a satisfactory agreement with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and, as well as that, on Papua New Guinea itself undertaking significant economic reforms. Two of those reforms are improving its own collection of revenue and increasing public investment from its budget. I emphasise that Australia's participation in that package would be most unlikely to involve any new or additional aid to Papua New Guinea, over and above the amounts which we are committed to supplying under the treaty. As far as our current aid program to Papua New Guinea is concerned, things are going well. Our budget support is being progressively replaced with much needed public investment programs, particularly in the areas nominated by Papua New Guinea of infrastructure, health and education. We also agreed during the discussions with Papua New Guinea that there would be full transparency in how those aid programs were progressing and that we would find ways of increasing the flow of public information. It was agreed that the review of the treaty of development cooperation, due to be conducted in September 1995, would proceed and that that review would consider matters induding Papua New Guinea's economic situation, the implications of the World Bank-International Monetary Fund adjustment programs and progress in implementing Australia's programmed aid. It was also agreed that planning for the review would commence shortly and that a working group would start meeting by April. In the context of the discussions, I was happy to be able to announce an $11 million project to assist sustainable forestry in Papua New Guinea, a matter of some concern in Australia as well. The project will improve education of forestry personnel and assist Papua New Guinea in the monitoring of logging activities. In announcing that, I urged Papua New Guinea to ensure that appropriate sustainable forest policies were implemented in line with the outcomes of the South Pacific Forum meeting in Brisbane. One move in that context would be to increase the level of export taxes on logs to improve the returns of logging to Papua New Guinea. Finally, I was able to present Papua New Guinea ministers with a report prepared by AIDAB on the damage to public infrastructure following the volcanic eruptions in Rabaul. That information will help them make the necessary decisions on the restoration or relocation of facilities in East New Britain and I believe it will be most valuable in that context. Title: Unknown
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. On Monday this week I, on behalf of the government, received the report on the review of the pensions income and assets test conducted by the independent consultant Ageing Agendas, which has worked on this matter over a considerable period together with a very broadly representative reference group of retiree organisations, the finance industry and relevant government departments. I think its report was a good, solid piece of work, which flowed out of a thorough consultation process, and it was very comprehensive in its review of the issues. It has put forward some 50 recommendations that will be considered in a budget context, and we will be developing a considered response to the report next year in that context. There is one recommendation in the report that, I can indicate, the government will be accepting now, and that is that the government maintain a targeted approach to pension provision. The alternative to that, which has been espoused by some, is the so-called universal pension, which in effect means paying pensions to everybody, irrespective of any assets or income test; in other words, completely removing any means testing. As anybody who is remotely honest concedes, the reality is" that that is simply unaffordable. We are talking about a cost of some $5 billion a year arising from removing all income and assets testing on pensions. It is also inequitable, and this has been confirmed in a study of the proposals by the retirement income modelling task force, which is a group of officials from Treasury, Finance and Social Security. Not only is it un affordable; it is inequitable in its impact. Contrary to the claims of the member for Berowra, proposals in this area were properly considered by the review. Just because a proposal is rejected does not mean that it was not properly considered. The honourable member for Berowra tries to have two-bob each way. Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Title: Unknown
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. Naturally, most Australians attach a very solemn importance to ANZAC Day. Some time ago in this House the member for Melbourne Ports, Mr Holding, and the member for Cook, Mr Dobie, in a bipartisan approach brought a private members motion to this House in which they asked exactly for this. The ex-service community has for some time been concerned that, as time goes on, the importance of ANZAC Day could be diminished, with younger generations coming up who may not be aware of the debts that are owed to those people who have fought not only in World War I or World War II but also in other wartime conflicts. Accordingly, the government tomorrow will be introducing a bill in this House to enshrine ANZAC Day in legislation as the day of commemoration, and we will provide that 25 April of each year be known as ANZAC Day. I want to thank all members of this House because I am certain that the legislation will be accepted-the honourable member for O'Connor publicly said that he would accept it. I am sure that it will be passed, and I have every confidence in ensuring that it will be passed in time for ANZAC Day 1995, which will mark the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II. In conclusion, I take this opportunity-it will probably be my last opportunity to do so this year-to thank all our colleagues from both sides of the House for the marvellous work that they are doing in their electorates with respect to the Australia Remembers year. I know it is going to be great. It has been taken up with a great deal of gusto by all Australians and I expect that the celebrations and commemorations next year will be something to behold. Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: Unknown
text: l thank the honourable member for Perth for the question. I acknowledge the close interest he takes in the work of schools in the electorate of Perth and the many opportunities he has given me to visit schools in electorate. In addition, the Commonwealth is to provide $67.7 million over the next four years to support increased enrolments in key Asian language studies among students from years 3 to 10 around Australia. The languages concerned are Indonesian, Chinese, Japanese and Korean. The national Asian languages studies strategy for Australian schools, NALSSAS, was agreed to by the Council of Australian Governments earlier this year and, of course, that included Western Australia. The Commonwealth appreciates the considerable benefits of fostering a multilingual population and it recognises the provision of appropriate funding as a key part of that process. For that reason, we provide considerable funds to the Western Australian government for this purpose. If schools in Western Australia are unable to offer classes through an alleged lack of trained teachers, there is no justification-none-for claiming that the fault lies with the Commonwealth. The Western Australian government has been provided with the funds. It is the Western Australian government's responsibility to use those funds and to provide the classes. Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: Unknown
text: by leave-I move: That this House censures the Minister for Transport for his failure to exercise proper ministerial standards and the maladministration resulting from his failure to perform his portfolio responsibilities. In the last few minutes as we have sat here, we have seen a very good reason emerge as to why the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) should 路resign forthwith from that post. Only a few moments ago we were reminded by him of people who preceded him in ministerial posts, people who had important responsibilities, who did the right thing eventually-and that was to resign. The minister reminded us of the honourable member who was the Minister for Aviation Support back in 1988, now the Minister for  who did the right thing and resigned. He reminded us of the former minister for the environment, the former Senator Richardson, who did the right thing and resigned. Thank you very much, Minister, for reminding us today of those who have gone before you who have ultimately seen the light and resigned. They resigned because they knew ultimately that the right thing was to act in a proper fashion because their ministerial responsibilities were beyond them. I do not think there has been a minister of this government over the last 12 months who has got himself into more trouble than the man sitting opposite us here today, the Minister for Transport. Just cast your mind back over the last 12 months and think of the great controversies that have been involved in federal politics and of the person who has been at the centre of those controversies. none other than the Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. There is a cartoon characterMr Costello-Danger Man.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: Unknown
text: Danger Man. Is it not amazing that the person who is responsible for aviation safety in this country is nicknamed 'Danger Man'? Mr Costello-By the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: Unknown
text: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was the man who named him, who gave him that nickname. Is it not also amazing that the day-today responsibility for aviation safety in this country is held by an organisation whose headquarters is called 'Fort Fumble'. So we have Danger Man and Fort Fumble looking after aviation safety in this country. There is a cartoon character that many of us would be familiar with called Flash Gordon. This character manages to get himself into trouble all the time. No sooner has he stumbled his way through one lot of trouble than he stumbles into the next. The person who best fits the description of Flash Gordon here in this parliament is the Minister for Transport. No matter what he does, and no matter how he goes about it, he walks straight into controversy and trouble; and no sooner has he got out of that trouble than he. gets into more trouble. The reputation that the Minister for Transport brought to this House when he was elected to the federal parliament in 1990 was one that certainly gave the impression that he, in his former role in the state parliament, was the equivalent of having an albatross around your neck. We all remember the reputation that this man had as the minister for public works in New South Wales. We will all remember the problems that the WranUnsworth government had in its dying days. Honourable members will remember the former Premier of New South Wales Barrie Unsworth, the old cardigan killer. Many people thought he was not all that bright. But I tell you that Barrie Unsworth was bright enough to know that, coming up to the election, the biggest albatross around the Labor It is government's neck in 1988 was none other than Laurie Brereton. What did he do? Mr Downer-He sacked him.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: Unknown
text: He demoted him and sacked him, and that is exactly what the Prime Minister here in the Commonwealth parliament should be doing to the same man. The situation surrounding the minister's carriage of his ministerial responsibilities here in this parliament are equal to or worse than they were back in 1988 when Barrie Unsworth got rid of him. When Barrie Unsworth got rid of him it was too late, the damage was done. I think you will find that, unless this minister is prepared to have his head put on the plate, what the Minister for Transport did to Barrie Unsworth in 1988 is what he is going to do to Bob Carr in 1995. You just watch. There has been a lot of controversy surrounding the Minister for Transport. He is a bit like a lightning rod for attracting controversy. Whether it be in the portfolio of industrial relations, whether it be his handling of the third runway controversy and all of the surrounding noise problems in Sydney, whether it be the handling of ANL or, indeed, the handling of aviation safety, this minister has got himself into hot water-on each and every one of those issues. Today in the House we saw how the minister and his colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) were trying to deal with the problem of ANL. Many of us would have watched the 7.30 Report last night to see the former chairman of ANL, Bill Bolitho, go on national television and make some very serious accusations about the way in which this minister has carried out his ministerial responsibilities as far as the privatisation and sale of ANL are concerned. Mr Bill Bolitho, a man whose reputation is unsullied throughout the business community and who is probably the most respected person in the Australian shipping industry today, went on national television and made some extraordinary and serious accusations about the propriety of the way in which this minister has carried out the sale and privatisation process of ANL. During this week, we also saw the Auditor General's report being tabled in the Senate. What did the Auditor-General's report tell us? It told us three things. Firstly, it drew some very serious questions about the process by which the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers report on, and valuation of, ANL was undertaken. The importance of that report on, and valuation of, ANL is that the Minister for Transport based all of his actions surrounding his decisions with ANL on that report. Yet the Auditor-General, in his report tabled in this parliament during the week, draws into question the whole process of the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers valuation mechanism for the ANL. That is the first thing the report tells us. Secondly, the Auditor-General in his report makes the point that he has been very concerned about certain public officials making public utterances which have the potential to damage the value of ANL. We heard earlier today the Minister for Finance trying to tell us that this was not directed in any way at the Minister for Transport. Yet the Minister for Transport got up here a little while later and said that the only thing in the Auditor General's report he was worrying about was the gratuitous advice that had been levelled at him. Do you know what the Auditor-General was saying? The Auditor-General was saying that the big mouth of the Minister for Transport has cost this country tens of millions of dollars. Why? Because he gave a press conference on national television and said, 'You could not give ANL away.' We are in the business of trying to sell ANL. It is a business that is worth many millions of dollars. Yet this man went out and said that we could not give it away. In the process of doing that, he damaged the value of that business irreparably. That is the second thing the Auditor General's report tells us. In addition to that, the Auditor-General attached an addendum to his report-a rather unusual thing for him to do. It is a letter from the Secretary to the Department of Financeno doubt at the instruction of the Minister for Finance-requesting that the Auditor-General alter some key paragraphs in his report which are implicitly critical of the comments of the Minister for Transport about the value of ANL. That is what this letter is all about. It was unusual for the Auditor-General to do that-but necessary because he felt that, unless he made it quite clear that an attempt had been made to try to whitewash this report, people would not note the gravity of the situation surrounding this whole process of trying to sell ANL. The net result of this is that it has cost us a lot of money.. So far it has cost us $20 million to fix up the strike of the Maritime Union of Australia which was created by this gentleman in the process of his handling of ANL. In addition to that, it will cost us more. We have already heard that next year we will have to have written into the budget an extra $50 million to try to keep this business that this man has now taken full charge of afloat for another 12 months. We also see that it will cost us money because of the big mouth this man has got. The views he has expressed, which he thinks are important, such as that ANL could not be given away, have cost the taxpayers of Australia a tremendous amount of money. As I said, Bill Bolitho made some extraordinary claims on the television last night. Over the last few weeks, we have also had several articles written by Laura Tingle. The minister referred to them in his comments today in question time. Those articles by Laura Tingle go to the whole propriety of this government. They refer to a secret loan of $22.4 million given by the company that this minister claims is bankrupt and that you could not give away: to the company that was buying ANL's shares in Australian Stevedores. Yet today we heard the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Transport saying, 'This was not a loan; this was just a deferred payment. It was exactly the same deal that Howard Smith had with Jamison Equity when it sold its 25 per cent shareholding in Australian Stevedores.' Let me tell you that it was not the same deal and the minister knows that. In fact, he knows it very well. The Australian Stevedores shares that Howard Smith owned were not handed over straight away to Jamison Equity. It did not lend Jamison Equity the money. This government with its secret deal, which Laura Tingle has highlighted to us, actually gave a $22.4 million loan to Jamison Equity, handed over all the shares and gave the seat on the board of Australian Stevedores that ANL had directly to Jamison Equity. None of this was done by Howard Smith. There is a clear and distinct difference. This government would have us believe that the deal that it did with Jamison Equity was exactly the same deal that Howard Smith did. It was not. Last night I had dinner with some people who were present at the finalisation of the sale of the Australian Stevedores shares to Jamison Equity. They told me that everything Laura Tingle wrote in that article is as.olutely and utterly true. That makes some of things that this minister and the Minister for Finance have said over the last few days quite wrong. So we have these quite reasonable and proper concerns about the propriety of this government and the administration by this minister of his ministerial responsibilities. These are serious concerns. If the Prime Minister does not deal with these sorts of concerns, Australia's taxpayers will continue to lose many millions of dollars due to the incompetence of this man. In the process of trying to cover up his actions over ANL, the ininister has worn the tag that he justly deserves and that is of being the champion deceiver. This man is the champion deceiver. We heard the term used in this House earlier this week, but nobody better fits the term of champion deceiver than the Minister for Transport. When talking about the champion deceiver, let us look at the third runway and the problems that Sydneysiders are experiencing at the present time. We have heard from this minister that we cannot have the east-west runway up and running again because it would be unsafe. Do you know the reason why the east-west runway is not going to be up and running again? It is not because it is unsafe. It has nothing to do with that at all. If we go back to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 23 March 1989 we find a detailed account of how the government changed its mind about the third runway; and who was responsible for changing the government's mind about the third runway. The article, which was written by Geoff Kitney, makes interesting reading. It states: After looking at various configurations, Mr Keating proposed that the new north-south runway be fully operational from both directions and the old east-west runway be virtually made redundant. The effect of this change was dramatic. That is the reason why the east-west runway is not being opened now. The significance of that is that the 10,000 people who rallied at Leichhardt Oval last Saturday expressing their concerns about the problems of noise over Sydney due to the opening of the third runway are saying that one of the best solutions to the problem is to open the east-west runway. We are not going to get it opened because the Prime Minister was the man who directed that it be closed. The reason why it was closed was explained further on in the same article. It states: The political significance of Mr Keating's proposal was that the noise impact on the most marginal Labor seats of Barton (1.1 per cent) and St George (3.7 per cent) would be greatly reduced, while the areas where noise would increase would be the safest Labor seats-Sydney (20 per cent) and Grayndler (10 per cent). We now know why we have all these problems over Sydney with the third runway. It has nothing to do with the east-west runway operating simultaneously with the other two north-south runways being unsafe. It is all about grubby politics-politics designed to advantage nobody else but the Labor Party. The man responsible for it is the Prime Minister. But the man who is covering for him, the champion deceiver, is going around trying to convince us that we cannot have this east-west runway up and running because it would be unsafe. This is yet another example of the way in which this minister is not honestly and properly administering his portfolio responsibilities. Another thing that earns him the title of champion deceiver is the meeting he held with some local government officials from Marrickville Council on 28 July this year. The minister was in possession of a report which indicated that the local government officials who were meeting with him had seriously underestimated the degree of noise they would experience as a result of the opening of the third runway. This minister, according to those officials, did not tell them about that report. He kept that report secret. That report only saw the light of day when it was subpoenaed to be heard in the Federal Court hearings of November of this year. That is the reason that report became public. That is another clear example of the way this minister has deceived the people of Sydney over the noise levels they would experience as a result of the third runway being up and running. Another thing that earns this minister the title of being incompetent is that he opened the third runway months ahead of the rest of the facilities at Sydney airport being ready. You have to ask yourself: why did the minister open the third runway months before the new air traffic control tower would be open? Why did he open it 12 months in advance of the new radar system being able to be used? That is a very good question. The net result of that is that 91 per cent all flights going into Sydney airport are currently delayed. Ansett experienced up to 30,000 complaints from travellers in one particular day. The capacity oJ Sydney airport has been reduced from 64 aircraft movements pe- hour to 50 craft movements per hour. We have gone out and spent over $200 million building the third runway, we have opened it, because this man decided to do it, months in advance of the rest of the facilities being available for use and the net result is the creation of an enormous mess at Sydney airport. Indeed, Peter Young, representative of Ansett Airlines, said yesterday that the airport infrastructure in Australia is completely broken at this moment. In the process of breaking it, this minister has destroyed the lives of hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders over the last few weeks because he has not been prepared to deal properly with the issue of noise levels for Sydney siders. The reason is that his Prime Minister is the man who made the decision to close the east-west runway for grubby, political purposes. That is why those people are suffering at this time. That is why the opposition moves this censure motion against the Minister for Transport. In relation to ANL, he carried out those actions of sacking the board of ANL, of appointing his old mate Neville Wran to run the ANt board for the next six months and of calling ANL a business that路 you could not give away. We know that all of that was done for grubby, political purposes-because of the ALP that was coming up in September. We now know the truth of the situation as to why Sydney siders are living a complete hell of a life at the present time. It is because of this路 government's grubby, political deals for their own grubby, political ends to try to win votes and seats in Sydney. We now know the reason. It is all due to this minister's incompetence and his inability to properly carry out his ministerial responsibilities. That is why this man should go. That is why this man was nicknamed years ago by the Prime Minister as Dangerman. That is why, if he is not careful, he will become the of albatross around the Keating government's neck, like he was the albatross around the Unsworth government's neck all those years ago.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: Is the motion seconded? Mr Connolly-I second the路 motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: Unknown
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (4.35 p.m.)-I have seen some censure motions in the 25 years I have spent in public office-I have seen plenty of them-but I have never seen a weaker one than the one we have seen here this afternoon, moved by the member for Hume (Mr Sharp). A censure motion is supposed to be the most serious thing that can happen in the parliament. A censure motion is a debate in respect of charges that should go to the very integrity of the minister being challenged. What did we see in the contribution from the honourable member? Not a single significant charge, but a lot of mealy-mouthed rubbish and recycled press releases-of course, he is the king of the press releases-but nothing to sustain the charge that I should be censured by this House. Having said that, I take the opportunity provided to me for the next 15 minutes to deal with some of the issues that have been discussed here this afternoon. I deal particularly with this question of Australian National Line and the actions of the cabinet, given effect to by me, in respect of its financial circumstance. As I have said to the House, the position of ANL was one causing us grave concern. We acted decisively and properly in order to make sure that taxpayers' interests were protected. We acted to make sure that ANL did not continue to haemorrhage to the average tune of $24 million per year-year in and year out. Indeed, the whole of the process I have instituted on behalf of the cabinet has been aimed at protecting taxpayers' interests, just as was the decision to sell the 25 per cent share in Australian Stevedores, which has been referred to by the honourable member this afternoon. It was a decision taken in order to eliminate a potential liability, which the trade union movement was trying to force us into, to spend $280 million and nationalise the greatest stevedoring company in Australia. I have indicated to the House before the nature of the problems facing ANL, but I recount them. The fact is that the due diligence report this year from Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers, in no way cut down by the Auditor-General, indicates that ANL over-estimated its profit forecasts, year in and year out. In fact, in September 1990 the advice of the board of ANL to the government was that its shipping terminals and business would earn it $32 million. They lost ANL $5.3 million. The same month, June 1991, the board was forecasting to the government that everything would be okay and that it was going to make $21.4 million in its shipping and terminal businesses. That was its projected profit for the next year. The result was a dismal loss of $26 million recorded by June of 1992-a turnaround of $47 million in 12 months. What was happening during this process? The board of ANL, chaired by Mr Bolitho, was indicating that everything was going to be all right, that everything was going to come up roses in the garden. In fact, it is worth recounting that Mr Bolitho, in his press release of 16 December 1993, claimed that ANL as a whole would at least break even in 1993-94. The result for 1993-94 will be somewhere between a $10 million and $20 million loss, the same sort of loss that it has sustained year in and year out. It was only in February of this year that ANL went on the public record in the Australian saying that the company could expect solid profits for the next few years. We now know, as a result of the work of Salomon Brothers and price Waterhouse, the very dismal state of that business. It was only six months after that that the company itself was coming to us saying that it wanted to draw down its promissory note, saying that it did not have sufficient funds to pay its bills. The fact is that ANL has only survived so long by selling assets. This is the bottom line. Mr Bolitho went on television last night-the member for Hume has relied on him for some of his comments-'-and talked about profitability. My challenge is: what profitability? We have not seen profitability for years. If you take out the selling of a large part of its fleet-it has already sold most of its fleetand you take .out the sale of its future income stream, another little trick aimed at keeping the company afloat, then you find that the figures for ANL are even more appalling. These sales are not revealed in those figures of an average $24 million a year loss that I have given, but in the process ANL has flogged off most of the fleet. ANL has gone further than that. It has sold the cash flow in respect of some remaining elements of the fleet. If you take out those extras, you find that ANL has pranged not just for the last four years but for six of the last seven years. When I come along, in concert with the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), and say that we are bringing in outside experts and that a due diligence study will be carried out, and when that due diligence study reveals the true state and nature of ANL and the government acts decisively, you have the hide to criticise us. Even then, as I have revealed in the House today, you could not get your act together. The shadow minister for privatisation is saying one thing and the shadow minister for transport is saying another. One is saying 'liquidate' in respect of ANL; the other is saying 'prop up'. Where do you get off? You talk about credibility. You have no credibility on this matter. The government was properly concerned about ANL in terms of the approach of the board of directors. It needs to be remembered that Mr Bolitho was there for 10 years. During that whole lO-year period, the company paid $20.7 million in dividends to the government. I repeat: in the whole of the 10 year-period, the government got $20.7 million. During that time, the government pumped $160.5 million into the company in debt forgiveness or equity injection. During that period, the taxpayer went down the gurgle hole to the tune of $140 million. Someone had to do something about that situation. It was not just that money that had been lost. The current debt of ANL sits in the books at $180 million. That $180 million has to be picked up at the end of the day by the taxpayer. The government acted decisively and did something about that, and you have the hide to come into this lIouse and challenge us in this censure motion against me. We have done the right and courageous thing in regard to ANL-the sort of thing that you would never do and never did during the many years that you had the carriage and control of ANL from 1975 to 1983. You left ANL in 1983 in the most appalling condition, which was why we had to pump $160.5 million of equity injection into it. You avoided your responsibility for ANL in the most scandalous manner. For you to have the hide to come in here and challenge us when we have done the right thing in respect of this matter really defies credulity. I have indicated to the House that, even were we to eliminate that $180 million of debt, the company would still be losing money month after month. Of course ANL needs restructuring, and that is exactly what this government is committed to. This afternoon there have been a number of-I cannot call them charges because there were no charges levelled against me

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: Unknown
text: Wet lettuce.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: Unknown
text: Yes, wet lettuce.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: Unknown
text: There were 10 wet lettuce leaves.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: Unknown
text: I think there were only three or four wet lettuce leaves that were flung across the chamber at me, and one concerned Bill Bolitho. At least Bill, for all his problems, had the decency to go on the radio this morning and say, 'I have a king sized chip on my shoulder. 'That I can understand. I know how he feels. If you had been associated with something for 10 years, if you had put your life's work into it and you had been asked by the minister of the day, for very good reason, to stand down, of course you would have a chip on your shoulder. The opposition should not be relying on Bill Bolitho, the man with the chip on his shoulder, as a basis for any censure motion against me. Yet opposition members come in here saying that we have lost tens of millions of dollars as a result of my saying, 'You could not give ANL away' - which was a pretty fair remark---on the day that I announced we were withdrawing it from sale. In the papers this morning, ANZDL indicated that it wants to bid for ANL. It said that the issue of its reputation will have lio bearing whatsoever on what price it pays. The company will base its price, as will all the bidders, on the basis of the worth of the company. It will have the assistance of a very good due diligence procedure carried out independently by Price Waterhouse and Salomons to assist it. I make no bones about the matter: I hope that we can see ANL privatised. I sincerely hope that the trade union movement can take a stake in that privatisation. I hope that we can see ANL recover from its parlous state and be reborn. It will be a different sort of line, but that is the approach the government has taken. We are doing something aboQt it. We are doing the sorts of things that you would never do. The next wet lettuce that came across the table was the Laura Tingle charge. Now there are four of them in the cart. There is Laura Tingle, Mr Dempster, who is formerly from the 7.30 Report, the shadow minister for privatisation and the shadow minister for transport, all of whom are saying that there is something in this charge. The directorsof ANL negotiated a sale-a very favourable outcome from the government's point of view-to stop us being reduced to a minority shareholding. They secured $28 million. Because that afternoon they could come up with only 20 per cent by way of a deposit and they were given 90 days to settle-that is a deferred settlement-that is characterised as the basis of a censure motion against me. This was a standard commercial arrangement entered into by the directors of ANL and Malcolm Turnbull, who was the negotiator on behalf of the government, yet in some way that is....supposed to represent the basis a censure motion. What an absolute wet lettuce. It is characterised here as a loan. No money changed hands; it was a deferred settlement. Yet there is something wrong with it! What a load of nonsense. The third damp lettuce concerned the third runway. Opposition members asked why the east-west runway cannot be opened. The attempt to charge the Prime Minister of Australia as the person responsible for airport noise in Sydney is about as sincere as John Fahey's charge that all of this was done to assist Bob Carr, whose electorate is on the east-west corridor. Who is it coming from? In the case of John Fahey, it is coming from a man who less than a year ago called for 24hour access in and out of Kingsford Smith airport. It is coming from the colleagues of John Fahey sitting opposite here. In the runup to the last election, we all remember the performances of the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) when they said that there should be a removal of the curfew. Yet they expect there to be some credibility in this charge that somehow or other the Prime Minister is responsible for the noise. The majority of people in Sydney are much better off. That does not mean that this government does not take with absolute seriousness the plight of those people who are worse off. It is for that very reason that we are committed to restricting the flight paths. It is for that very reason that we are committed to very substantial penalties against people who fly outside those flight paths. It is for that very reason that we want to bring forward the sound amelioration program so that we can treat the worse affected areas. It is for that very reason that we want the new operational requirements at Kingsford Smith to make sure that the minimum number of people are exposed to noise. Yet you come in here today and talk about opening up the third runway. What you are doing is arguing for more planes into Kingsford Smith, not for jets on the east-west runway. You know that you cannot do that. You are arguing the position of Hazelton Airlines and the position of Graeme MCMahon of of Ansett. You think that, if all of the propeller planes take off and land to and from the east, you will be able to put more jets on the north-south axis. You know full well that jets cannot take off on the new parallel runway. In the view of those opposite, that means that five, 10 or 15 more jets per hour can take off when the conditions would mean take-offs to the north across that corridor of people directly under the flight path to the north. That is what you are really about. You are using this to undermine the micro-economic reasons for the development of Badgerys Creek; a second airport that can meet the demands of Sydney and can provide the hubbing arrangements to adequately cater for all of the flights that are currently being demanded. I have told you today that the increase in flights is between 48 and 50 per cent only in the last nine months. That was the third damp lettuce. No-one should be deceived by any of this, least of all the poor individuals who are suffering at the moment from noise exposure on the north-south runway. You are attempting to dupe and deceive them by saying that their lot can be made better by opening the east-west runway to propeller planes, knowing all the time that more and more jets will be taking off over the top of them. The member for Hume finished up by saying that it was an enormous mess. I am proud that this government is tackling all of these issues vigorously-whether they be ANL, aircraft safety, the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the restructure of the Civil Aviation Authority or the measures that will be discussed by cabinet tomorrow-to guarantee that we have the airport that Sydney needs and the maximum protection for people. We reject utterly this censure motion as being a total waste of the parliament's time. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: Unknown
text: Not one single federal member bothered to tum up--or maybe I should say that they were not game enough to tum up. Had the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), who has just spoken, been there he would have noted, among other things, the intention of people to lynch him. They believe-and rightly s()--'-that, as the minister, he has to .-arry the responsibility for the total disruption to the lifestyle of thousands upon thousands of Sydney residents. One of them made the point, which I thought was rather cryptic, that Mr Brereton's street should be made runway No.4. More recently than that, last Saturday at Leichhardt Oval, 10;000 people came out on this issue. Yes, it is serious. Yes, it is important. Yes, it does affect the lives of these people. The one characteristic that brought those people together was not just noise and its clear physical and psychological effect upon them and their families, but the firm belief that they have been misled by this government that for so long has carried out, under the protection of silence, a series of activities which were ultimately going to cause massive losses to the character of their lifestyle, to the value of their homes-to their very sanity. When we heard those people speaking at those public meetings, we heard from the heart what ordinary people are suffering because of the circumstances over which they have absolutely no control. It is fine for the minister to tell us why the east-west runway cannot be reopened. It is fine for him to protect himself on the grounds that the CAA says that there are safety reasons. Of course, safety in aviation is of fundamental importance. But the sad fact of the matter is that there are political considerations in this area. The honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson), who is in the chamber here today, knows that she has been sacrificed. S'he knows that she is the loser of this outcome, and she knows that the government has made a decision that Barton, St George, Sydney and Grayndler are more important than the seat of Lowe. Let me assure her of one thing: we are on her sideThe boundaries of this problem do not stop at the Parramatta River. This problem goes well beyond that-well over Lane Cove, well over Hunters Hill and right to the very edge of Kuring-gai National Park. Even the animals in the park are complaining. We were not told about this. My constituents were not told. People in Chatswood were not told. People up in Wahroonga and Turramurra were not told. I had an engineer do a survey this week in west Pymble, and he picked up 88 decibels of sound. It might be worth members knowing that on the race track those very noisy sports cars are not allowed to go over 100 decibels. So when you are talking about 88 decibels in a valley-that is where this person did the test-you can see easily what the effect of noise is on the people who are caught in this environment. Geography has them caught, and the sound reverberates through their homes and through their lives. Version 6 of the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport noise management plan was issued in March 1994. When you go through this document, you find these interesting tables outlining the effect that the noise would have on people. It talks about the aircraft noise effect on people by the year 2010. It almost puts you into that somnolent sense that it is over the hill, far away; that it is not really going to be an issue for the people of today. But it is a problem for the people of today; it is a very real problem on a daily basis. The questions asked and the analysis which was carried out was very interesting. Was it going to affect conversation, watching TV or listening to radio or music? Would sleep be disturbed by noise? There is an analysis of the number of people who would be affected by the noise: 26,800 would be seriously affected; 127,700 would be moderately affected; 100,000 people would have their conversation disturbed; and 135,300 would be disturbed whilst watching TV or listening to radio. I love the preciseness of these figures. A mere 59,000 people would have their sleep disturbed. The document claims that the total number of people in that group in the population who would be affected by the airport is 417,600 people. My mathematics may not be marvellous but it seems to me that, on the basis of this survey, every single person has been affected to a significant degree by the noise generated by this airport. That survey was done on the basis of the anticipated problems in the year 2010. We have been told by the minister today that, in this year alone, the use of Mascot airport has gone up by over 50 per cent in those peak periods. If the increase is 50 per cent in one year, what is it going to be by the year 201O? The people of Sydney demand answers to these problems. They believe, and rightly so, that this analysis which apparently took place was either wrong or was organised in such a way that people were never told the truth. I, like many other members in this House who have been affected by this problem, have received numerous letters from constituents who make these points. They ask us to be their voice in this House. They ask us to say to the government, 'You are ruining our lives. Why did you do this to us and why didn't you give us a fair warning?' Mr K. Lane of Turramurra wrote: Before the runway opened we had only 5-10 planes going over our house a week. Now it is about 80 a day. A person in St Ives wrote: The chief culprits are the 747s ... at times, they are only a few hundred metres overhead (despite the airport being some IOkms away from us) ... The interesting thing is that this analysis done by the government never at any stage suggested that the problems of the airport were going to go beyond a clearly defined area, the northern boundary of which would be the Parramatta River. Not one of the maps provided by the authority, by the government, by the minister, by his department, shows a single indicator of any noise problems north of the Parramatta River or the Lane Cove River. Yet the fundamental fact of the matter is that those figures of the number of people affected by sound are absolutely flawed. The real figure is probably twice that. I think we have a right to know why that is so. Why were those figures so wrong? Why was that analysis so wrong? Why were people not told? Why was this whole exercise carried through with such a degree of secrecy, in an underhand way? Perhaps the most poignant statement. I heard at the public meeting at Petersham Town Hall came from a young girl called Amanda. She was quoted on AM of Wednesday, 30 November as saying: My name is Amanda, and I come from Sydenham, and us kids at school, we can hardly hear what the teachers are saying from these planes because every two minutes, our teachers have to stop what they're saying, and then when us kids have more ideas in our heads, when one of the planes go, every single idea goes out of their heads. Time after time, person after person came forward at that meeting making the point of how disastrous the effect had been on their living capacity, on the ability of their children to go to school. Yet we have been told by this government, 'Don't worry. We are going to buy thousands of houses. We are going to take over the land. We are going to close it all down. We are going to organise the schools and give them a decent system so they will not get the sound effects.' On behalf of those hundreds of thousands of people, I ask the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) who is at the table and Minister Brereton, who is no longer here for this debate, that fundamental question: why did you not sort this mess out before you ruined the lives of these people? That is what they want to know. If you had all the answers-and we are still looking for them; that is why we are having this debate today-why did you not put the insulation into these homes? Why did you not insulate those schools? Why should the children in those suburbs suffer so grievously? Why should the results from their examinations be less than they ought to be? Why should their lives be ruined because of the short-term nature of this government's political decision making process? I gave out forms at that meeting and asked people to fill them in, to give them the opportunity to see precisely what the situation was. I got some very interesting responses, one from a Mr Antonios Samaras of Newington Street, Marrickville. He sent me two pages. The horrifying thing is that he has planes flying over his house on average about one every four minutes. Just imagine it-one every four minutes! How could you conceivably live under conditions like that? I seek permission of the House to table this material so that people can see what the realities are and what they mean to ordinary people.
