text: We currently anticipate that we will sit on Friday. Also, we will probably suspend the closure rule and sit late tomorrow. The rate of business coming back from the Senate is still slow, and I would expect that to carry us through. However, we are currently looking at the possibility of doing the valedictories tomorrow, as I know that is a matter of concern to the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). We would do that, in all probability, sometime after what would be likely to be a dinner break tomorrow. NA Defending Australia: Defence White Paper 1994  Science and Personnel)-by leave-The world has changed dramatically since the Australian government published its last defence white paper in 1987. We knew then that we were living in a dynamic era, but the nature and the pace of the changes which have since taken place were quite unforeseeable. Of all the changes, the most significant has been the collapse of the Soviet Union. This was a massively important event, which fundamentally changed the global security environment. Almost overnight, the east-west stand-off, which dominated international strategic affairs for 50 years, was no more. No part of the globe was unaffected by this radical changecertainly not Asia and the Pacific. This historic geo-strategic change has been accompanied in the Asia-Pacific region by continued and rapid economic growth. Potentially, this too has enormous long-term consequences for strategic relationships and security in the region. The government's 1994 defence white paper, Defending Australia, addresses the long-term consequences of these major changes for our defence policy. Defending Australia looks ahead 15 years to provide broad guidance for defence policy making and for the force structure and capability decisions we will have to make. It provides the framework for developing our defence policy through the next decade. Defending Australia is a substantial and complex document. Today I will simply highlight some of the underlying thinking and key themes. Our starting point is the conviction that Australia must maintain the capability to defend itself against armed attack. Despite all the hopes and aspirations we share for reducing the chances of conflict since the end of the Cold War, military force is still an important element in international affairs, and will remain so. That is a fact of life, regrettablybut a fact nevertheless. It is also a fact that, while we will do all we can to avoid the use of force ourselves, ultimately, armed force can only be resisted by armed force. We must, therefore, continue to be sure that we can defeat an armed attack on our territory. We have a continent of our own to defend, and a unique set of national interests. We must be self-reliant, with the capabilities to provide for our defence without relying on the combat forces of other countries. The key judgment in this white paper is that fundamental changes in strategic affairs, both globally and within our region, will make Australia's strategic environment more demanding over the next 15 years. The threat of global war has all but disappeared, but so has the predictable shape which the Cold War imposed on strategic affairs throughout Asia and the Pacific. In its place, a new, more fluid and more complex strategic pattern will emerge. Security in the region will be shaped by continued high levels of economic growth. The sustained expansion in the economies of most countries is bringing enormous social and economic benefits. It is also increasing the capacity of many countries to modernise and develop their armed forces, and to become more confident and self-reliant in their security. The military capabilities of our regional neighbours are improving, especially through the introduction of higher technology systems. We will also see a growing capacity to sustain and operate these systems. Australia looks to the future of this region with confidence, and with a strong awareness of the opportunities which Asia offers for our own future. In looking to our long-term security, we will take a positive approach the region, and to the international defence policies and relationships which support defence interests. Nevertheless, prudence requires that we maintain the capabilities ensure our defence self-reliance. Australia's defence policy, as spelt out this white paper, recognises our responsibility to help shape our security environment. This requires that we engage closely with our region on strategic issues; that our alliances with the United States and New Zealand; and that we contribute effectively to multinational security efforts. Just as Australia's prosperity is strengthened by our economic integration with Asia, so our security will be enhanced by closer strategic engagement. Australia has an active role to play in the evolution of a secure regional environment which reflects our needs and interests, and makes armed attack on this country less likely. The way we seek to influence this environpaper ment will need to eV,olve as strategic circummeasure. stances change. The task will become more challenging as our security environment becomes more complex and more demanding. We will strengthen our bilateral defence relationships, and actively pursue multilateral approaches to security in the region. particular, we will foster an accurate underensure standing of Australia's strategic interests security concerns. In tum, we will ensure that we understand the perceptions, concerns <;:apabilities of our neighbours. , At the same time, our alliance with the United States will continue to be a key element of our defence policy. We will work with the United States to ensure that the alliance continues to meet the needs of both parties-both in a strategic sense and in the practical benefits it delivers. We will continue to give strong support to the United Nations and other multinational endeavours which promote global security. An effective United Nations can help to make war less likely throughout the world by mobilising international action against aggression. Our support for the United Nations to therefore makes a direct contribution to our security. It is also through the United Nations our machinery that the government is able to respond effectively to humanitarian crises, to such as those in Rwanda and Somalia. Important as these commitments are, we do not structure the Australian Defence Force for in them. The ADF has clearly demonstrated that its force structure and readiness levels are sufficient to undertake United Nations tasks, provided the defence budget is supplemented we maintain for major contributions. We will continue to examine each multinational operation on its merits, and evaluate each contribution in terms of our national objectives. Effective arms control measures also contribute directly to Australia's security. Therefore, defence will continue to support the government's policy objectives in relation to global regimes for arms control. We are also strongly committed to transparency in defence planning in order to build trust and reduce suspicion, especially within our own region. The publication of this white is in itself an important trust building While the government will continue its active pursuit of Australia's international defence interests in these ways, the key message of Defending Australia is that our highest defence priority will continue to be to In build, maintain and support forces which we can defeat any armed attack against and Australia. We do not believe that any country has an intention to use force against Australia. and We have no disputes with other countries which might be expected to give rise to the use of force, and there is also no reason to expect one to develop. However, disputes can arise and intentions can change relatively quickly. Because military capabilities take many years to develop, it follows that we plan on the basis of capabilities and not threats. Let me repeat that: we plan on the basis of capabilities, not threats. No country has the capability to seize and hold major territory on our continent. SignifiDefence cantly, we believe that no country plans to develop such forces. To do so would require a very large effort, and we would expect to have substantial warning of any such development. However, the capabilities available to mount lesser levels of attack on Australia grow over the next 15 years. Such attacks could be very damaging to Australia, and could arise with relatively little warning. The key challenge for defence capability planning will be to adapt to the greater demands posed by increasing military capabilities in such short-warning conflict. We will continue to use the most costeffective means to ensure our security. Our planning will exploit Australia's geographic advantages, technological capabilities and wider national resources to ensure we can defend this country. This means giving clear priority to the naval and air capabilities needed to deny our approaches to an adversary. We must recognise, however, that the development of military technology poses new challenges. Over the longer term, we will need to be more selective about those military capabilities in which we must maintain our technological advantage. We will also use our defence capabilities more efficiently. All elements of the Australian Defence Force will work closely together as an integrated force and make the best possible use of their equipment and facilities. Our ability to draw on wider national resources will grow in importance. We will seek to integrate a range of civil assets and expertise into our defence effort order to sustain our capabilities more efficiently. This will provide a wider base for developing and supporting high-technology systems. The effective use of our geographical and technological advantages, backed by the diverse strengths of our national support base, will give Australia a defence posture of greater depth and resilience. From this key objective flow the main defence priorities set out in Defending Australia. I want to highlight three today. Firstly, high priority will be given to the skilled people we need in the ADF. The Australian Force's tradition of excellence is based on the professionalism of its people. Our deployments to the Gulf War, Namibia, Cambodia, Somalia, Rwanda and elsewhere have demonstrated this beyond question. We - hould also acknowledge the great body of will unsung work which our forces do every day to ensure they retain the necessary levels of proficiency and preparedness. The ADF will remain fundamentally dependent on the quality of its people. It is easy to overlook some of the special demands military life places on our people and their families. We must therefore ensure that they receive adequate recognition. While personnel numbers will not increase over the next 15 years, the demands placed on our people by new technology will. Recruiting and retaining high-calibre people in the Defence Force presents long-term challenges. Over time, we will increase community understanding of defence and encourage greater recognition路 of the career opportunities that military service provides. In addition, a路 wide ranging defence review of the principles which underpin ADF personnel policies and procedures has begun and will be completed next year. Reserves too have a long and proud tradition of service in peace and war. The white paper makes clear that reserves now have specific roles in our operational elements. They form a fundamental part of our total force and provide important links between the Defence Force and the wider community. Changes in reserve training are being in implemented, and a detailed structural review of the army reserve will be carried out next year. This will ensure that our reserves are better equipped, and that their training standards are more closely aligned to those of regular members. Secondly, the government will emphasise investment in high-technology capabilities which increase our security. We are moving ahead with plans to procure airborne early warning and control aircraft, and we will replace the Macchi lead-in fighters and our ageing transport aircraft. We will also proceed with new command, control, communications and intelligence networks, new helicopters for our ANZAC frigates, new minehunters and new vehicles for the land force. Our six new Collins class submarines, due to come on line in the next few years, will be the most capable, conventional submarines in the world. They are sufficient to meet our forecast needs. We will, however, review the need for additional submarines in the context of the first five-year defence budget in 1996-97. Our existing Leopard tank fleet will meet our needs until at least 2010. Therefore, we will not take up the recent offer to purchase newer Leopards because this would not be cost-effective. Defence capability development is not just based on acquiring new equipment. In a number of cases, we have the opportunity to enhance our capabilities by upgrading existing equipment and systems. For instance, we will ensure our FA18 Hornet fighter aircraft remain highly effective well into the next century by upgrading their sensors, electronic countermeasures and weapons. We will also undertake major upgrades of Australia's FFG frigates, M113 tracked armoured vehicles, and P3C maritime patrol aircraft. In our land force, the scope of efficiencies programmed by army will free up the personnel and resources necessary to raise a fifth infantry battalion. This battalion will be formed over the next three to four years. Thirdly, the government will continue to pursue a more effective partnership between Defence and Australian industry. This is essential to strengthen defence self-reliance over the long term. We look to internationally competitive industries in Australia and New Zealand to supply, maintain and adapt our high-technology defence equipment. We also look to industry to design and manufacture equipment suited to our unique needs. To encourage and assist our industries to develop the capabilities Defence needs, we have identified a number of changes to the way Defence works with industry. Defence will rely more on the strengths of the commercial sector. We will identify further opportunities for the commercial support program and help industry to acquire more defence related intellectual property. In addition, we will encourage greater local industrial research and development and, within carefully enforced guidelines, encourage increased international materiel cooperation and defence exports. Our emphasis on a strong partnership with industry will be complemented by the efficient use of Australian defence science and technology to help develop and support our most important defence capabilities. More broadly, successful national defence requires the closest possible links between Defence and the wider Australian community. This partnership ensures that vital support is available for our defence in peace and in conflict. It also provides "major benefits to the Australian community through the ADF's activities in areas such as disaster relief, bushfire fighting, search and rescue, and counter-terrorist support. Finally, I want to address the issue of resources. National defence can never be done 'on the cheap' . More'complex and demanding strategic circumstances will place even greater pressure on our defence budget. We cannot escape that. It is often assumed that by reducing uniformed personnel numbers we reduce our defence capabilities. This is not the case. Defence has recently achieved major reforms which have reduced personnel numbers and costs significantly without reducing capabilities. Personnel costs have dropped from 60 per cent of the defence budget 20 years ago to under 40 per cent today. The government will continue to seek defence reforms and efficiencies. Nonetheless, we recognise that these savings cannot accommodate all the additional pressures on the defence budget over coming years. Those pressures will arise from the need to meet higher labour costs as ADF skill requirements rise and to sustain the operations needed to keep our capabilities highly effective. At the same time, we must invest in major new equipment and facilities because continual development is essential to maintain our relative level of capability. The government is determined to sustain defence funding. A long-term commitment is December 1994. fundamental when capabilities take decades to develop and introduce. We will provide stability and predictability which is so importgovernment's ant to the development and management of long-term projects and activities. For the next few years defence expenditure at current programmed levels will enable the plans and projects outlined in Defending Australia to proceed. Beyond that, modest increases will be needed to meet the demands of an increasingly complex defence environinterested ment. The government has considered these issues carefully and responsibly, and is committed to sustaining defence spending at approxiportfolio mately two per cent of GDP. The government has also decided that, from 1996-97, it will provide defence with a five-year budget commitment. This is a historic commitment. It is a decision which will provide an assured basis for long-term planning. This will allow more efficient development of defence bilities, more effective procurement from industry and better personnel planning and management. Many areas in Australia contribute to our defence objectives. Defence, in tum, contrifacto butes to other national interests. This includes Australia's international security interests, which ryquire very close integration of govworld affairs. ernment policies and approaches. The relationship between the Departments of Defence, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Foreign Affairs in these areas is especially strong and contrasts markedly with the proach of some 10 years ago. Our commitsions ment to this integrated approach was reflected in the close consultation which occurred during preparation of this white paper. The decisions we make on crucial resource and other issues over the next few years will shape Australia's defences well into the next century. The government is determined that, in the coming decades, our adaptable, versatile and self-reliant defence effort will effectively safeguard our country. I present the following papers: Defending Australia: Defence White Paper 1994-Ministerial Statement and Paper, 7

text: by leave-I welthe come the opportunity to respond to the 1994 defence white paper. I do so in my capacity as the opposition defence spokesman representative in the lower house. I endorse the excellent contribution to the debate about Australia's defence policy made by my colleague the shadow minister for real defence, Senator Jocelyn Newman, in the Senate this week. I also commend to those in the debate the remarks of my coalition colleagues in the Senate, particularly those of Senator MACGIBBON. I am pleased to have the opportunity to make a few remarks. I held the defence on behalf of the coalition for some time; which sharpened my interest in defence policy matters. There is also clearly a link between the portfolio of foreign affairs and defence policy issues. As the coalition's current spokesman on foreign affairs, I believe that it is important to be abreast of the capaissues and to comment on them. It is also important to continually monitor and assess developments on major defence issues confronting the country. The end of the Cold War has meant the end of direct and de superpower confrontation and the lifting of the pall which the threat of global or large scale regional war had previously brought to The end of the Cold War has brought with it new but sometimes uneasy balances. It has seen the coincident breakdown of order in the Balkans and in central Asia, just to mention aptwo. There have been some increasing tenover proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in north Asia, for example, which is in our own region. Also, in our own region, the spectacular economic success of some of Australia's neighbours has underpinned a steady improvement in regional defence capabilities and signals an inevitable end to our claims to continued technological superiority in defence capabilities. At the same time, there have been stresses and fractures in long established alliances and there have been renewed pressures on the will and the resources of multinational fora, such as the United Nations. These and other developments have raised new uncertainties and new challenges for defence policy makers. Australia is not immune from direct developments in our own region or from the flow-on effects from events further afield. I quote with approval paragraph 1.6 of the white paper, which I think puts it quite well: The next fifteen years will see great change strategic environment. With the end of the Cold War, important new uncertainties have emerged about the future strategic situation in Asia. nomic growth will increase the power of nations in our region, and political change may make their policies less predictable. Because of these uncertainties, we acknowledge the possibility that our security environment could deteriorate, perhaps quite seriously in the future. We recognise that some time in the future armed force could be used against us and that we need to be prepared to meet it. That is a useful summary contained in the early pages of this defence white paper. This is not to say-I do not say--or suggest that Australia suddenly finds itself in a new and threatening environment. But it does mean that the certainties of the Cold War are over and that Australia will have to work hard to promote and secure its own interests in a more fluid and potentially more volatile region. In that context, the coalition does welcome the government's interest in defence and the release of this paper. In February, the government released its long overdue Strategic review 1993. We also welcomed that but made the point that it was rather tardy in coming. In fact, it had merely followed the coalition's earlier policy initiative released in 1992, particularly as it relates to cooperative regional defence. This white paper has been too long in coming, but it is welcome despite that. However, having read it, I am just not sure whether it was worth the wait after all. It is sometimes stated by defence commentators in Australia that, leaving the Democrats and the Greens aside-you can safely discard them when it comes to sensible debate on these issues-there is a fair degree of common ground between the major parties on defence issues and that differences centre more on the scope and scale of defence preparedness and on issues of portfolio management than on the broad thrust of defence policy. There is some truth in this argument, but I stress that whilst there is some common ground between the government and the opposition this should not be seen as a guarantee of bipartisanship on defence policy issues. Far from it. There are substantial in our differences between the government and the coalition. When we read this white paper we find that it highlights our concerns and the Ecodifferences between ourselves and the government. For some time now we have held grave concerns about the way capabilities, operational readiness and personnel levels are at being whittled down under Labor stewardship. We are concerned about mismanagement and about the size of the defence bureaucracy. We see nothing in this white paper which will sensibly address these issues. Under Labor, our defence capability has been cut. Under the 1991 force structure review we lost two out of our six regular infantry battalions. The white paper proposes that the army can re-raise one of these battalions, but only by stripping manpower from somewhere else in an already depleted Australian Defence Force. It is a case of robbing Peter to pay Paul when you have already impoverished Paul. Mr Somlyay interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: Unknown
text: I can assure the honourable member that I am not referring to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister has not been impoverished by his years in office, as his latest purchase of a mansion in Sydney shows. Under Labor our fighter force has been pared from four to three squadrons and we have fewer surface combatants and fewer submarines available for operational service. That is a fact. During Labor's term in office our personnel numbers have dropped by almost 20 per cent. I recognise that some of that has been due to the introduction of the commercial support program. The opposition supports the CSP. I understand that there have been a lot of difficulties with the introduction and implementation of the CSP, but I think the government can go further with the CSP. I say that because I think people join our defence forces to be active in the principal roles of the defence forces and not to be doing those functions which could be contracted out. The opposition is concerned by the fall off in uniformed personnel, especially in combat elements. Sustainability levels have been shattered as the government trades off stockholding to meet underfunded recurrent expenditure bills. The much touted force structure review initiatives, such as the ready reserve scheme and the commercial support program to some extent, have simply failed to deliver the sorts of efficiencies and savings expected of them. The list goes on and on. There have been delays in the Collins project, mismanagement and debates about the ANZAC contract and we have had the ill-conceived ready reserve scheme which I think the government, in its heart of hearts, knows was ill-conceived from the word go. Virtually anybody who has looked at the scheme would come to that conclusion. The opposition has also been worried about the flea market approach to defence purchasing and the insidious erosion of conditions of service. At the heart of all this is the question of defence funding. In this context, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is not keen to promote debate about defence in this country. I went to a seminar recently where the minister was supposed to speak, but apparently he declined the invitation because he did not want to promote defence policy debate in this country which I think is a great shame. The minister is on the public record back in November 1992 talking about his role as Minister for Defence. When asked a question about defence funding, the minister told the Australian: ... that's how I'm judged (by the Chiefs of Staft)--can I deliver a politically reasonable base funding ... Yet in the 1994-95 budget allocations, spending on defence will drop to the lowest level as a percentage of government outlays since the last year of the Whitlam government. By the end of the current Labor term it will fall to the lowest per cent of GDP since before the Second World War. The minister says, 'Judge me by whether or not I have the political clout to keep the dollars going into defence,' but on his own criteria he fails miserably. This defence white paper is yet another confirmation of that sorry fact. The failure of the Minister for Defence to meet his own criteria路 for success as a minister has been recognised by the Labor Left. The incredible thing about Australian politics is that even the Left admits that cuts in personnel and operating costs have been to the detriment of readiness and morale. It put out a paper entitled 'The price of peace in an age of uncertainty' which acknowledges: Further defence cuts would raise concerns about Australia's capacity to fulfil its national goals in the area of defence self reliance, Foreign Affairs and the promotion of peace. That is exactly the direction in which this defence white paper and the government's policy is taking us. Mr Taylor- Mr Two Per Cent.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: Unknown
text: Mr Two Per Cent. Why would anybody believe that the two per cent is going to be maintained anyway? In the last white paper the government told us that it would keep defence spending between 2.6 and three per cent, which is what was necessary to keep the show on the road. Of course, that has been eroded. I have no doubt that the government will erode it further. Commonsense tells me that spending on defence is like writing out a cheque for home insurance. Honourable members know that, every year when they write out a cheque for insurance, they would have second thoughts and say, 'I will work on the basis that there will not be a fire this year because there has never been a fire' - I am lucky I have never had a fire bum down any of my homes-but common sense tells you to keep paying the premium. I believe that when it comes to Australia's defence forces we have to keep on paying the premium. Year in and year out, sadly, this government is whittling away Australia's defence efforts. At $9.87 billion in 1994-95, defence allocais tions will fall to 2.1 per cent of GDP. This is Labor. $21t2 billion dollars lower than if spending were pegged at the 1987 expectations raised by the government of a benchmark figure of three per cent. Clearly, the spending projections in the 1987 white paper have proved to be unrealistic and unsustainable. With the latest white paper imposing a cap of two per cent of GDP, the problem can only be exacerbated. I will put it in the most simple terms: when the government brought down its defence paper in 1987 it said, 'This is what we think we ought to do to defend Australia. This is the personnel and equipment that is necessary.' To achieve that the government would need to spend between 2.6 and three per cent of GDP. That was the way it was going to proceed. It did proceed and proceeded particularly on the capital equipment side. The opposition has supported the government in its commitments to buy new ships, submarines and other sorts of equipment. But the fact is that after it made the commitments it then started to cut back on defence spending. It was committed to various contracts and the like on the equipment side so, when it was short of a dollar, what did it do? It cut into readiness and personnel resources. We have great people in the Australian Defence Force and I pay tribute to the people who are prepared to serve our country in the defence forces. They have to put up with a hell of a lot. Within the last 12 months I spent a day out on HMAS Adelaide. I was most impressed by the work the captain and entire crew do. I have been to the RAAF base Pearce. You could not meet Australians more dedicated to the future of this country than those in either of those two situations and Defence Force in general. We are very lucky to have those people. That imposes an obligation on us to look after those who are prepared to serve their country. Let us look at the pay rates for some of our defence people. We pay some of our defence people so little by way of remuneration, take home pay, that they qualify to go around to Social Security for a welfare payment. That is a disgrace. Unfortunately, that the reality of defence spending under I have said in earlier speeches that it would be tragic for Australia's defence if the white paper simply sets about justifying existing structures and capabilities. It is the old trap of situating the appreciation rather than providing a disciplined analysis upon which defence policy and force structure planning can be solidly founded. Unfortunately, this has proved to be true. This white paper simply recycles the 1987 white paper, the 1991 force structure review and the 1993 strategic review. It offers very little that is new to the debate. It is less a policy review than an apology for the government's failure to fund its last white paper proposals. I conclude my response, which is a bit limited by nature of the schedule today, with three issues. The first goes to Labor's approach to regional defence cooperation. This government, which prides itself on its understanding of Asia, has not managed to strike the right balance in its proposals for closer regional defence cooperation. The 1994 defence white paper fails to recognise that the development of a sense of strategic community, which is so vital to continued regional stability, rests on a balanced effort to strengthen regional relationships as well as on direct bilateral ties. In our defence policy document A Strong Australia, released in 1992, the coalition unambiguously supported the strengthening of defence ties in the region under the aegis of cooperative regional defence. Our policy places particular emphasis on the development of defence cooperative arrangements, particularly where these serve to improve stability the through transparency and mutual understanding. We were heartened to see that this concept was picked up by the government in the 1993 Strategic Review and were pleased to see its similar acknowledgment in this latest white paper. The extension of Labor's strategic horizons beyond South-East Asia to North Asia, to include Japan, the Koreas, China and Taiwan, and the Indian subcontinent is also welcome. But, on Labor's record, we doubt whether it will be able to translate its expressions of good intention into effective action. Labor has too often displayed an inconsistency in its dealings with the region and this has, at times, caused some friction. Our relations with Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand have all been bedevilled by Labor's lack of balance and even-handedness. Sadly, I do not see any relief from this in the latest white paper. Indonesia, for example, is now touted by the defence minister as our most important relationship. I hope that this does not send confusing signals to our long standing defence partners in the region-particularly New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Singapore and Malaysia-who are partners in formal defence arrangements. Indonesia is important, but other regional players deserve appropriate regard. Relative size and proximity should not be the only determinants of the importance of bilateral relations. The coalition acknowledges the significant role which smaller and less proximate nations also play in promoting regional stability. It views the scope of relationships between regional nations to be no less important than the strength of discrete bilateral relations. While the government is right to focus on the development of bilateral relationships, it must not lose sight of the need to promote regional, and not just bilateral, cooperation. And it should" not overlook the fact that our bilateral cooperative programs also offer opportunities for promoting interaction between regional counterparts. In particular, concurrent attendance by officers from regional nations at courses at our military and academic institutions offers far greater scope for effective and cooperative interaction than a purely bilateral course. Similarly, we should seek to promote seminars and discussions at the senior policy and strategic levels on a broader than bilateral basis. The bottom line is that we must ensure that our finite defence cooperative resources are put to the most efficient and mutually beneficial use. By mutually beneficial, I mean regional and not just bilateral benefit. The second matter I raise is a rather specific, one, but it is on my mind because I have been reading the papers this morning about the Prime Minister and his interest in foreign affairs matters. It reminds me that the skills you learn as a wheeler and dealer in the New South Wales Right are not always appropriately transferred and applied in the matter of sensitive international relations. I refer particularly to two paragraphs in the defence white paper. The first is paragraph 2.17, which refers to Taiwan. It states in part: The relationship between China and Taiwan is likely to evolve in response to political change in both, but in a direction that is not easy to foretell. I also quote an interesting statement from paragraph 8.29. It states: In time, opportunities also may arise for constructive contact with Taiwan on defence and security issues. My attention was drawn to this, not just because of the newspaper reports this morning but also because of the fact that in the last two or three months I have been in both China and Taiwan and there are some very interesting issues which Australian policymakers should be addressing. There has been a continuation of the political liberalisation in Taiwan. When I was there, I was able to see for myself the vibrant democracy at work as elections were being held for the mayoral positions in both Taipei and Kaohsiung in the south, and there was also an election for the position of Governor of Taiwan Province. It is interesting that, in the outcome, the DPP was successful in wresting the mayoral position in Taipei from the ruling party. The interest in that is that this is yet another signal of the development of a multi-party political system in Taiwan. Taiwan has an interesting history. When I was there, the KMT was enjoying its lOath anniversary. The KMT has had a chequered past-I think that is a fair comment to make-but it is very interesting to see in Taiwan the unilateral handing over of political power by a monopolist political party to establish a multi-party, democratic system. It is a matter of great tribute to the leaders of the society in Taiwan that those who have held power have been prepared to share power and to establish a democratic system. Mr Lindsay-It has taken a long time.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: Unknown
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (6.24 p.m.)-I move: That this House: (1) congratulates the International Labour Organiconstitution sation (ILO) on the 75th anniversary of its foundation and on the 50th anniversary of adoption of the Declaration of Philadelphia; (2) notes that Australia was a founding member of the International Labour Organisation when was formed in 1919 with 45 member states; (3) notes that on this anniversary, as a result of the ongoing international support for the Organisation, there are now 171 member states; (4) recognises and appreciates the uniqueness of the Organisation within the framework of UN specialised agencies by way of its tripartite structure, which enables governments, employers and workers to participate directly in its activities; (5) reaffirms its support for the important role played by the ILO as an international forum dedicated to the objectives of promoting and raising labour and social standards with a view to advancing social justice and ensuring world peace; and (6) wishes the ILO continued success in building links of friendship and understanding through the improvement of working conditions, general welfare and the human rights of working people and their families throughout the world. Australia was a founding member of the ILO in 1919 and has been an active participant in the ILO throughout its 75-year history. I am pleased to say that the ILO has always enjoyed bipartisan support in this country. Throughout the world governments of all political persuasions have recognised the importance of the ILO and supported its work. Since 1919, the membership has grown from 45 countries to virtual universal membership by 171 countries today. I am particularly pleased to note that South Africa is the newest member. South Africa rejoined the ILO this year after a 3D-year absence following the election in April of President Nelson Mandela's government of national unity. The ILO can count among its many achievements the vitally important contribution it has made to overcoming the abhorrent regime of apartheid in South Africa. The ILO was founded on the belief of social justice and to provide basic human rights for working people. The ILO's mandate, reflected in its and in the 1944 Declaration of Philadelphia, continues to be as relevant today the as it was at the time of its adoption. It includes respect for human rights, decent living standards, humane working conditions, emit ployment opportunities and economic security. The ILO can boast a commendable record in fulfilling its mandate. It can truly reflect on its 75 years and say that it has been a most effective international organisation. That is an assessment not just of this government but of many leading world figures. On the occasion of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the ILO in 1969, the Chairman of the Nobel Committee said: There are few organisations that have succeeded, to the extent that the ILO has succeeded, lating into action the fundamental moral idea on which it is based ... Working earnestly and untiringly, the ILO has succeeded in introducing reforms that have removed the most flagrant injustices in a great many countries . . . His Holiness, Pope John Paul II, when he gave an audience to the chairman of the ILO governing body in 1992, congratulated the ILO for putting social dialogue and tripartite cooperation at the forefront of its considerations. President Nelson Mandela, in contributing to the volume of essays entitled Visions of the Future of Social Justice on the occasion of the ILO's 75th anniversary, wrote: The present situation in South Africa, where路 a majority of the population is trying to rectify experience of generations of systematic exclusion from the most basic rights and benefits, highlights the ongoing relevance of the ILO mandate. Many South Africans are only now recognising that lasting peace can be established only on the basis of social justice, 75 years after it was expounded as the founding principle of the ILO. Through the adoption, ratification and application of international labour standards by member states, the ILO's relevant is continually reinforced. Australia has ratified 54 of the ILO's 175 conventions, including the fundamental standards concerning freedom of association, abolition of forced labour, discrimination of employment, equality of opportunity and tripartite consultation. These standards have played a very significant role in improving employment conditions for all of Australia's working men and women. Our landmark Industrial Relations Reform Act has, for the first time, given all Australian workers access to key minimum standards based on ILO conventions. It opens the 'way for Australian workplaces to become more productive and more internationally competitive. It does so within a secure framework of comprehensive minimum standards underpinned by the award system and complementary entitlements based on relevant international standards. Ratification of ILO conventions has advanced the rights of workers throughout the world across a very broad spectrum. The in transfundamental conventions on freedom of association, forced labour and quality of opportunity, have now been ratified by well over 100 countries. Together they constitute a vital safety net of industrial protection. The fact that ratified ILO conventions are binding has also helped in countries where there has been a chance of their slipping backwards and adopting regressive legislation. However ILO conventions are by no means rigid, inflexible or overly prescriptive documents. The ILO assesses the need to revise its conventions on an ongoing basis. This ensures that they remain compatible with the realities of modem labour markets. Through its conferences, meetings and technical cooperation activities, the ILO is constantly exposed to the reality of the the changing labour market conditions in each and every one of its 171 member states. This experience is invaluable in assisting those member states in their implementation of conventions, in the development of new standards, and in the revision of existing standards. The full and independent participation of employer and worker organisations in the work of ILO also ensures that standards are kept up to date. More broadly, the ILO is uniquely placed to play a major part in improving social and labour conditions, as it is the only tripartite institution at an international level. . The government is presently evaluating several ILO conventions concerning basic human rights, occupational health and safety, and a range of other issues. A number of these conventions are included in Australia's national action plan on human rights, released earlier this year. Our target is to ratify the conventions progressively over the next five years. We will pursue this objective in full consultation with the states and territories, with employers and with the trade union movement. The government is also consulting with the states and territories concerning the possible ratification of ILO convention 169 on indigenous and tribal peoples. This international agreement is the only international convention which exclusively deals with the rights of indigenous peoples. Consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations is also a fundamental precondition to the ratification of this important international convention. There has sometimes been ill-informed comment about how Australia's sovereignty is affected by our international obligations and about the effect of conventions on states rights. The ratification of ILO conventions a decision that each member of the ILO takes in the free exercise of its own sovereignty. determining whether to become a party to a convention, successive Australian governin ments have considered whether the relevant convention is consistent with our national interests. Ratification creates binding international obligations on Australia to recognise and to apply in law and in practice the provisions of the ratified convention. The ILO has a well developed system of monitoring a country's practical application of the provisions of a ratified convention. ILO conventions have normally been ratified by Australia where our law and practice satisfy the convention. Ratification invariably follows extensive consultation with state and territory governments and the peak employer and union bodies through the National Labour Consultative Council. With the increasing globalisation of the world of work, the ILO's basic principles and standards of freedom of association are relevant today than they ever have been. This is particularly true in the Asia-Pacific region, where many countries are looking to work partnership with the ILO to establish plans technical cooperation in labour law, labour relations, employment promotion and training. There is a growing awareness in Australia of the need for a closer, more cooperative relationship between Australia and the countin ries of our region. We are strongly committed to playing an active role in promoting ecofor nomic and social development of the region ship, in many fields, and that includes employment and labour issues. A joint Australian-ILO project is assisting the governments of eight South Pacific island countries to improve the standards of their own policy and administration and, in the process, to significantly lift the productivity of their work forces. This project commenced in 1990 and has been highly successful, achieving higher levels of workplace safety and health and more cooperative industrial relations. It has been widely acclaimed by all parties and has been independently evaluated is by Coopers and Lybrand, which described it as 'an excellent example of effective developIn ment assistance in the South Pacific'. A second project with the ILO commenced February 1993. It is a tripartite project involving Australian advisory and training services to provide assistance to labour ministries, trade unions and employer organisations in Indonesia, China, Vietnam, Thailand and Malaysia. Although only in operation for some 18 months now, it is a program that is already having a substantial and positive effect. Most importantly, it has established an internationally acceptable model by which Australia can play a constructive role in the very sensitive area of labour rights and standards. To build on these efforts, we have established an Asia Desk in the Department of Industrial Relations. It is aimed at strengthening our focus on assisting the development of sound industrial relations throughout the Asia-Pacific region. The government has provided funds in this year's budget to support our industrial relations initiatives in Asia and particularly our more role in implementing our memorandum of understanding on industrial relations cooperation with Indonesia, a memorandum that we in signed in November last year. I am also for pleased that we will be working with the ILO to assist its programs in our region on combating the exploitation of children at work. Let me conclude by saying that I believe the ILO needs to continue to play a key role guiding and influencing international social policy development. It is uniquely well placed this, given the universality of its memberits tripartite structure, its machinery for development and supervising standards, its principles, its values and its 75 years of operational experience. International organisations are strong and effective only if they are supported by their constituents. In Australia, the political parties and the social partners have firmly supported the ILO's principles and its work throughout its 75-year history. The ILO conference this year unanimously adopted a resolution which called on all member states and employers' and workers' organisations to reaffirm the principles and fundamental values upon which the ILO was founded. I trust that the House, in adopting this motion, will join with the international community in reaffirming our support for the vital work of the ILO in advancing social justice and human rights of working people and their families throughout the whole world.

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Title: Unknown
text: La Trobe) (6.36 p.m.)The opposition joins with the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in congratulating the International Labour Organisation, the ILO, on the 75th anniversary of its founding. There is no doubt that the ILO has performed a very valuable service and is a very respected organisation in world social and equity terms. The International Labour Organisation was founded in 1919 under the Treaty of Versailles. After World War I, representatives of countries present at the peace conference framed a Constitution and an Enumeration of Principles for the International Labour Organisation. These texts would become Part XIII of the Treaty of Versailles. The organisation was formed to improve labour and social conditions. For example, the preamble states: . .. universal justice and lasting peace can be established only if it is based upon social Right from its inception, the ILO has encouraged all nations to join its organisation. According to the preamble: The failure of any nation to adopt humane conditions of labour is an obstacle in the way of other nations which desire to improve the conditions in their own countries . . . The 42 members of the League of Nations, including Australia, were the founding members of the ILO. Germany was admitted to the organisation in 1926 and the United States in 1934. It could well be said that the operations of the ILO-certainly through the early years-were dominated by European nations and by the developing culture in Europe of a social partnership between labour and capital. The idea emerged and then became the foundation of bureaucratic institutionsincluding the ILO-in such countries as Austria and Germany, where social compacts led to very heavily bureaucratised industrial relations systems. In such cases legislation is often not needed because all work practices are frequently sorted out before such issues ever even reach government. They are sorted out through total bureaucratic mechanisms. It has been said recently that highly centralised industrial relations systems, such as those throughout much of Europe, are reasonably efficient. It is also said that highly deregulated industrial relations systems, such as the one found in the United States, are relatively efficient. But Australia, caught in this time warp in the middle of deciding whether or not we will be highly regulated and centralised or whether we will be deregulated and open, is caught in a problem with makes us less efficient than either one of the others. While we have always supported the ILO and continue to do so, it causes some diffiCUlty. One difficulty we have is the way this Labor government selectively uses ILO conventions through the external affairs power of the constitution to back legislation which otherwise would offend the constitutional powers of the various states. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) in his speech to the House a few moments ago talked about sovereignty. He talked about justice maintaining the sovereignty of Australia through the links of our international treaties. What the minister forgets is that we are giving away a portion of our sovereignty, we have reduced our sovereignty, by allowing international bureaucratic organisations to an extent to make laws which under other circumstances we might not have made. I was pleased to hear the minister say that when he considers Australia signing and ratifying a number of conventions for the government he will consult widely with the states, with employers and with union bodies. I trust that he will live up to that statement, that he will consult well and that he will seek the agreement of the ,states before he signs such instruments on behalf of all the Australian people. Two examples come to mind of where this government has used conventions, I believe Every quite improperly, to override the powers of the states. The first recent example was when join the Minister for Industrial Relations used n..o convention 137, signed and ratified in 1974, 20 years ago, a convention that we have had simply: no need to use for some considerable time because it dealt with the issue of containerisever, ation in the ports. The minister attempted to use that convention to allow the waterfront union movement through the finance tee to reintroduce employer levies and pooling of employees to create once again a register which the Waterfront Industry Reform AuthWorkers ority had attempted to do away with. The second instance is the Industrial Relations Reform Act, which came into being on 30 March this year as an amendment to the Industrial Relations Act. The minister spoke of that briefly, talking about using the n..O convention to give every Australian worker minimum rights of protection guaranteed. But he has used the n..O convention to override what are state rights. They are written into the constitution as the rights of the states to make laws with respect to industrial matters except where a dispute occurs crossing the borders of two states, in which case the Commonwealth has jurisdiction. So the minister has improperly, in my view, used n..o conventions to legislate to enable his legislation to override state legislation because there was no other way under the constitution that he could do it. One area of concern where we differ with the n..O is the issue of freedom of association. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights, article 20(2) states: No one shall be compelled to belong to an associa tion. I believe very strongly in freedom of association. People in our country-hopefully everyone in the world-should have the right to belong or not to belong to any organisation that they choose: a union, a management organisation, a community organisation, any kind of organisation. One of our basic rights should be freedom of association. Article 22 of the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights states: person has the right to freedom of association with others, including the right to form and trade unions for the protection of that person's interests. But n..O convention No. 87, article 2, says Workers and employers, without distinction whatsoshall have the right to establish and, subject only to the rules of the organisation concerned, to join organisations of their own choosing without commitprevious authorisation. Convention No. 98, article 1, in part says: shall enjoy adequate protection against acts of anti-union discrimination in respect of their employment. I agree with the sentiments expressed in those articles absolutely. But the n..o does not go on in any of its articles, in any of its conventions, to define the right that a worker or an individual shall also have, an equal right, not to belong to a union of trades-'shall have the right not to belong'. That is a very important difference in principle which we on this side of the House hold dear and which those on the other side of the House, with a Labor government that is indebted to the trade union movement and to the trade union organisations, will not endorse in any way. The minister talks about the tripartite nature of the n..O. I wish to bring to the attention of the House that in Australia, as in the majority of industrialised nations in the Western world, the rate of union membership is once again falling. A recent article defined, and the Australian Bureau of Statistics has confirmed, th -.t in August 1993 union membership was down to 37.6 per cent of the work force compared with 39.6 per cent in August 1992. - The' unionisation rate at that time in the private sector was 27.5 per cent compared with 29.4 per cent in August 1992. The rate of decline in the public sector was higher, with the proportion of public sector employees who were union members down from 67.1 per cent in 1992 to 64.4 per cent last year. So all categories of union membership are showing falls. That is because of two factors. One is that unions are finding that they are less and less relevant to the needs of employees in workplaces, who today feel much more inclined to negotiate their industrial issues, their pay structures and their working conditions directly with their employer. So the two of them can work together to achieve a highly productive and high quality outcome for their firm. According to the AAP this morning, the New South Wales Labor Council Secretary Peter Sams has warned that the union movement is in danger of losing its power to lobby government. The ACTU executive meeting in Melbourne this week was told that union membership affiliated with the ACTU had fallen over the last year by 400,000 to 2.4 million. Mr Sams evidently told guests at路 a breakfast meeting in Sydney this morning that the correct number was more likely to be closer to two million. That is a fall of 800,000 in a very short period. Mr Sams said it was vital that a new membership drive succeed. He stated: 'If we can't do it now in 1995 with an improving economy and good employment growth then we are never going to do it and we will end up as a rump, as an unrepresentative group of people that meet from time to time and create a bit of ruckus', Mr Sams said. 'But we won't actually have a major representation or a major representative organisation in which we can lobby government for the things we believe in. I think issue and address it wholeheartedly in 1995, then we will be in for a very long period in which our influence will be marginalised. The tripartite nature of the ILO, about which the minister spoke so eloquently, is in danger in Australia from the union movement destroying itself because of its lack of relevance to a modern work force dedicated to improving productivity, improving wage rates路 and improving the lives of those who work for Australia's industry. text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for considerand report: Con"struction of a multi-level car for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melbourne Airport. Melbourne airport is the second busiest in Australia. It is subject to continuing growth for in passenger movements and, as a consequence, the present short-term car park is comsuffering severe congestion and frequent closure. As this growth in passenger numbers is forecast to continue for the foreseeable it is necessary for the corporation, in order to provide an appropriate level of service to its customers, to increase the of the short-term car park. As it is desirable that short-term car parking spaces be provided as close as possible to the terminal, it is preferable that the increased capacity be provided in a multi-level structure adjacent to the passenger terminal, rather than through further ground level parking. The proposed work involves the construction of a four-level, open-sided concrete car park, consisting of a covered ground level of 20,869 square metres, three suspended decks, including the open roof level, totalling 58,665 square metres, and a ground floor open car park of 23,500 square metres. text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Maralinga rehabilitation project, SA. This project is being conducted by my department. The Maralinga and Emu sites are located in South Australia in the region north of the Nullarbor Plain. Maralinga is 270 kilometres north-west of Ceduna. Emu is 190 kilometres north-east of Maralinga. Between 1953 and 1963, Great Britain conducted several programs of nuclear warhead development trials at Maralinga and Emu. These included detonations of nine nuclear weapons and hundreds of so-called 'minor trials' that dispersed radioactive materials. The former test site areas are contaminated to various levels with plutonium and other artificially produced radioisotopes that present an unacceptable risk to future users of the sites. In 1969 Britain undertook a program of clean-up works called Operation Brumby. The 1985 royal commission into British nuclear tests in Australia concluded that Operation Brumby was inadequate, based on wrong assumptions and left the area in a more difficult state for any further clean-up. The royal commission concluded, inter alia, that action should begin immediately to effect a clean-up of Maralinga and Emu to a level where they are suitable for unrestricted habitation by the traditional Aboriginal owners. A technical assessment group, TAG, was formed in February 1986 to address technical matters stemming from the royal commission. A three-year program of scientific and engineering studies by TAG developed a range of rehabilitation options and comparative costs. TAG's report was tabled in parliament in 1990. During 1990, the Commonwealth government agreed on a preferred rehabilitation option for the Maralinga test sites as a basis on which to seek a substantial contribution to rehabilitation works from the British government. This clean-up option is the lowest cost option developed by TAG that would enable Aborigines to resume access to the former test site areas. It is intended that upon completion of the project the test site area will be returned to South Australian control for addition to the Maralinga Tjarutja freehold lands. In December 1993, the Australian and British governments concluded an agreement under which Britain will pay 拢20 million in an ex gratia settlement of Australia's claims concerning the British nuclear test program in Australia. This amount will be paid in six annual instalments. The first instalment of 拢5 million was paid in December 1993. The proposed clean-up will reduce the radiological hazards at the test sites to enable Aboriginal use of and transit through the test site area, reduce and possibly eliminate the need for control and surveillance of the sites and remove potential Commonwealth liabilities arising from site contamination. The majority of the works will be undertaken at Maralinga, including: installation of a construction camp at Maralinga village; upgrading of general site infrastructure; construction of burial trenches; collection of contaminated soil and placement in burial trenches; stabilisation of material in selected debris pits and removal of contents from other debris pits to burial trenches; and general clean-up and surface restoration and revegetation of disturbed areas. . Work at Emu will involve the ripping up of roads to discourage access to the site. All work in the contaminated areas of the site will be undertaken under strict controls. It is anticipated that work will commence in mid1995 for completion in late 1999 at an estimated cost of $104.4 million at November 1994 prices. I would not recommend the committee attend this particular site until after the restoration is complete. I commend the motion to the House.

Western Australia: Electoral System

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: Unknown
text: It is a fundamental tenet of democracy that all people are regarded as equal. The fundamental principle of one vote one value is reflected in the Commonwealth Electoral Act and our electoral system. That reflects the tenet of people being equal and their votes being equal. Unfortunately, this is not reflected by the parliament, the electoral act or the electoral system in my own state of Western Australia. Members should be aware that no legislation has ever been enacted in Western Australia without the support of the state colleagues of those opposite. The conservatives have always dominated the Legislative Council in Western Australia, so the electoral system in Western Australia is determined by them. I draw the attention of the House to the recent redistribution of the state parliament effected by the Western Australian government Gazette of Monday, 28 November. The electoral system required by the conservative controlled Legislative Council of Western Australia has the effect of dividing the state into a metropolitan area and a country area. It is interesting to note that of the 1,034,000 enrolled voters at the time the redistribution was effected, over 760,000 of those were in the metropolitan area and over 270,000 were in the country area. There are 34 Legislative' Assembly seats allocated in the metropolitan area, so that is 34 for 760,000-an average enrolment of 22,370-and 23 seats in the country area for just over 270,000-an average enrolment of 11,887. Members can see that the vote weighting is two to one. When you look at the electoral statistics released by the Electoral Commission at the time of the redistribution and then look at the current boundaries on the same electoral system determined by the conservative controlled Legislative Council, you find that the greatest number of enrolled voters in the metropolitan area is in the seat of Wanneroo, which is in the electorate held by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). The current enrolment in that seat is 30,885. The country seat with the lowest number of enrolled voters is Ashburton. That seat has 8,610 voters. So we have nearly a four to one weighting there. On the new boundaries, the greatest number of enrolled voters in the metropolitan area are in the seat of Belmont. Those 23,511 voters can be compared with the 10,363 voters in the seat of Pilbara. That is before the quotient variant of 15 per cent comes into play. So we can see what those opposite and their state colleagues stand for when it comes to treating people equally. In the West Australian of Thursday, 1 December, I was very interested to see reference made to the President of the Liberal Party of Western Australia. The article entitled 'Honey on a Return Ticket' states: Liberal Party State president David Honey went on a strange journey to one-vote one-value and back yesterday. Perhaps the heat got to him, but Dr Honey first declared himself in favour of ending vote-weighting in elections to the Legislative Assembly and then did a back-flip after a chat with Premier Richard Court. The article goes on to say: . . . soon after, Mr Court appeared in the office The West Australian at Parliament House and said Dr Honey would be calling because he had got it wrong. Dr Honey called within five minutes and said the party supported vote-weighting. He had called back after speaking to Mr Court because he had misstated party policy. So that reflects the commitment of the state colleagues of those opposite to vote weighting and electoral system rorting. I must say that I was dismayed to see a few days later in the West Australian of Monday, 5 December that same David Honey, who one minute before he spoke to Premier Court was in favour of a review of the Electoral Act to take away vote-weighting, had this to say under an article entitled 'Boundary changes draw Liberal fire': Liberal Party state president David Honey has attacked the new WA electoral boundaries, saying they are diabolical ... Dr Honey said the electoral Act needed to be reviewed. It goes on to report: Dr Honey said the Government should consider amending the Electoral Act so that the commission - ould redraw the boundary of the Upper House's Mining and Pastoral Region to take in some of the area covered by the Agricultural Region. So they want rorts within rorts in Western Australia. They are not committed to people casting equal votes; they are not committed to the basic notion of equality; and they are quite prepared to see a gross malapportionment occur in Western Australia. Mainstream elements of the Western Australian Liberal Party do not believe that people's votes ought to be equal. In fact, half of them do not believe that some people should be entitled to have a vote. An article in the West Australian in August 1992, after the Liberal Party's state annual conference of that year, headed 'Plan to end forced voting' states: The Liberal Party's annual state conference yesterday backed a call to end compulsory voting in state and federal elections . . . The president of the Canning division, Mrs Ricky 10hnstonwho has been a candidate for the seat of Canning on a number of occasions. .. said it was not compulsory to actually vote. She goes on to say: of A compulsory system meant "dregs of society" got a say whereas with voluntary voting only those who were interested actually cast a vote. So those on the other side of the chamber do not believe that votes ought to be equal. They also believe that people who actually have a vote are the 'dregs of society'. No doubt this attitude is adopted largely because their so called 'dregs of society' do not vote for them. Sydney Airport: Third Runway

Title: Unknown

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: Unknown
text: From a very low base, though.

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: Unknown
text: Of course. I do not deny that at all. I was very impressed today to find that he was able to say that cabinet will be tackling a range of measures in the next day or so-it was all happening tomorrow. So he can move mountains as far as cabinet meetings are concerned. I hope he can move mountains as far as noise over Sydney is concerned. I have some doubt about that. But I would put to him tonight, in view of the fact that cabinet is meeting tomorrow, that the solution to the problem in the area to the south of the north-south runway is simple. We do not have to have planes directed to the north, to the west, to the east-wherever. All we need to have is the flight paths that have existed for 22 years, which were changed on 4 November when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) opened the new runway. We want those flight paths returned to what they were two months ago. If that happens, planes will no longer be flying at 800 feet above the suburb of Kurnell, which they have never flown over before, nor will they be flying over the Kurnell oil refinery at 1,000 feet. No airport in the world allows planes to fly over areas at 1,000 feet. Rather than find fault with the Minister for Transport, I say to him, if he should read this paper before the cabinet meeting tomorrow

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: Unknown
text: Do you think he will?

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: Unknown
text: I would hope he does, because he is reading an awful lot of stuff that comes from this side of the House at the moment. As one of the longest serving members of this House, I must say that I am so impressed-unbelievably impressed-that this Labor government is so influenced by the words and statements of the members of Liberal-National state governments and of the members who sit on the coalition side of this House that it changes not mountains but airports. We are being blamed for the twoyear delay on Badgerys Creek, which the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) cleverly put forward today. I say to him in the kindest and the most friendly of manners: if you think that is going to happen in your term here in this parliament, forget it. As far as the airport in Sydney is concerned, the east and the west of the airport have massive problems. I am not addressing those this week, but I am addressing the problems that are facing the people of Kurnell-an isolated part of my electorate which the member for Kingsford-Smith looks out upon. I tremble to admit to the House that he and I are in fact political neighbours. We meet occasionally in surf club situations-not in football clubs, Mr Speaker, as you and I meet in the area. I am impressed that, with only 1,800 people there, people have gone to live there with their small families. Why? Because it is isolated from the normal suburbs of Sydney and because they have the advantage of having their own beach. It is a delightful spot which has been totally and utterly ruined by the acts of the last four weeks. Though I rose and praised the Minister for Transport for moving the cabinet, I sincerely put to him that he can solve one problem very simply in the cabinet meeting tomorrow by returning the flight paths over to the northern part of Sutherland shire to what they were before his leader opened the third runway on 4 November. I will be speaking again this week on this same subject. Queensland National Party

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: Unknown
text: In today's Bulletin, the Queensland National Party made it brutally clear that the Joh campaign rides again. Today in the Bulletin, Joh's offsider and mouthpiece, Mr Ken Crooke-you might recall that Mr Crooke was Joh's press secretary for many years and is the current Director of the National Party in Queensland-described the federal coalition as 'wishy-washy'. He described the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), as an appeaser. These are fighting words. They are deliberately designed to wound, mock and ridicule the Leader of the Opposition. It is pretty clear that the Queensland Nationals are hell-bent on smashing the coalition at both the federal and state levels. The first shot in this war, in this new Joh campaign, was fired on 15 November when Don MCDonald, the President of the Queensland National Party, issued an ultimatum to the Queensland Liberal Party to agree to a joint Senate ticket in that state or face the repercussions. The repercussions of failure to agree to a joint Senate ticket would be three-cornered contests-three-cornered contests in seats like Fisher, Longman and Groom. That ultimatum, which was delivered by the Queensland Nationals to the Liberals, has passed. Today we have what I think is the second shot in that campaign. Today's Bulletin states: Crooke believes conservative supporters are dismayed by Downer's equivocal stance on sexual privacy and racial hatred issues. Mr Crooke says: If you are going to succeed, people want to where you stand ... People are sick to death this wishy-washy waffle. The coalition needs define itself clearly on matters straddle the barbed-wire fence, you get hurt in all the wrong places. Mr Crooke was joined in that campaign by the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who had this to say: A lot of Liberals have been very appreciative stand I've taken. Downer is trying to appease small-'l' people in the Liberal Party, but that has antagonised and disillusioned people in the coalidivisive tion ... You have got to be a mug to go along with the Labor Partylike the Liberals. It continues: If I was in the Liberal party I would be clearly worried about the polls. The Liberal Party is clearly very worried by the polls. Thinking about those statements, they may not have come from the member for Kennedy; they could well have come from National Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and that is the point. The point about these attacks by the memin ber for Kennedy is that they all before. They all occurred in 1987 when the Nationals humiliated their leader at the time, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), and pushed him out of the coalition. When is the member for Kennedy going to do that with the current Leader the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer)? When is the push going to come land from inside the National Party caucus to were really put the pressure on the National Party? It is crunch time for the Leader of the National Party as much as it crunch time for the Leader of the Opposition. I know what the answer would be to these questions if we asked the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) or the member for Groom (Mr Taylor). They would say, 'Take them on. can't take any more of these divisive tactics / from the National Party. We don't want a repeat of the Joh for PM campaign of 1987. We will stand up to the Nationals.' Because who will be the candidate for the National Party in the federal seat of Fisher at the next election? It will be none other than the son of the Joh Bjelke-Petersen-John Bjelke-Petersen. The lad is looking for something useful to do. He needs a job, so he is now intending to know make his bid on the back of this new camof paign from the Queensland Nationals to split to the coalition. The Bjelke-Petersen forces of principle-if you strike back. In 1987 we had the jack-in-the-box, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who dreamed of being PM, and the Queensland Nationals took it all away from him. Where is the honourable member for of the Bennelong tonight? Is he up there with the Leader of the Opposition, talking about these tactics from the National Party? Is he out there condemning the National Party? Can we expect him to say something to the press about the Liberal Party and the National Party at another one of those famous doorstops where he does not really talk about anything, does not talk about a leadership challenge? Is he going to come in, stand shoulder to shoulder with the Leader of the Opposition, and repudiate the tactics from the Queensland Party? If he is not, we all know what he is really up to: that is, he will make his bid the new year. If we expect him to do that, occurred I would think pigs might fly. Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: Unknown
text: I remind the House that the honourable leader of to whom Mr Swan referred, Mr BjelkePetersen, won in his last election in Queenswith nearly 60 per cent of the vote. If he still there, he would still be giving that Leader of the mob a terrible hiding. The farmers of Australia got $164 million is off the federal government. Very regretfully, I think a lot of the farming organisations which laid on their backs and had their tummies scratched by the federal government were lavish in their praise for the $164 We million they received. A couple of weeks later, the arts in Australia got $252 million and the ANL employees effectively got around $250 million, but the $164 million was not given to the farmers; it was given to the banks. Effectively, that money goes as a subsidy on the farmers' interest, and that means that the money goes to the banks and not to the farmers; If the banks were borrowing money at five per cent and lending it out at six per cent, I would say, 'Fair enough.' But, at the present moment, the banks are borrowing at five per cent and lending it to the farmers at 10 per cent, and the difference is being made up by the Australian taxpayers. Not only is this unfair but also it is toweringly stupid. Not only was the $164 million supposed to be good for us-the farmers in this case-but straight afterwards we had a 1% per cent rise in interest rates foisted upon us by the federal government. That led to a $302 million a year extra burden upon the farmers of Australia who owe $17,000 million. At the start of the ALP decade, they owed only some $4,700 million. That tripped off a rise in the Australian dollar which saw farmers lose $540 million per year. So, whilst we got $164 million, we now find ourselves in a situation where we have been hit with a bill from the actions of the federal government of an extra $842 million per year. Thank you; it is a lovely Christmas present from the federal government. It indicates clearly the government's treatment of the farming sector of Australia.
